                  </DefinitionList>
                </AbbreviationGroup>
              </ArticleHeader>
              <Body>
                <Section1 ID="Sec1">
                  <Heading>Introduction</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par19">Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death within the United States (Siegel et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">2016</CitationRef>). The TNM staging system developed by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC)/Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) is the primary means for classifying patient disease status and predicting patient prognosis, with the most recent 8
                    <Superscript>th</Superscript> edition recently introduced by the International Association for the Study of Lung Cancer (IASLC) (Detterbeck et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>; Asamura et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">2015</CitationRef>; Rami-Porta et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR4">2015</CitationRef>; Goldstraw et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">2016</CitationRef>). Stage 3B Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) now comprises patients without distant metastases (M0) who have stage T3 or T4 primary disease, with ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal nodal metastases (N2), as well as patients with T1 or T2 primary disease with metastases in scalene, supraclavicular, contralateral mediastinal or contralateral hilar lymph nodes (N3). In other words, Stage 3B encompasses a wide range of primary tumor burden, including patients with primary tumors ranging from &lt;1 cm (T1a) to ≥7 cm (T4) in greatest dimension and N0 to N3 nodal metastases.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par20">For patients with locally advanced lung cancer, fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) enables detection of CT-occult, metabolically active tumor. Maximum standardized uptake value (SUVmax) is an established measurement of maximal tumor metabolic activity and facilitates identification of tumor metastases, but it fails to take into account total tumor abundance/burden. Quantitative FDG measurements, namely the amount of whole body metabolic tumor volume (MTVwb) and total lesion glycolysis (TLGwb), may be used to quantify both total tumor burden and metabolic activity. These parameters have been found to be associated with OS for both surgical and non-surgical NSCLC patients, after adjusting for clinical stage (Liao et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">2012a</CitationRef>; Zhang et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR7">2013a</CitationRef>; Zhang et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">2013b</CitationRef>). These PET/CT metrics have yet to be evaluated for Stage 3B NSCLC patients (Ohri et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">2015</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par21">Patients with Stage 3B NSCLC are rarely surgical candidates due to mediastinal invasion or extensive nodal disease, and are routinely treated with combined radiation and chemotherapy, though options are constantly evolving to cater to a more individualized patient-centered therapeutic approach (Rocco et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR10">2016</CitationRef>). The overall survival (OS) of Stage 3B NSCLC patients at 2 and 5 years is 44% and 26%, respectively (Goldstraw et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">2016</CitationRef>). If we can identify additional prognostic markers for these patients, we may be able to better stratify Stage 3B NSCLC patients, and determine who is more likely to benefit from more aggressive therapy.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par22">Here we aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of MTVwb, TLGwb, and SUVmaxwb, on baseline FDG PET/CT in patients with Stage 3B NSCLC.</Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec2">
                  <Heading>Materials and methods</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par23">This Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act compliant retrospective study received institutional review board approval. The need for informed consent was waived.</Para>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec3">
                    <Heading>Patient cohort</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par24">Utilizing a retrospective search of our health information system, patients were included if they met both of the following inclusion criteria: a. diagnosed with Stage 3B NSCLC in accordance with the 8
                      <Superscript>th</Superscript> edition of the TNM classification system; and b. received baseline staging PET/CT between February 2004 and Dec 2014. Patients were excluded if they either: 1. received prior lung cancer treatment, including chemotherapy, radiation, or surgery; or 2. had a second primary cancer diagnosed from 5 years before to 2 months after the FDG PET/CT scan conducted for NSCLC diagnosis and staging. 110 consecutive patients were identified from center A and served as the training set. The external validation set included 44 patients managed and imaged at institution B from 2008 to 2014. These patients received a FDG PET/CT within 3 months of starting radiation therapy.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par25">Patient demographics, clinical information, and follow-up were collected from the health information system. Patients were censored at date of last contact.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec4">
                    <Heading>PET/CT acquisition</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par26">Imaging was performed on a Siemens mCT scanner (Siemens Healthcare, Knoxville, Tenn) or Reveal HD scanner (CTI, Knoxville, Tenn). All patients fasted for a minimum of 4 h prior to imaging, confirmed by fingerstick serum blood glucose levels &lt;200 mg/dl. Patients were injected with 370-555 MBq 
                      <Superscript>18</Superscript>F–FDG. At center A (the training dataset), whole body PET/CT imaging was acquired approximately 90 min later. At center B (the validation dataset), patients were scanned approximately 60 min later. Concomitant low-dose non-contrast or diagnostic CT extending from the skull base to thighs was performed for anatomic localization and attenuation correction.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par27">PET/CT tumor volume, SUVmaxwb, MTVwb, and TLGwb were measured using the PET Edge tool of MIMvista software as illustrated in Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1</InternalRef>, using semi-automated tumor segmentation, as previously described (Liao et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">2012a</CitationRef>).
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Whole-body PET images of a 59 year-old male with newly diagnosed squamous cell carcinoma, stage IIIB (T4N2M0). This study was performed for initial staging. Colored regions of interest (ROIs) show the tumor contours. The MTVwb in mL is the sum of tumor volumes in all ROIs. Axial image (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis>), sagittal image (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis>), coronal image (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis>) and maximal intensity projection image (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">d</Emphasis>)
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO1">
                          <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/41824_2017_13_Fig1_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par28">Briefly, SUVmax for each tumor lesion was defined as: 
                      <InlineEquation ID="IEq1">
                        <InlineMediaObject>
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="41824_2017_13_Article_IEq1.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="Linedraw"/>
                        </InlineMediaObject>
                        <EquationSource Format="MATHML">
                          <math display="inline" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                            <mfrac>
                              <mrow>
                                <mtext>decayed corrected activity</mtext>
                                <mo stretchy="true">/</mo>
                                <mtext>tissue volume</mtext>
                              </mrow>
                              <mrow>
                                <mtext>injected dose</mtext>
                                <mo stretchy="true">/</mo>
                                <mtext>injected weight</mtext>
                              </mrow>
                            </mfrac>
                          </math>
                        </EquationSource>
                        <EquationSource Format="TEX">$$ \frac{\mathrm{decayed}\  \mathrm{corrected}\  \mathrm{activity}/\mathrm{tissue}\  \mathrm{volume}}{\mathrm{injected}\  \mathrm{dose}/\mathrm{injected}\  \mathrm{weight}} $$</EquationSource>
                      </InlineEquation>. SUVmaxwb was taken to be the largest SUVmax among all tumor lesions identified on baseline staging PET/CT. MTVwb was defined as the total segmented volume of all FDG-avid tumors in the body. TLG for a single tumor lesion is the product of MTV and the average SUV for the lesion. TLGwb was calculated as the sum of the TLGs of all segmented tumor.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec5">
                    <Heading>Statistical analysis</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par29">Statistical analyses were performed using Stata Software version 14. OS was considered the primary endpoint and defined as the time from baseline PET/CT to time of any cause mortality. Analysis was conducted using natural-logarithm transformed values of the PET parameters [(ln(MTVwb), ln(TLGwb), and ln(SUVmaxwb)] in order to achieve a near-normal distribution of independent variables. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed with Cox proportional hazard regression models to test for an association with the primary end point, OS. 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">P</Emphasis>-value of &lt;0.05 from a two-tailed test was considered significant. Survival curves were plotted using the Kaplan-Meier method.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec6">
                  <Heading>Results</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec7">
                    <Heading>Model fitting</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par30">The model was fitted using the training dataset of 110 patients with Stage 3B NSCLC (41% adenocarcinoma; 32% squamous cell; 27% other histologic sub-type) who met the inclusion criteria, with patient characteristics summarized in Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>. The median patient age was 67.3 (range 31.4–83.9) years. There were 47 Caucasian patients, 60 African American patients and 3 Asian patients. The majority of patients (69%) were managed non-surgically (with chemotherapy and/or radiation), while 22% received surgical treatment, and 9% did not treatment. 86/110 patients expired during follow-up. The median OS was 14 months. 1-year, 2-year, and 5-year OS was 56.5%, 34.6% and 13.9%, respectively. The median follow-up among survivors was 26.0 months (inter-quartile range 13.6 to 57.1 months).
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Table 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Characteristics of patients from the University of Chicago</SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>

                                <SimplePara>40%</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara> &lt;65</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>66</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>60%</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>MTVwb (Median and range, ml)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>85.6(3.2–1261.4)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3"/>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>TLGwb (Median and range, ml)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>485.5(12.1–4921.0)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3"/>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>SUVmaxwb (Median and range)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>13.07(3.5–42.9)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3"/>
                            </row>
                          </tbody>
                        </tgroup>
                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">MTVwb</Emphasis> whole-body metabolic tumor volume, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">SUVmaxwb</Emphasis> whole-body maximum standardized uptake value, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">TLGwb</Emphasis> whole-body total lesion glycolysis
                          </SimplePara>
                          <SimplePara>
                            <Superscript>a</Superscript>Other histological subtypes including large cell (
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 7), NSCLC not otherwise specified (
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 21) and neuroendocrine tumor (
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2)
                          </SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par31">Univariate Cox regression analysis showed no significant difference in OS on the basis of age, gender, or histology (Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef>). Surgical treatment (24/110 patients) was associated with improved OS, as compared to the no treatment and non-surgical treatment groups. Some of the PET/CT variables, ln(TLG
                      <Subscript>WB</Subscript>) and ln(SUV
                      <Subscript>WB</Subscript>), were not associated with OS.
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab2">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Table 2</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Univariate Cox regression analyses</SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <tgroup align="left" cols="4">
                          <colspec align="left" colname="c1" colnum="1"/>

                                <SimplePara>0.303</SimplePara>

                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry nameend="c4" namest="c1">

                            </row>

                              </entry>

                                <SimplePara>Reference</SimplePara>

                              <entry colname="c3"/>

                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">

                              </entry>

                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara> No treatment (
                                  <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 10)
                                </SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>0.99</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>0.47 -2.1</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>0.986</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>ln(MTV
                                  <Subscript>wb</Subscript>)
                                </SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>1.23</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>1.01–1.49</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>0.037</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>ln(TLG
                                  <Subscript>wb</Subscript>)
                                </SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>1.13</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>0.95–1.34</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>0.175</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>In(SUVmaxwb)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>0.91</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>0.57–1.43</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>0.67</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                          </tbody>
                        </tgroup>
                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>Note: ln(MTVwb), ln(TLGwb) and ln(SUVmaxwb) are continuous variables. ln = natural logarithmic transformation</SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par32">However, ln(MTVwb) was positively associated with OS, with a hazard ratio (HR) of 1.23 with 95% confidence interval (95% CI) of 1.01–1.49, (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.037). This association persisted on multivariate Cox regression analysis with a HR of 1.28 (95% CI =1.01–1.64, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.043), after adjustment for age, gender, treatment and tumor histology (Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab3">3</InternalRef>).
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab3">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Table 3</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Multivariate Cox regression analyses of whole cohort</SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <tgroup align="left" cols="4">
                          <colspec align="left" colname="c1" colnum="1"/>
                          <colspec align="center" colname="c2" colnum="2"/>
                          <colspec align="char" char="–" colname="c3" colnum="3"/>
                          <colspec align="char" char="." colname="c4" colnum="4"/>
                          <thead>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>Variables</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>Hazard ratio</SimplePara>

                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>95% CI</SimplePara>
                              </entry>

                                <SimplePara>
                                  <Emphasis Type="Italic">P</Emphasis>-value
                                </SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                          </thead>
                          <tbody>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara>ln(MTVwb)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>1.28</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>1.01–1.64</SimplePara>

                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>0.043</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>

                                <SimplePara>Reference</SimplePara>

                            </row>

                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>0.004</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>

                              </entry>

                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>0.59–3.02</SimplePara>

                                <SimplePara>0.48</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                          </tbody>
                        </tgroup>
                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>Additional adjustments were made for age, gender, treatment and tumor histology</SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par33">The training dataset was segmented by the median MTVwb of 85.6 mL, Kaplan-Meier survival curves (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>) demonstrate decreased OS among patients with MTVwb greater than or equal to the median, when compared to those patients with MTVwb less than the median (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.021). The median OS was 9.5 months in patients with MTVwb greater than or equal to the median, while the median OS was 17.3 months in patients with MTVwb less than the median.
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig2">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 2</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Kaplan-Meier overall survival curves of the training dataset of 110 patients with TNM Stage 3B NSCLC, stratified by the median MTVwb of 85.6 mL. The dashed line indicates patient group with MTVwb greater than or equal to 85.6 ml with median OS of 9.5 months. The solid line indicates patient group with MTVwb less than 85.6 ml with median OS of 17.3 months. The difference is statistically significant with 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.02
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO2">
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/41824_2017_13_Fig2_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec8">
                    <Heading>Model validation</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par34">To validate the model, a separate analysis was performed using a dataset of 44 patients who were imaged and managed from medical center B. These 44 patients received radiation-based treatment. The median OS was 20 months and 1-year, 2-year, and 5-year OS was 60%, 45% and 38%, respectively. 24/44 patients (55%) expired during follow-up. The median follow-up among survivors was 30.7 months (inter-quartile range 12.7 o 49.1 months).</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par35">With a univariate Cox regression model, there was significant positive correlation of ln(MTVwb) with OS, HR of 1.83 (95% CI = 1.14–2.94, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.012). For 7 of 44 patients, the SUVmax and TLGwb were not available due to missing accurate weight information during PET/CT acquisition. Univariate Cox regression analysis in the remaining 37 patients demonstrated no statistically significant association of ln(TLGwb) (HR = 1.37, 95% CI = 0.94–2.00, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.1) and ln(SUVmaxwb) (HR = 1.30, 95% CI = 0.53–3.17, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.57) with OS. After adjusting for tumor histology, there remained significant positive correlation with ln(MTVwb) and OS, with HR of 1.78 (95% CI = 1.01–2.90, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.02). The results provided further evidence for the prognostic value of ln(MTVwb). Kaplan-Meier survival curves with groups defined by the median MTVwb from the training set (85.6 mL) further demonstrated significantly lower OS among patients with MTVwb ≥85.6 mL, when compared to those with MTVwb &lt;85.6 mL (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.028; Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3</InternalRef>). The median OS was 13.9 months in patients MTVwb ≥85.6 mL. For patients with MTVwb &lt;85.6 mL, the median OS could not be determined because more than 50% of patients were alive at the last follow-up (median follow-up of 30.7 months).
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig3">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 3</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Kaplan-Meier overall survival curves of the validation dataset of 44 patients with TNM stage 3B NSCLC, stratified by the median MTVwb of the training dataset, 85.6 mL. The dashed line represents the patient group with MTVwb ≥85.6 ml with median OS of 13.9 months. The solid line represents the patient group with MTVwb &lt;85.6 ml with median OS not reached during follow-up period. The groups were significantly different with 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.03
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO3">
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/41824_2017_13_Fig3_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec9">
                  <Heading>Discussion</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par36">Quantitative PET/CT parameters are increasingly used to better stratify patients with cancer. Multiple studies have evaluated the association of primary tumor and whole body MTV, TLG, and SUVmax with respect to OS, though this has yet to be evaluated for Stage 3B NSCLC (8
                    <Superscript>th</Superscript> edition TNM classification) (Liao et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">2012a</CitationRef>; Zhang et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR7">2013a</CitationRef>; Zhang et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">2013b</CitationRef>; Ohri et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">2015</CitationRef>; Liao et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">2012b</CitationRef>; Chung et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">2014</CitationRef>; Im et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">2015</CitationRef>; Hyun et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR14">2013</CitationRef>; Hyun et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">2014</CitationRef>; Carvalho et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">2013</CitationRef>; Kim et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">2012</CitationRef>; Abelson et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">2012</CitationRef>; Satoh et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">2014</CitationRef>; Winther-Larsen et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">2016</CitationRef>; Yoo et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">2012</CitationRef>; Zhu et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR22">2016</CitationRef>; Vu et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">2013</CitationRef>; Lee et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR24">2007</CitationRef>). We sought to better delineate prognosis among patients with Stage 3B NSCLC by utilizing MTVwb, SUVmaxwb, and TLGwb.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par37">Among patients with Stage 3B NSCLC, greater MTVwb was associated with shorter OS, independent of age, sex, and histology. This was further validated by an external dataset of 44 patients treated with radiation-based treatment at outside hospitals. Other studies have shown that OS significantly decreases with every 1 cm increase in primary tumor burden and with increasing number and extent of nodal metastases, which prompted recent changes to the TNM classification (Asamura et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">2015</CitationRef>; Goldstraw et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">2016</CitationRef>). Thus, it is not surprising that quantitative PET/CT measures of whole body tumor burden are similarly associated with OS.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par38">Here we did not find a significant association between SUVmaxwb or TLGwb and OS in patients with Stage 3B NSCLC. SUVmaxwb is a maximum single voxel measurement, so it may not be representative of the entire disease process. Additionally, SUVmaxwb is not representative of the total extent of tumor burden. Though TLGwb incorporates MTVwb, it was not statistically significantly associated with OS in this sample of patients with Stage 3B NSCLC, despite the estimated HR of 1.13. The lack of statistical significance is most likely due to the small sample size in this study, as opposed to a true lack of association with survival.</Para>
                  <Para ID="Par39">Among the Stage 3B NSCLC patients in the training cohort, the 2-year and 5-year OS was 34.6% and 13.9%, lower than the survival observed in the IASLC database (44% and 26%, respectively) (Goldstraw et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">2016</CitationRef>). However, our validation dataset had 2- and 5-year survival of 45%, 38%, which is more similar to the IASLC database. One explanation for the difference in OS may be related to socioeconomic status: Center A serves a predominantly low-income neighborhood, a factor that has been previously associated with worse OS (Aldrich et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR26">2013</CitationRef>). Furthermore, the training dataset included 10 patients who had no treatment, which is likely to lower OS.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par40">The training dataset had a significantly higher proportion of African American patients (55%) than other studies, like the 1996–2007 Florida Cancer Data System registry of 98,541 patients with NSCLC, which was only 7.4% African American (Tannenbaum et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR25">2014</CitationRef>). Although our study included a disproportionate number of African Americans compared to both other registries and the national population, prior work by Aldrich et al., has shown that lung cancer survival is independent of race, when adjusting for stage and socioeconomic status (Aldrich et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR26">2013</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec10">
                    <Heading>Limitations</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par41">Due to the retrospective design of this study, it was not possible to control the type of surgery, chemotherapy or radiation that patients received. Treatment for each patient was determined at the discretion of the surgeon and oncologist and, ultimately, by the patient. In addition, PET/CT has limited sensitivity to detect lesions which are less than 1 cm in diameter or which have low metabolic uptake, likely resulting in a slight under measurement of MTVwb and TLGwb. Since patients in the validation dataset were exclusively treated with radiation-based treatment, and the significant association between OS and MTVwb persists, this strongly suggests the robust prognostic value of MTVwb.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par42">In summary, among patients with Stage 3B NSCLC increasing MTVwb measured on baseline FDG PET/CT is associated with worse OS in both univariate and multivariate cox regression analysis, as seen in both the training and validation datasets. Currently, PET/CT volumetric parameters do not affect clinical management, but hopefully the developing knowledge regarding the values of these measurements may allow more targeted treatment for patients with more or less aggressive disease. Regardless, identifying which patients are more likely to survive to 2 or 5 years may be extremely valuable to patients, who may be planning the final months or years of their life.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec11">
                  <Heading>Conclusion</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par43">MTVwb is a prognostic marker for OS in patients with Stage 3B NSCLC, independent of age, gender, treatment, and tumor histology.</Para>
                </Section1>
              </Body>
              <BodyRef FileRef="BodyRef/PDF/41824_2017_Article_13.pdf" PDFType="Typeset" TargetType="OnlinePDF"/>

                    <BibUnstructured>Abelson JA, Murphy JD, Trakul N et al (2012) Metabolic imaging metrics correlate with survival in early stage lung cancer treated with stereotactic ablative radiotherapy. Lung Cancer 78(3):219–224</BibUnstructured>
                  </Citation>

            <Article ID="s10637-017-0471-y" OutputMedium="All">

                <ArticleID>471</ArticleID>
                <ArticleDOI>10.1007/s10637-017-0471-y</ArticleDOI>
                <ArticleSequenceNumber>18</ArticleSequenceNumber>
                <ArticleTitle Language="En">Successful osimertinib rechallenge in a patient with advanced non-small cell lung cancer following osimertinib-induced interstitial lung disease after treatment with nivolumab</ArticleTitle>
                <ArticleCategory>SHORT REPORT</ArticleCategory>
                <ArticleFirstPage>839</ArticleFirstPage>
                <ArticleLastPage>841</ArticleLastPage>
                <ArticleHistory>
                  <RegistrationDate>
                    <Year>2017</Year>
                    <Month>4</Month>
                    <Day>25</Day>
                  </RegistrationDate>
                  <Received>
                    <Year>2017</Year>
                    <Month>3</Month>
                    <Day>21</Day>
                  </Received>
                  <Accepted>
                    <Year>2017</Year>
                    <Month>4</Month>
                    <Day>25</Day>
                  </Accepted>
                  <OnlineDate>
                    <Year>2017</Year>
                    <Month>5</Month>
                    <Day>2</Day>
                  </OnlineDate>
                </ArticleHistory>
                <ArticleCopyright>
                  <CopyrightHolderName>The Author(s)</CopyrightHolderName>
                  <CopyrightYear>2017</CopyrightYear>
                  <License SubType="CC BY" Type="OpenAccess" Version="4.0">
                    <SimplePara>
                      <Emphasis Type="Bold">Open Access</Emphasis> This article is distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided you give appropriate credit to the original author(s) and the source, provide a link to the Creative Commons license, and indicate if changes were made.
                    </SimplePara>
                  </License>
                </ArticleCopyright>
                <ArticleGrants Type="OpenChoice">
                  <MetadataGrant Grant="OpenAccess"/>

                </ArticleGrants>
              </ArticleInfo>
              <ArticleHeader>
                <AuthorGroup>
                  <Author AffiliationIDS="Aff1" ID="Au1">
                    <AuthorName DisplayOrder="Western">
                      <GivenName>Nobuaki</GivenName>
                      <FamilyName>Mamesaya</FamilyName>
                    </AuthorName>
                  </Author>
                  <Author AffiliationIDS="Aff1" CorrespondingAffiliationID="Aff1" ID="Au2" ORCID="http://orcid.org/0000-0003-0590-9259">
                    <AuthorName DisplayOrder="Western">
                      <GivenName>Hirotsugu</GivenName>
                      <FamilyName>Kenmotsu</FamilyName>
                    </AuthorName>
                    <Contact>
                      <Phone>+81-55-989-5222</Phone>
                      <Email>h.kenmotsu@scchr.jp</Email>
                    </Contact>
                  </Author>
                  <Author AffiliationIDS="Aff1" ID="Au3">
                    <AuthorName DisplayOrder="Western">
                      <GivenName>Toshiaki</GivenName>
                      <FamilyName>Takahashi</FamilyName>
                    </AuthorName>
                  </Author>
                  <Affiliation ID="Aff1">
                    <OrgID Level="Institution" Type="ISNI">0000 0004 1774 9501</OrgID>
                    <OrgID Level="Institution" Type="GRID">grid.415797.9</OrgID>
                    <OrgDivision>Division of Thoracic Oncology</OrgDivision>
                    <OrgName>Shizuoka Cancer Center Hospital</OrgName>
                    <OrgAddress>
                      <Street>1007 Shimonagakubo, Nagaizumi-cho, Sunto-gun</Street>
                      <City>Shizuoka</City>
                      <Postcode>411-8777</Postcode>
                      <Country Code="JP">Japan</Country>
                    </OrgAddress>
                  </Affiliation>
                </AuthorGroup>
                <KeywordGroup Language="En" OutputMedium="All" Source="Author">
                  <Heading>Keywords</Heading>
                  <Keyword>Lung cancer</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>EGFR mutation</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Anti-PD1 antibody</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Interstitial lung disease</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Rechallenge</Keyword>
                </KeywordGroup>
              </ArticleHeader>
              <Body>
                <Para ID="Par1">Dear Editor:</Para>
                <Para ID="Par2">We have already reported a case of a 38-year-old woman with advanced non-small cell lung cancer harboring a sensitive epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) L858R mutation with T790 M who was treated with osimertinib, a third generation EGFR-tyrosine kinase inhibitor (EGFR-TKI), which induced interstitial lung disease (ILD) after treatment with nivolumab [
                  <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. In that report, we mentioned that an anti-programmed cell death-1 (anti-PD1) antibody therapies may be a risk factor for EGFR-TKI-induced ILD. Herein, we describe the clinical course of a patient who was successfully treated with osimertinib rechallenge after osimertinib-induced ILD following treatment with nivolumab.
                </Para>
                <Para ID="Par3">In our patient, osimertinib-induced ILD improved within 2 months after discontinuing osimertinib. She was treated with a combination of docetaxel and ramucirumab (10 mg/kg, up to four cycles), as sixth-line chemotherapy, from August 2016, and then she received gemcitabine monotherapy (up to two cycles). However, no significant response was observed in any conventional chemotherapy, and tumor-related pain became worsen regardless of the administration of oxycodone. Therefore, osimertinib rechallenge was considered based on the expected clinical benefit of its antitumor efficacy over the risk of osimertinib-induced ILD recurrence. Although the risk of drug-induced ILD recurrence may be increased by rechallenge, we considered that the interaction between EGFR-TKI and the anti-PD1 antibody was decreased, because the interval from treatment with nivolumab had been more than 6 month. After obtaining informed consent, a rechallenge of osimertinib (80 mg, once daily) was started as eighth-line treatment for 8 months after the last initiation of nivolumab. One week after the re-administration of osimertinib concurrently without a steroid, her symptom (right chest pain) improved, and right tumor shadows were shrinking, as indicated by the chest radiograph (Fig. 
                  <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1a</InternalRef>, b). Furthermore, 3 months after treatment with osimertinib, the chest computed tomography scan showed a remarkable antitumor response with improvement in right pleural thickening without evidence of the recurrence of osimertinib-induced ILD (e.g., bilateral diffuse, faint, ground-glass opacities or consolidation) (Fig. 
                  <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1c</InternalRef>, d). Now, she continues to receive treatment with osimertinib.
                  <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig1">
                    <Caption Language="En">
                      <CaptionNumber>Fig. 1</CaptionNumber>
                      <CaptionContent>
                        <SimplePara>Chest radiographs before and after treatment. 
                          <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis> Solid tumors with intrapulmonary metastasis have aggressive regrowth. 
                          <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis> Remarkable shrinkage of tumors after osimertinib rechallenge treatment within 1 week. 
                          <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis> Solid tumors with intrapulmonary metastasis and no evidence of preexisting interstitial pneumonia before osimertinib rechallenge treatment. 
                          <Emphasis Type="Bold">d</Emphasis> Remarkable shrinkage of tumors after osimertinib rechallenge treatment without evidence of the recurrence of osimertinib-induced interstitial lung disease
                        </SimplePara>
                      </CaptionContent>
                    </Caption>
                    <MediaObject ID="MO1">
                      <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/10637_2017_471_Fig1_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                    </MediaObject>
                  </Figure>
                </Para>
                <Para ID="Par4">To our knowledge, this is the first case report of a successful osimertinib rechallenge following osimertinib-induced ILD after treatment with nivolumab. The strategy for treating lung cancer harboring a sensitive EGFR mutation is preferentially to administer EGFR-TKI. However, most patients unfortunately acquire resistance to EGFR-TKI. Several conventional chemotherapies or anti-PD1 therapies, in general, are initiated after resistance without a T790 M mutation to the first or second generation EGFR-TKI or the acquisition of osimertinib-resistance. In particular, PD1 antibody therapies are expecting to be one of the potential salvage chemotherapies. Kotake et al. reported a high frequency of osimertinib-induced ILD after immediate prior treatment with nivolumab in a series of 19 patients with EGFR-T790 M mutation-positive advanced non-small cell lung cancer who acquired resistance with the T790 M mutation [
                  <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>]. They also showed that the administration interval between prior nivolumab and osimertinib tended to be shorter in patients with ILD than in those without ILD. However, it is unknown how long of an interval is safe for ILD due to the synergistic reaction between osimertinib and nivolumab. Brahmer et al. reported that the nivolumab serum half-life concentration (t1/2) was approximately 12 days (3 mg/kg dose), according to flow cytometric methods used to evaluate the pharmacodynamics of infused nivolumab [
                  <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">3</CitationRef>]. In addition, they showed that estimating the plateau PD-1 occupancy on circulating CD3
                  <Superscript>+</Superscript> T cells after one infusion was observed at 4 to 24 h and ≥57 days. These data showed the high affinity of nivolumab for PD-1 in vitro, which suggests that sufficient concentrations persist to plateau PD-1 occupancy, even when nivolumab serum levels are undetectable (&lt;1.2 μg/mL). However, it is unknown whether these findings in circulating lymphocytes reflect PD-1 occupancy on lymphocytes in the tumor or other normal tissues relating to antitumor activity or the development of immune-related adverse effects. This case report suggests that even if patients receive nivolumab therapy, a long interval from the last administration of nivolumab may reduce the risk of osimertinib-induced ILD.
                </Para>
              </Body>
              <BodyRef FileRef="BodyRef/PDF/10637_2017_Article_471.pdf" TargetType="OnlinePDF"/>
              <ArticleBackmatter>
                <Acknowledgments>
                  <Heading>Acknowledgements</Heading>
                  <SimplePara>The authors were responsible for all content and editorial decisions and received no honoraria related to the development of this publication. All authors contributed to the writing and reviewing of all drafts of this manuscript and approved the final draft.</SimplePara>
                </Acknowledgments>
