                    </OrgAddress>
                  </Affiliation>
                </AuthorGroup>
                <Abstract ID="Abs1" Language="En" OutputMedium="All">
                  <Heading>Abstract</Heading>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec1">
                    <Heading>Purpose</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par1">The aim of this study is to evaluate the feasibility of a telehealthcare application for operable lung cancer (OLC) patients, consisting of ambulant symptom and physical activity monitoring (S&amp;PAM) and a web-accessible home-based exercise program (WEP), and identify possible barriers for successful adoption and implementation.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec2">
                    <Heading>Methods</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par2">A two-stage mixed methods design was used, in which 22 OLC patients and their treating healthcare professionals (HCPs) participated from pre-surgery to three (stage 1; 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 10) or six (stage 2; 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 12) months post-surgery. Actual use and acceptability (usability, usefulness, and satisfaction) were evaluated.
                    </Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec3">
                    <Heading>Results</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par3">Seventeen OLC patients (age (SD): 59 (8) years; 8 female) actively used the modules. S&amp;PAM use varied from 1 to 11 monitoring days prior to outpatient consultations. Patients used WEP most frequently during the first 5 weeks, with an average of four logins a week. Fifty-eight percent used WEP beyond 7 weeks. No adverse situations occurred, and patients felt confident using the applications.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par4">Perceived added value included active lifestyle promotion, decreased anxiety, and accessibility to specialized HCPs. Physiotherapists used WEP as intended. Contrarily, physicians scarcely used information from S&amp;PAM. To promote future adoption, strategies should focus on high-level patient tailoring of the technology, and formalization of including the applications in the clinical workflow.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec4">
                    <Heading>Conclusions</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par5">Ambulant monitoring and web-accessible home exercise is clinically feasible for OLC patients. However, low level of adoption by referring physicians may hamper successful implementation.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec5">
                    <Heading>Implications for cancer survivors</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par6">Patients perceived both ambulant monitoring and web-accessible exercise as an added value to regular care and feasible to use in the period before and after lung resection.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                </Abstract>
                <KeywordGroup Language="En" OutputMedium="All" Source="Author">
                  <Heading>Keywords</Heading>
                  <Keyword>Lung cancer</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Telehealthcare</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Cancer survivorship</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Rehabilitation</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Feasibility</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Implementation</Keyword>
                </KeywordGroup>
                <ArticleNote Type="ESMHint">
                  <Heading>Electronic supplementary material</Heading>
                  <SimplePara>The online version of this article (doi:
                    <ExternalRef>
                      <RefSource>10.1007/s11764-017-0611-6</RefSource>
                      <RefTarget Address="10.1007/s11764-017-0611-6" TargetType="DOI"/>
                    </ExternalRef>) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.
                  </SimplePara>
                </ArticleNote>
              </ArticleHeader>
              <Body>
                <Section1 ID="Sec1">
                  <Heading>Introduction</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par7">Lung cancer is associated with high symptom burden and high level of unmet needs during and after treatment [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. Although lung resection has the best treatment outcomes in terms of survival in early stage lung cancer, resected patients are faced with an additional worsening of physical fitness, lung function, quality of life, and symptoms such as pain or fatigue following surgery [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR4">4</CitationRef>]. Good quality survivorship care post-surgery is essential to optimize recovery and prevent rehospitalization. Physical training and ambulant symptom monitoring might promote recovery and optimize treatment outcome [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">5</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">8</CitationRef>], yet availability and accessibility of such non-invasive interventions specifically adapted for operable lung cancer (OLC) patients remains extremely low [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">9</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par8">Telehealthcare, defined as delivery of care by a healthcare professional over a distance using information and communication technologies (ICT) [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR10">10</CitationRef>], is hypothesized to be a promising method to improve both the accessibility and quality of post-surgery cancer rehabilitation. Studies in various cancer diagnoses showed beneficial effects of telehealthcare on physical fitness, symptom management, and patient empowerment through frequent health monitoring, home-based exercise programs, and tailored information on disease and treatment [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">11</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR14">14</CitationRef>]. Using the internet, smartphones, and sensors, telehealthcare services are accessible on patients’ demand, wherever and whenever they need, providing timely support and promoting health-related self-management behaviors. Currently, evidence is emerging that telehealthcare applications are also acceptable for OLC patients and clinically safe [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">13</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">8</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par9">However, showing acceptability and clinical safety is not sufficient for successful adoption and widespread use in everyday care [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">17</CitationRef>]. The context of use is considered important as well [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">18</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">17</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">19</CitationRef>], which means that insight in acceptability and use 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">within</Emphasis> this context is of utmost importance to make the potential of telehealthcare come true.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par10">Therefore, the primary aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of a telehealthcare application when used in clinical practice. Research questions to be answered were: (1) how do patients and HCPs use the application during outpatient follow-up in terms of frequency and duration; and (2) is the application acceptable for patients and HCPs as offered. A secondary aim was to identify factors for successful adoption and implementation following the staged approach of Jansen-Kosterink and Vollenbroek-Hutten [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>]. By doing so, essential factors can be detected in an early phase, which enables efficient modification of the application before larger-scale implementation.
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec2">
                  <Heading>Methods</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par11">A repeated-measures, single-arm, mixed-methods feasibility study was performed from January 2014 to January 2016. The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board Netherlands Cancer Institute—Antoni van Leeuwenhoek Hospital (NL44192.031.13/N13POR), and all participants provided informed consent prior to participation in the study. The staged approach was used to guide the evaluation [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>], resulting in a stage 1—optimization of usability for use in clinical practice—and a stage 2—evaluation of clinical feasibility—study.
                  </Para>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec3">
                    <Heading>Sample and setting</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par12">Participants were recruited from the Netherlands Cancer Institute (NKI), Amsterdam, the Netherlands, between January–May 2014 (stage 1) and January–July 2015 (stage 2). Eligible participants were Dutch-speaking adults aged 18 years or older, diagnosed with primary non-small lung cancer (NSCLC) and scheduled for curative lung resection. Participants were identified during the multidisciplinary meeting at the NKI, and patients’ treating oncologist validated eligibility. A study information letter was sent to eligible patients, after which patients were contacted by the first author. When interested, a first appointment was scheduled at the NKI prior to surgery.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par13">Participants were excluded if they had no access to a computer or internet, were unable to walk independently with or without walking aid (e.g., cane), exhibited severe cognitive disorders or emotional instability, or suffered from uncontrolled comorbidities. HCPs (oncologists, surgeons, physiotherapists) involved in the care of the included patient were also recruited.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec4">
                    <Heading>Intervention</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par14">The telehealthcare application, called the 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Remote Monitoring and Treatment (RMT) application</Emphasis>, has been described previously [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">20</CitationRef>]. Briefly, it consists of two modules: (1) a symptom and physical activity monitoring (S&amp;PAM) system, and (2) a web-accessible exercise program (WEP) with remote supervision by a physiotherapist.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par15">
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">The S&amp;PAM module</Emphasis> aims to increase insight in the severity of and change in self-reported symptoms, well-being, and daily physical activity. The system consists of an android smartphone—used as input device for self-rated symptom severity (pain, dyspnea, fatigue; scored by moving slider between 0 (‘no [symptom] at all’) to 10 (‘extremely/a lot of [symptom]’)), mood (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">valence</Emphasis>, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">calmness</Emphasis>, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">energetic arousal</Emphasis>; scored from 0 (e.g., ‘tense’)—6 (e.g., ‘calm’) [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">21</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR22">22</CitationRef>]), weight, and pain medication use—and three on-body sensors, i.e., an accelerometer, heart rate sensor, and an oxygen saturation sensor (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1a</InternalRef>). The symptom scores are combined with physiological parameters from the sensors and summarized into graphs, accessible for both patients and HCPs via a web portal, which is integrated with existing electronic medical records (EMRs) at the hospital.
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>The remote monitoring and treatment (RMT) service for lung cancer patients. 
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis> The symptom and physical activity monitoring (S&amp;PAM) system consisting of a smartphone, heart rate sensor, pulse oximeter, and accelerometer. 
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis> Example exercise of the web-accessible home-based exercise program (WEP) including a movie and written instructions as displayed in the online portal
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO1">
                          <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/11764_2017_611_Fig1_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par16">
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">The WEP module</Emphasis> aims at improving physical fitness of the patient by means of an online, tailored exercise program, which is based on patients’ fitness and goals—assessed during a face-to-face intake—and is performed at home. Each exercise is illustrated by a movie with spoken instructions, and supported by written text (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1b</InternalRef>). Progress is monitored via patient self-report (number of exercises successfully completed, and the experienced difficulty of the exercise) and automatically logged information on use (frequency, duration of login, number of page, and exercise views). If a patient experiences problems with exercise execution (e.g., unclear how to perform an exercise or non-acute bodily pain related to the exercise program), the patient can click a button on the web portal reading “cannot perform exercise, report to therapist”, which results in a standardized email sent to the responsible physiotherapist with instructions to contact the patient. For acute physical problems, the patient is instructed to contact his/her GP.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par17">The modules were accessible for patients via ‘MyAVL’, the interactive patient portal from the NKI [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>] but ran on the Continuous Care and Coaching Platform hosted at the research institute [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">19</CitationRef>].
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec5">
                    <Heading>Study procedures</Heading>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec6">
                      <Heading>Stage 1 study: preparation of the RMT application for clinical use</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par18">To optimize usability of the application for clinical use, the RMT application was offered to a small sample of operable NSCLC patients and their HCPs at the NKI from pre-surgery to 3 months post-surgery.</Para>
                      <Para ID="Par19">Patients, pulmonologists, and physiotherapists participated in telephone or face-to-face semi-structured interview to evaluate satisfaction 3 months post-surgery. All interviews were performed by the first author and lasted between 15 and 30 min. Participants were asked to describe how they used the application, what they thought of the ease of use, and if they had experienced any problems (e.g., technical) using the application. Their comments resulted in a list of critical requirements for adaptation of the RMT application. Results are summarized in this article and adaptations were realized before start of the stage 2 study.</Para>
                    </Section3>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec7">
                      <Heading>Stage 2 study: evaluation of clinical feasibility of the RMT application in clinical care</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par20">Before start of the study, thoracic surgeons and pulmonologists of the NKI were given a 30-min presentation about content and possible benefits of the S&amp;PAM module, where in the EMRs the data could be found and how these should be interpreted. Physiotherapists of the NKI were familiarized with the WEP portal during a 2-h workshop. Additionally, a paper manual was provided. Telephone and email support for the use of the modules was also available for both patients and HCPs.</Para>
                    </Section3>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec8">
                      <Heading>Study protocol</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par21">The study protocol is summarized in Fig. 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>.
                        <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig2">
                          <Caption Language="En">
                            <CaptionNumber>Fig. 2</CaptionNumber>
                            <CaptionContent>
                              <SimplePara>Study protocol stage 1 and stage 2 study. Stage 1 ran from 2 weeks prior surgery (t0) to 3 months post-surgery (t2) only. 
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">S&amp;PAM</Emphasis> symptom and physical activity monitoring module; 
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">WEP</Emphasis> web-accessible home exercise program; 
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">UTAUT</Emphasis> unified theory of acceptance and use of technology
                              </SimplePara>
                            </CaptionContent>
                          </Caption>
                          <MediaObject ID="MO2">
                            <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/11764_2017_611_Fig2_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                          </MediaObject>
                        </Figure>
                      </Para>
                      <FormalPara ID="FPar1" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                        <Heading>Pre-surgery (t0)</Heading>
                        <Para ID="Par22">At baseline, patients received the system for the S&amp;PAM module, oral instructions, and a paper manual. Patients were asked to use the system in the period 
                          <Emphasis Type="Italic">before</Emphasis> surgery for a minimum of 3 days a week, preferably for 2 weeks. The first week following the appointment, the investigator checked if scores were displayed in the EMR, and when necessary, encouraged the patient to complete measurements before surgery.
                        </Para>
                      </FormalPara>
                      <FormalPara ID="FPar2" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                        <Heading>Post-surgery</Heading>
                        <Para ID="Par23">Outpatient appointments with the physician (thoracic surgeon or pulmonologists) and the physiotherapist were scheduled at 1 month post-surgery, as per usual care. After hospital discharge, the patients were contacted by the investigator and reminded to use the S&amp;PAM system for a minimum of 3 days a week, preferably all weeks until the 1-month physician appointment at the hospital (t1).</Para>
                      </FormalPara>
                      <FormalPara ID="FPar3" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                        <Heading>First month post-surgery (t1)</Heading>
                        <Para ID="Par24">Two days before the outpatient visit, physicians received an email with a reminder that additional information from the S&amp;PAM system was available in the EMRs, including instructions where and how to access this information. Patients returned the S&amp;PAM system during their visit to the hospital.</Para>
                        <Para ID="Par25">During the physiotherapist consultation, patients received user instruction for the WEP portal, including a personal login and a paper manual. A brief and individualized assessment of the patient’s fitness level was made, after clarifying individual exercise goals and preferences. A tailored exercise program was then constructed by the physiotherapist and made accessible to the patient within the first week following the appointment. The exercise program was adjusted at least once a month. If needed, the physiotherapist could adjust the program more often. No specific guidelines were given regarding the number or content of contacts between patients and the physiotherapists. Contact between patient and therapist was possible via chat messages on the portal. More complex issues, such as problems with performing exercises or changes in health, could be discussed by telephone or email. The WEP module was offered until 6 months post-surgery.</Para>
                      </FormalPara>
                      <FormalPara ID="FPar4" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                        <Heading>Three and 6 months post-surgery (t2 and t3)</Heading>
                        <Para ID="Par26">Three weeks prior to the 3 and 6 months follow-up, the S&amp;PAM system was again sent to the patients by the investigator, including written instructions for use. Patients were asked to use the system prior to their appointment for 3 days a week during 2 weeks. Two days before the appointment, physicians received a reminder that monitoring data was available for this patient in the EMR. Again, instructions were included where and how to access this information. Patients returned the S&amp;PAM system during their follow-up visits to the hospital.</Para>
                        <Para ID="Par27">Dropout was defined as a patient who did not attend the final measurement at t3. Every patient was contacted to determine their reason(s) for dropping out.</Para>
                      </FormalPara>
                    </Section3>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec9">
                    <Heading>Data collection</Heading>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec10">
                      <Heading>Patient characteristics</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par28">At baseline, demographics such as sex, age, marital status, education level, and employment status were collected via a questionnaire. Experience with internet and computer technology was self-reported in terms of frequency and duration. Clinical information (diagnosis, cancer stage, treatment details, number of comorbidities, lung function) were obtained from the hospital medical records.</Para>
                    </Section3>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec11">
                      <Heading>Actual use</Heading>
                      <FormalPara ID="FPar5" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                        <Heading>Symptom and physical activity monitoring</Heading>
                        <Para ID="Par29">To reflect use of the S&amp;PAM module, the following measures were logged, extracted from the database, and further analyzed:
                          <UnorderedList Mark="None">
                            <ItemContent>
                              <Para ID="Par30">
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">Patients:</Emphasis>
                                <UnorderedList Mark="Bullet">
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par31">The number of days that patients used the monitoring system, calculated as the number of days that data were available from the system (accelerometer or symptom scores) expressed over all periods together as well as per treatment period (pre-surgery, first month following surgery, prior to 3 months consultation, and prior to 6 months consultation).</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par32">Frequency (number) and duration (minutes) of login on the S&amp;PAM portal expressed over all periods together.</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                </UnorderedList>
                              </Para>
                            </ItemContent>
                          </UnorderedList>
                        </Para>
                        <Para ID="Par33">
                          <UnorderedList Mark="None">
                            <ItemContent>
                              <Para ID="Par34">
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">Physicians:</Emphasis>
                                <UnorderedList Mark="Bullet">
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par35">Frequency (number) and duration (minutes) of login expressed over all weeks together.</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                </UnorderedList>
                              </Para>
                            </ItemContent>
                          </UnorderedList>
                        </Para>
                      </FormalPara>
                      <FormalPara ID="FPar6" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                        <Heading>Web-accessible home-based exercise program</Heading>
                        <Para ID="Par36">For the WEP module, the following use measures were evaluated:
                          <UnorderedList Mark="None">
                            <ItemContent>
                              <Para ID="Par37">
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">Patients:</Emphasis>
                                <UnorderedList Mark="Bullet">
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par38">Number of weeks patients used the service, measured as number of weeks from the first to the last week that a patient logged in on the portal</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par39">Frequency (number) of logins per week</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par40">Average duration (minutes) of login per session</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par41">Reason for ending service (provided by patients through self-reported)</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                </UnorderedList>
                              </Para>
                            </ItemContent>
                            <ItemContent>
                              <Para ID="Par42">
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">Physiotherapists:</Emphasis>
                                <UnorderedList Mark="Bullet">
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par43">The frequency (number) and duration (minutes) of login expressed over all weeks together were logged.</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                  <ItemContent>
                                    <Para ID="Par44">Time needed to perform the first consultation (including instruction), setting up and adapting a tailored exercise program, as recorded by the therapist per patient.</Para>
                                  </ItemContent>
                                </UnorderedList>
                              </Para>
                            </ItemContent>
                          </UnorderedList>
                        </Para>
                      </FormalPara>
                    </Section3>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec12">
                  <Heading>Acceptability</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par45">A combination of quantitative and qualitative measures was used to measure acceptability of the S&amp;PAM and WEP modules in both patients and HCPs.</Para>
                  <FormalPara ID="FPar7" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                    <Heading>Patients</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par46">An 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">online questionnaire</Emphasis> based on the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT) [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">23</CitationRef>] was administered at pre- (t0) and post-intervention (t3). The modules (S&amp;PAM and WEP) were evaluated independent from each other in the questionnaire. Scores prior to surgery give an indication about the 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">expectations</Emphasis> patients had about the RMT service, while the scores at study completion represent their 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">experiences</Emphasis> or 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">acceptability</Emphasis> of the RMT service. The questionnaire evaluated the components 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">effort expectancy</Emphasis> or usability, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">performance expectancy</Emphasis> or usefulness, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">social influence</Emphasis>, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">behavioral intention to use</Emphasis>. Facilitation conditions were measured in terms of 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">perceived self-efficacy</Emphasis>. Computer availability and internet access were inclusion criteria for participation and therefore not measured as part of facilitation conditions. 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Attitude</Emphasis> and 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">satisfaction</Emphasis> were added, as they are hypothesized to influence intention to use and actual use [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR24">24</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">18</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR25">25</CitationRef>]. Each item was phrased as a statement, and scored on a 7-point Likert scale (from completely disagree to completely agree). Negative phrased items were transformed so that a higher score indicated higher expectation/experience. For each component, the item scores were summed, and the average score was taken as the final outcome measure.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par47">At the end of the study, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">a patient focus group</Emphasis> was performed by the investigator. Discussion focused on usability and perceived usefulness of the application for resected lung cancer patients, patients’ motivation for use, and if they thought the application should be part of standard care for resected lung cancer patients (intention to use). The first aim was to generate input for improvement of the application itself. The secondary aims were to gather information about the clinical value of the application as well as influencing factors that motivate or hamper patients to use these kinds of applications. The focus group was recorded with permission of the participants and notes were taken.
                    </Para>
                  </FormalPara>
                  <FormalPara ID="FPar8" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                    <Heading>Healthcare professionals (HCPs)</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par48">Acceptability of the S&amp;PAM module was evaluated via an online questionnaire at the end of the study (January 2016). The questionnaire was send to 16 HCPs that are involved in the outpatient care of operable lung cancer patients (two specialized oncology nurses, four thoracic surgeons, ten pulmonologists).</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par49">If an HCP indicated that he/she had not used the results of the S&amp;PAM module, reasons for non-use were registered as well as the expected usefulness of symptom monitoring in clinical care for lung cancer patients.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par50">A focus group with physiotherapists who used the WEP module was performed by the first author at the end of the study to evaluate acceptability of the WEP module in terms of usability, usefulness, satisfaction, and intention to keep using the module.</Para>
                  </FormalPara>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec13">
                    <Heading>Data analysis</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par51">IBM’s Statistical Package for the Social Sciences (SPSS, 23) was used for the statistical analyses. Demographic, patient expectation and experience (UTAUT components) were calculated as frequencies (percentage), medians, and interquartile ranges.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par52">For evaluating the actual use of the web portals of S&amp;PAM and WEP all logins less than 2 min in duration were excluded from analysis. Following, logins that occurred on the same day were considered a single session and duration of these sessions were summed. Means, standard deviations, and ranges were calculated of the use measures. For visualization of actual use, dot plots were generated capturing each individual use values, means, and 95% confidence intervals (95% CI). CI’s were calculated using the 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">t</Emphasis>-distribution due to small sample size.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par53">For qualitative insight into feasibility and acceptability, notes of the focus groups were combined with results of the questionnaire to highlight the most important aspects. Responses on the HCPs questionnaire were summarized using descriptive statistics.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec14">
                  <Heading>Results</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec15">
                    <Heading>Stage 1 study</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par54">The RMT service was offered to 10 patients (60% female; median age (IQR): 56.6 (52.8–62.8) years), of which eight patients used one or both modules of the RMT service. Seven physicians were involved in the care of these patients (three surgeons, four pulmonologists). Detailed description of patient characteristics can be found in Online Resource 
                      <InternalRef RefID="MOESM1">1</InternalRef>. In post-intervention, patients indicated good usability and usefulness, confidence in using the modules (‘self-efficacy’), and a positive attitude and intention to use the modules (i.e., all components a median score of &gt;5 out of 7). Overall, patients felt satisfied with the modules, rating the S&amp;PAM and WEP modules with a 5.3 (4.5–6.5) and a 5.6 (4.5–6.9), respectively (out of 7). Four patients (two female) and four HCPs (two physiotherapists, two pulmonologists) participated in the semi-structured interviews. Two patients declined participation in a personal interview, but gave written comments on the questions from the interview. From the interviews and written comments, eight critical issues were extracted for the S&amp;PAM and five critical issues for the WEP module. Critical issues and the functional requirements for adaptations have been summarized in Online Resource 
                      <InternalRef RefID="MOESM2">2</InternalRef>.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec16">
                    <Heading>Stage 2 study</Heading>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec17">
                      <Heading>Sample</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par55">Eighteen NSCLC patients scheduled for curative lung resection were approached for participation. Twelve patients agreed to participate (33% female; median age (IQR): 59.5 (54.5–66.0) years); a consent rate of 67%. Detailed description of patient characteristics can be found in the Online Resource 
                        <InternalRef RefID="MOESM1">1</InternalRef>. Most important reasons for refusal were surgery before enrollment could take place (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2), too little experience with computers/internet (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2), or emotional burden (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1). Following enrollment, four patients dropped out of the study, three prior to intervention, and one after 2 months of participation. Reasons for dropout were cancelation of the surgery (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2), emotional burden (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1), or complications following surgery (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1). Internet experience was high in this sample, with all patients indicating using the internet almost every day for more than 3 years. Twelve physicians were involved in the care of enrolled patients (four surgeons, eight pulmonologists).
                      </Para>
                    </Section3>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec18">
                      <Heading>Actual use of the modules</Heading>
                    </Section3>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec19">
                  <Heading>Ambulant symptom and physical activity monitoring (S&amp;PAM)</Heading>
                  <FormalPara ID="FPar9" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                    <Heading>Ambulant S&amp;PAM system</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par56">All patients used the S&amp;PAM system at least once, resulting in 179 monitoring days. On average, patients used the system between 5 to 6 days per treatment period (i.e., pre-surgery, 1, 3, and 6 months post-surgery (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3a</InternalRef>).
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig3">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 3</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Use of the RMT application. 
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis> S&amp;PAM: number of days with physical activity data (
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">dots</Emphasis>) and symptom scores (
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">crosses</Emphasis>); 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">PS</Emphasis> post-surgery. WEP: 
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis> frequency of login on the WEP portal per training week; 
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis> average duration of login per session per training week. 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">Training week 1</Emphasis> indicates the first week that a patient logged in on the web portal. A patient data point is represented by a 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">dot/cross</Emphasis>. Data points that overlap each other are visualized with 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">larger dots/cross</Emphasis>; the more overlapping points the 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">larger the dot/cross</Emphasis>. The average (
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">horizontal lines</Emphasis>) and 95% CI (
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">vertical lines</Emphasis>; calculated with 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">t</Emphasis>-distribution) are given
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO3">
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/11764_2017_611_Fig3_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par57">During the study, in three patients, heartrate and oxygen saturation monitoring was removed from the system. One patient experienced problems with attachment of the heartrate sensor because of his thorax wound post-surgery. One patient was anxious about using these sensors and for the other patient there simply was no sensor available. Technical issues were reported by six patients, but all issues could be resolved remotely. Most often reported was a loss of connection between the pulse oximeter and the smartphone during increased physical activity (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 4). Two patients indicated problems rating the symptoms on the smartphone prior to surgery (t0). As can be seen from Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3c</InternalRef>, there are in general fewer days with PA data than there are for subjective symptoms. This was caused by low quality data in terms of missing data points.
                    </Para>
                  </FormalPara>
                  <FormalPara ID="FPar10" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                    <Heading>Web portal</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par58">In total, patients logged in 28 times on the portal to view the results of the symptom monitoring. Nine patients logged in at least once. Mean duration of login was 8 min (min-max: 2–35 min). On average, patients clicked on 11 different pages per session (SD = 12 page clicks). Patients looked most to the pages containing the detailed information about heart rate and oxygen saturation (40% of all page clicks), followed by the summary of symptom scores and daily activity (33% of all page clicks).</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par59">Of the 12 physicians involved, only three physicians logged in on the portal (once each), with an average login time of 12 min.</Para>
                  </FormalPara>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec20">
                  <Heading>Web-accessible home-based exercise program (WEP)</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par60">Eight patients (67%) used the exercise portal at least 1 week following lung resection. Patients started 4 (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 3), 5 (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2), 6 (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2), or 7 (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1) weeks following resection. Use of the portal in terms frequency of use per week and average duration per session are visualized in Fig. 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3b</InternalRef>/c. Patients used the exercise portal most frequently in their first 5 weeks of use. Seven patients (58%) used the portal for 7 weeks or longer. During the program, none of the patients used the shortcut button to indicate difficulty in exercise performance or reported an acute, serious problem as a result of the exercise program. Twenty percent of all sessions lasted 20 min or longer; while the majority of all sessions (66%) lasted less than 10 min.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par61">Half of the patients reported that after some weeks practicing at home, they printed the exercise program and performed the exercises at a local fitness center (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 3) or community center (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1). Reasons for exercising in these centers were availability of better equipment (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1), support from trainer (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1), and ‘used to go to the fitness center prior to surgery’(
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2). Reasons for ending were that patients felt that they had reached their fitness goals and were fit enough to pick up their usual exercise activities (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 5), outpatient follow-up ended (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 1), or that exercises were too easy (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par62">Two physiotherapists participated in the study. They logged in 46 times during the study, with a total duration of 805 min. Time investment per patient was as follows (mean ± SD): intake with the patients 60 ± 7 min (including 30 min consultation part of ‘standard’ care), first set-up of exercise program 35 ± 9 min, and adaptation of the training program 19 ± 7 min.</Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec21">
                  <Heading>Acceptability</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par63">Eight patients completed the online questionnaire at both t0 and t3, and six of these patients participated in the patient focus group. Dot plots of the results from the online patient questionnaire can be found in Online Resource 
                    <InternalRef RefID="MOESM3">3</InternalRef>. Seven HCPs completed the online questionnaire; five pulmonologists and two specialized oncology nurses.
                  </Para>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec22">
                    <Heading>Ambulant symptom and physical activity monitoring (S&amp;PAM)</Heading>
                    <FormalPara ID="FPar11" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                      <Heading>Patients</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par64">At t0, patient expectations were generally high (medians &gt;5 out of a score of 7), with the exception of usability (median (IQR): 4.3(4.0–6.0)), and all patients had a positive intention to use the S&amp;PAM module.</Para>
                      <Para ID="Par65">Following the intervention (t3), most patients indicated that the monitoring system had good usability and all felt competent using the module (that is, score &gt;5 on perceived self-efficacy). Patients felt satisfied with the module and had the opinion that the module should be offered by the hospital to all eligible OLC patients as part of standard care (median satisfaction score =6.0 (IQR = 5.6–6.2); median intention to use score =6.0 (IQR = 5.0–6.8), respectively). On average, scores for usefulness indicated that patients experienced benefit using the system during treatment. Nevertheless, three patients scored rather low on usefulness (score between 3 and 4). Qualitative data show that they were disappointed with the lack of feedback from their physician on the results of the S&amp;PAM, which made the module less useful, and, as a consequence, decreased motivation to use the S&amp;PAM system. During the focus group, this decline in motivation was confirmed by all other patients. As a result, patients felt no need to extend measurements beyond the prescribed frequency. Next to that, patients also requested tailoring of the monitoring protocol in terms of monitoring frequency and sensors employed, based on their individual pattern of recovery and needs.</Para>
                      <Para ID="Par66">Patients mentioned several points of improvements regarding usability. Connection problems between pulse oximeter sensor and smartphone during activity (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 4), and difficulty understanding visualization of the results on the portal (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 4) were the aspects mentioned most often.
                      </Para>
                    </FormalPara>
                    <FormalPara ID="FPar12" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                      <Heading>Healthcare professionals</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par67">The majority of the HCPs (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 5) expected added value of a symptom monitoring system in the care for lung cancer patients in that it might improve insight into the capacity, symptoms, and daily activity, and with this information, improve treatment choices. Most HCPs reported that they would use the S&amp;PAM during chemo (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 4). But in their opinion, also surgery (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 3), concurrent (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2), and radiation therapy (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2) might benefit from the use of the S&amp;PAM module.
                      </Para>
                      <Para ID="Par68">Yet, only two pulmonologists who completed the online questionnaire indicated to be aware that their patients had used the S&amp;PAM module. None of these HCPs actually checked the results of the monitoring in the EMRs. Reasons mentioned for not using the information from S&amp;PAM were unawareness that a specific patient participated in the study, lack of time to check the information, and non-compatibility with the content and process of their work.</Para>
                      <Para ID="Par69">From a HCP perspective, most relevant to optimize future use was to emphasize and improve HCPs’ perception of the added value of the symptom monitoring system (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 7).
                      </Para>
                    </FormalPara>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec23">
                  <Heading>Web-accessible home-based exercise program (WEP)</Heading>
                  <FormalPara ID="FPar13" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                    <Heading>Patients</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par70">Prior to intervention (t0), expectation scores were high with all UTAUT components median scores higher than 5, and all patients had the intention to use the WEP module as much as needed.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par71">In the following use, most patients were satisfied with usability of the module, except for two (score &lt;5) since the program was difficult to access on mobile phone, which hampered execution of the program on a different location than home. Nonetheless, all patients felt confident in their ability to use the module (“self-efficacy”).</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par72">Seven patients found the WEP module useful (score &gt;5 out of 7), but one patient scored extremely low (2 out of 7). During the focus group, this patient indicated a lack of interaction with the physiotherapist, insufficient tailoring of the exercises, and lack of insight in progression as most important reasons for dissatisfaction. The majority of patients (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 7) had the opinion that the module should be accessible to all operable lung cancer patients (score ≥5 on intention to use).
                    </Para>
                  </FormalPara>
                  <FormalPara ID="FPar14" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                    <Heading>Physiotherapists</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par73">Overall, physiotherapists indicated satisfaction and voiced a positive intention to keep using the WEP module. Therapists found it easy to provide user instruction to the patient, due to the simplicity of the patient portal. However, some suggestions for improvement were given for the therapist portal, including navigation between the summary of patient reported progress and corresponding exercises (to quickly adapt instructions based on the progress), and rearrangement of visualization of the chats (i.e., all the chats into one ‘chat-roll’ with a clear mark for messages that have been read).</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par74">Regarding usefulness, therapists believed that the module might contribute to improved accessibility of a cancer rehabilitation program and support of patients towards an active lifestyle by decreasing anxiety for physical activity. For improvement, a smartphone-supported application was considered likely to improve accessibility even more. In general, the necessary time investments were regarded acceptable to the therapists. It appeared critical to instruct the patient when and for what to use the chat function of the module as to prevent unmanageable number of messages.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par75">To ensure successful implementation of the module, therapists advised a more blended care approach, that is, a combination of supervised and home-based training as to facilitate adequate evaluation of patients’ fitness and optimize program tailoring. Also, official (organizational) agreements are needed to ensure financing of the treatment and time to use the module next to face-to-face patientcare.</Para>
                  </FormalPara>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec24">
                  <Heading>Discussion</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par76">This study aimed to evaluate the clinical feasibility in terms of actual use and acceptability of a telehealthcare application, the Remote Monitoring and Treatment (RMT) application, for lung cancer patients treated with lung resection when used in daily clinical practice. Our findings suggest that the use of remote monitoring and treatment is feasible to lung cancer patients when offered pre- and post-surgery. Patients actively used the modules prior and following surgery, and perceived both modules as a beneficial contribution to their care. Also, the continuous treatment and involvement of ‘experts’ from the cancer institute, who were expected to be better informed about cancer and the treatment patients had received, was seen as a big advantage of using ICT-supported rehabilitation. These results are in line with previous studies that showed willingness of lung cancer patients to exercise at home following surgery [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>] or daily rate symptoms on a smartphone during radiotherapy [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">11</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par77">During the study, several issues emerged that need consideration for successful patient adoption. One of the important factors observed is usability of the RMT application. Results show that participants felt confident using on-body sensors, a smartphone, and corresponding protocols. This positive attitude might have been facilitated by a perceived usefulness of the system as well as a flexible monitoring protocol (e.g., change to a different monitoring protocol that did not include heart rate and pulse oximeter sensor) and availability of (paper) manual and a ‘helpdesk’. These factors have previously been linked to the acceptance of personal health devices in patients with chronic conditions [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR26">26</CitationRef>]. Unfortunately, the S&amp;PAM module suffered from loss of connection between the pulse oximeter and the smartphone during performing physical activities. Patients felt annoyed by this problem and it resulted in loss of data for the HCPs. Although SpO
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript> is considered clinically relevant both pre- and post-surgery for lung cancer patients [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR27">27</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR28">28</CitationRef>], it should only be included in the monitoring protocol when the sensor’s performance is adequate and reliable in the ambulant setting. Also, previous studies have shown the added value of S&amp;PAM without SpO
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript> measurement [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">11</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">8</CitationRef>]. Therefore, we recommend that only patients at risk for desaturation should be offered the pulse oximeter [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR28">28</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par78">For the WEP, the main usability issue reported was accessibility of the program from a mobile platform such as a smartphone. Providing the program on smartphone or tablet may facilitate patient use, due to accessibility at various locations which is preferred by patients (e.g., fitness center, local therapist, or communal centers), but also accessibility by broader (e.g., elderly) population due to increasing number of people possessing tablets rather than desktops [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR29">29</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par79">Another factor that influences patient use is motivation. For both modules, patients explicitly reported a perceived decline in motivation towards the end of the study, caused by a lack of sufficient feedback by physicians and the system, and insufficient tailoring of the modules to the needs and capacity of the patients. In agreement, Hoaas et al. recently reported that providing patients with (objective) signs of improvements as well as treatment tailoring in terms of individual goal setting were seen as most important for COPD patients maintaining motivation to participate in a long-term telerehabilitation program [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">18</CitationRef>]. Lack of motivation is not unique to the use of telehealthcare applications, but has been the object of evaluation in other, not ICT-related, interventions that focus on behavior change, such as promoting physical exercise [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR30">30</CitationRef>]. Tailoring, or personalization, of treatment, and feedback is considered beneficial for treatment compliance and long-term behavior change [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR31">31</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR32">32</CitationRef>]. Evidence is growing that shows the potential and unique capability of technology to provide high level of personalization through monitor on an individual level and translate this complex gathering of information into tailored feedback and treatment [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR33">33</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR35">35</CitationRef>]. Adding a gaming layer (‘serious gaming’), a virtual coach, or social component such as online group-based exercise to the program, may further enhance motivation [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR35">35</CitationRef>]. Given the fast technological developments, we should strive for an individual, holistic approach that takes into account the complex interaction between the patient—including his/her health, norms, beliefs, and goals—the context and changes herein. For our RMT application, this means that we should utilize information about the patient (such as age, sex, cancer stage, experience with technology), his/her treatment (including treatment phase, care processes) to tailor the intervention protocol, and adapt the protocol frequently based on newly acquired information. Next to tailoring, other motivational strategies have been reported by our patients and HCPs that might improve the use and adherence of the RMT service. The most promising improvements were providing feedback about health and recovery via a smartphone app instead of a web-based portal since it is readily available and more user-friendly; and a more blended treatment approach, that is combining face-to-face consultation with home-based treatment as to optimize continuous tuning of the treatment to the patient.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par80">In contrast with the overall positive findings regarding feasibility and acceptability from patients, the findings from HCPs were mixed. From the HCPs’ perspective, both modules were regarded beneficial and a valuable addition to care for operable lung cancer patients. However, evaluation of HCP satisfaction with the S&amp;PAM module was unsuccessful, since physicians that completed the questionnaire all indicated non-use of the module. Since HCPs play a key role in making innovations available to patients and the influence they may have on the adoption and adherence of patients [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">20</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">17</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR36">36</CitationRef>], active involvement of HCPs is regarded crucial for successful implementation of telehealthcare and should be given more attention. In line with a recent publication of Vollenbroek et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">17</CitationRef>], our results also show that a process of co-creation of the telehealthcare applications and protocols that are considered useful for their patients, it was clearly not enough for physicians to actually start using these modules as part of their daily practice. Interestingly, in our study, large variation was observed in HCPs using the modules. Physiotherapists that participated in the study showed high level of involvement, while physicians hardly used the information from the S&amp;PAM module in their patients’ consultation. Research suggests that ease of use, perceived usefulness, and organizational- and work-related factors play an important role in HCP adoption [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR37">37</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">19</CitationRef>]. In our current study, it is difficult to draw firm conclusions about facilitating and impeding factors due to the small sample size. However, since ease of use and perceived usefulness of symptom monitoring were rated positive in our current and previous study by HCPs [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">20</CitationRef>], the low use in clinical practice suggest a role of these work- and organization-related factors. For example, for the WEP module, the physiotherapists explicitly reserved time in their schedule for usage of the module, and they were solely responsible for the content of the exercise program and also served as the primary contact for patients regarding the WEP module. In contrast, no explicit agreements were made with physicians in terms of their role and responsibilities, and no time was reserved for learning and working with the S&amp;PAM. Another issue might be that only few patients used the S&amp;PAM, causing that usage of the monitoring data was not part of their daily routine. Lastly, the intervention protocol lacked clear guidelines how the modules and the results generated, should be integrated with hospital-based care. For example, specific cut-off scores for symptom levels were lacking, as was a clear protocol for handling alarming results of the S&amp;PAM such as high pain scores.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par81">This study provides valuable insight in how adoption and implementation of the RMT application in clinical practice can be promoted. While the technology can be further improved, we believe that integration of the RMT application with existing care processes is of paramount importance. This is in line with the work of Jansen-Kosterink, who states that it is not the technology, but the way the technology is embedded in care processes (‘service configuration’) that defines the service [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR38">38</CitationRef>]. Therefore, implementation strategies should focus on formalization of the tasks and processes needed for usage of telehealthcare in practice, which should include the availability of time, funding and creating leadership [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR37">37</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">19</CitationRef>], and education of all involved personnel about the benefits of the service, as well as defining clinical protocols for the resulting information. Additionally, a stage 3 (large-scale) evaluation study is needed to evaluate effectiveness (clinical outcomes), adoption, adherence, and cost-effectiveness when used in clinical practice [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec25">
                  <Heading>Strengths and limitations</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par82">This study is one of the few that evaluated feasibility of ambulant symptom monitoring and web-accessible home-based exercise in clinical practice for lung cancer patients that underwent lung resection. We used the staged approach, resulting in a two-stage study, that allows for gradual development and fine-tuning between technology and clinical context. Several limitations of our study need consideration. First, our convenience sample might have resulted in inclusion of ‘enthusiasts’, resulting in higher IT literacy and levels of use. Also, patients with complications or who experience high levels of stress as a result of diagnosis are less likely to participate in the study. Exclusion due to lack of experience with or access to IT is a well-known barrier for successful adoption and implementation of telehealthcare in the elderly [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR39">39</CitationRef>]. Currently, there are no reliable data available on IT literacy for this specific subgroup of patients, but the low percentage (i.e., 11%) of patients excluded in the current study for this reason probably is a too optimistic figure for the population as a whole. On the other hand, the number of chronically ill and elderly that have access to the internet and own a smartphone or tablet is increasing fast in the Netherlands [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR29">29</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR40">40</CitationRef>]. For example, in 2016, 82% of chronically ill patients were estimated to have internet access [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR40">40</CitationRef>], and 63% of people 65+ years used a smartphone [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR41">41</CitationRef>]. These numbers suggest that a lack of IT literacy as a barrier for participation will decrease in the upcoming years for elderly and chronically ill patients.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par83">Second, the first author performed several research activities, including recruitment, S&amp;PAM instruction, and leading the patient focus group. Therefore, patients might have been less willing to report negative comments during the focus group. However, the questionnaires were completed anonymously and resulted in better rating of the modules than the results during the focus group, suggesting that this effect can largely be ignored. Lastly, in the present study, we did not report effect of the intervention on treatment outcome and patients’ health or costs of the intervention. Although patients experienced the intervention as a beneficial addition to their treatment, additional research is needed to confirm clinical effect and cost-effectiveness objectively and in a larger sample.</Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec26">
                  <Heading>Conclusion</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par84">Our study demonstrates that remote monitoring and treatment is feasible to lung cancer patients when offered pre- and post-surgery. Patients actively used the ambulant symptom monitoring and web-based exercise modules prior and following surgery, and perceived both the modules as a beneficial contribution to their care. However, we also showed that a low level of adoption by referring physicians may hamper successful implementation.</Para>
                  <Para ID="Par85">A stage 3 (large-scale) evaluation study is needed, with focus on both involvement of HCPs through organizational formalization and adequate education, as well as promotion of patient motivation through individual tailoring of treatment content and feedback. Following the staged approach, outcome should evaluate clinical effect (in relation to the goal of each module), costs (in time and money), and factors that determine use and effect in both HCPs and patients.</Para>
                </Section1>
              </Body>
              <BodyRef FileRef="BodyRef/PDF/11764_2017_Article_611.pdf" TargetType="OnlinePDF"/>
              <ArticleBackmatter>

                <ArticleTitle Language="En" OutputMedium="All">3.0T MRI for long-term observation of lung nodules post cryoablation: a pilot study</ArticleTitle>
