                </AuthorGroup>
                <Abstract ID="Abs1" Language="En" OutputMedium="All">
                  <Heading>Abstract</Heading>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec1">
                    <Heading>Background</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par1">The purpose of this study was to use serial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examinations to observe changes in malignant lung tumors over time post-cryoablation.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec2">
                    <Heading>Methods</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par2">The study protocol was approved by Institutional Review Board, and written informed consent was obtained from each participant in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Patients with primary or metastatic lung tumors eligible for cryoablation were included in this prospective study. Cryoablation was performed according to standard procedures. Unenhanced and dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI scans were performed pre-cryoablation and at 1 day, 1 week, and 3-, 6-, and 12 months after cryoablation. At each time point, the signal intensity of the ablated zone on both T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images, and volume and characteristics of the ablation zone were examined, and changes over time analyzed.
                    </Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec3">
                    <Heading>Results</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par3">A total of 26 nodules in 23 patients were included in the study. The mean patient age was 53.7 ± 13.6 years, and 57.7% were males. Ablation zone volume increased to 1 week after the procedure, and then returned to baseline by 3 months. Cavitation post-cryoablation was found in 34.6% (9/26) of the nodules 1 month after treatment. Two types of time-signal intensity curves post-cryoablation were found: a straight line representing no definite enhancement from 1-day to 1-month, and an inflow curve representing mild delayed enhancement from month 3 to month 12. Local progression was associated with an incomplete hypointense rim around the ablation zone and absence of cavitation post-treatment.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec4">
                    <Heading>Conclusions</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par4">Characteristic changes are present on MRI after cryoablation of lung tumors. A complete hypointense rim and cavitation may be signs of adequate treatment and that local tumor progression is less likely.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                </Abstract>
                <KeywordGroup Language="En" OutputMedium="All" Source="Author">
                  <Heading>Keywords</Heading>
                  <Keyword>Lung cancer</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Magnetic resonance imaging</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Percutaneous cryotherapy</Keyword>
                </KeywordGroup>
                <ArticleNote Type="ESMHint">
                  <Heading>Electronic supplementary material</Heading>
                  <SimplePara>The online version of this article (doi:
                    <ExternalRef>
                      <RefSource>10.1186/s40644-017-0131-7</RefSource>
                      <RefTarget Address="10.1186/s40644-017-0131-7" TargetType="DOI"/>
                    </ExternalRef>) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.
                  </SimplePara>
                </ArticleNote>
              </ArticleHeader>
              <Body>
                <Section1 ID="Sec1">
                  <Heading>Background</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par5">Lung cancer is the most common cancer worldwide, and is the leading cause of cancer-related death in both men and women [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. Surgical resection is the standard treatment for early-stage patients. However, patients with advanced stage disease and those with significant comorbidities may not be eligible for surgery. Metastases is the second most common pulmonary malignancy, and resectability depends on many factors [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>]. Nonsurgical candidates are usually managed with systemic chemotherapy; however, side effects can be severe and not all tumors respond to chemotherapy [
                    <CitationRef AdditionalCitationIDS="CR4" CitationID="CR3">3</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">5</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par6">Cryoablation of a tumor can reduce its size, or completely eliminate it, and can thus alleviate symptoms and improve survival [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">6</CitationRef>]. Cryosurgery is commonly used for the treatment of prostate and liver tumors [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR7">7</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">8</CitationRef>]. Although percutaneous cryoablation of tumors in the thorax was first reported in 2005 [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">9</CitationRef>], and it has been shown to be safe and effective for lung tumors [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">3</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">5</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR10">10</CitationRef>], it is still not widely used for lung malignancies [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">11</CitationRef>]. No tissue is removed during cryoablation; thus, imaging is necessary to determine if the extent of ablation is adequate, and to determine how the lesion has responded to the treatment. Imaging studies are mainly utilized for intra-operative guidance, and there is only 1 report on application of computed tomography (CT) for determination of the ablated zone and the examination of serial post-ablative changes [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>]. While the study showed that CT was useful for examining changes following cryoablation, the large radiation dose from multiple CT scans cannot be ignored.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par7">Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has advanced such that artifacts due to breathing and heart function can be reduced or eliminated, and MRI is frequently used for the diagnosis of thoracic disease [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">13</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR14">14</CitationRef>]. MRI has been shown to clearly reflect changes in the ablation zone after radiofrequency ablation of liver lesions [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>]. Unlike CT, MRI is not associated with ionizing radiation. However, there is currently only 1 report of MR-guided cryoablation for lung cancer [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>], and data of long-term changes of the ablation zone using MRI are not available.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par8">We hypothesized that MRI can identify changes in the ablation zone after radiofrequency ablation of lung tumors, and thus may be useful for monitoring treatment effectiveness. Thus, the purpose of this study was to use serial MRI examinations to observe changes in malignant lung tumors over time post-cryoablation, and correlate these changes with the effects of treatment.</Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec2">
                  <Heading>Methods</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec3">
                    <Heading>Patients</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par9">The study protocol was approved by Institutional Review Board, and written informed consent was obtained from each participant in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par10">This prospective study included patients with primary or metastatic lung cancer who received cryoablation from December 2013 to December 2015. Malignancy was diagnosed by a tissue specimen obtained via percutaneous or transbronchial lung biopsy, or clinical changes in the nodule such as rapid enlargement or glucose uptake on positron emission tomography (PET/CT). Other inclusion criteria were 1) newly diagnosed and had received no prior treatment; 2) were judged able to tolerate general anesthesia and the cryoablation procedure; 3) had a single nodule in the target lobe; 4) nodule size &lt;4 cm and no invasion into the adjacent structure; and 5) can complete the entire MRI scanning plan. Patients were excluded if 1) they had more than 1 tumor in the target lobe or had received prior therapy; 2) image quality was too poor to meet diagnostic requirements; 3) significant comorbidities or vital organ failure were present; and 4) nodule size &gt;4 cm, or invasion into mediastinal structures, chest wall, segmental bronchi, vessels, or nerves.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par11">During the post ablation follow-up period, progression was diagnosed by biopsy only if the patient was able to tolerate the procedure, or changes in the nodule such as rapid enlargement or increased glucose uptake were identified on positron emission tomography (PET/CT).</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec4">
                    <Heading>Cryoablation protocol</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par12">Cryoablation was performed under general anesthesia and CT guidance. All procedures were performed with a percutaneous cryoablation device utilizing 1.7 mm diameter cryoprobe and an Ar-He cryosurgery unit (CryoHit type; Galil Medical, Yokneam, Israel). The target lung nodule was identified, and a 3-dimensional (3D) treatment plan was designed based on 16 slice helical CT images (Light Speed; GE Medical Systems, Milwaukee, WI). The criteria for effective treatment were an ice hockey puck zone 1 cm or more from the edge of the target nodule, and the frozen range after 1 single procedure covered more than 80% of the lesion. The needle interval was set to 2 cm when using 2 needles so that the ice ball produced by each needle slightly overlapped and formed a seamless large frozen ball. The number of needles used depended on the size of the tumor.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par13">After the skin was prepped and draped, 1% lidocaine was injected subcutaneous from the skin to the pleura. A 21-gauge guide needle was inserted along the planned optimized path using scout CT images. The needle position was confirmed in the targeting area by repeat CT scanning, then the 17-gauge stainless steel cryoablation probes consisting of an external sheath and inner-guide needle was inserted. The guide needle was removed after confirming the position, and the cryoprobe was introduced through the external sheath. The needle always penetrated the tumor, and the tip of the needle was placed at the far end of the lesion. Freeze-thaw cycles were then performed. A single cycle consisted of a 10 min freezing period in which the local temperature decreased to minus 170 °C due to argon gas rapid expansion, and a 2-min re-warming period in which the local temperature increased to plus 20 °C as a result of helium rapid expansion. Generally, a single procedure consisted of 2 freeze-thaw cycles; however, in the case of large tumors multiple cycles were performed.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec5">
                    <Heading>MRI scanning program and parameters</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par14">All patients received chest unenhanced and dynamic enhanced MR scans pre-cryoablation, and at 1 day, 1 week, and 1, 3, 6, and 12 months after the procedure. Scanning was done with a 3.0T MR scanner (SignaHDx; GE Healthcare, Waukesha, WI), using a TORSO coil. Patients were in the supine position, foot ahead. Imaging was performed from the apex to the top of the diaphragm, including the target lung nodule. Six different sequences were used, and the sequences and parameters are summarized in Additional file 
                      <InternalRef RefID="MOESM1">1</InternalRef>: Table S1.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec6">
                    <Heading>Image analysis</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par15">The size of the ablation zone was measured in 3 dimensions on each imaging study. In prior studies, the post-ablation zone was characterized by regional ground-glass opacity on CT images [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">17</CitationRef>]. As MRI characteristics of the ablation zone for pulmonary nodules are not available, we referred to studies of MRI characteristics after cryoablation for liver tumors [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">18</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">19</CitationRef>]. The ablation zone was defined as an area of high signal intensity on both T1WI and T2WI images, and no enhancement, which histologically represents the region of coagulative necrosis. Tumor volume (lesion length × lesion width × lesion height)/2) was recorded for each ablation zone. Each diameter was measured 3 times by an independent radiologist, and the average value was used for further calculations.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par16">All MRI images at each time point were analyzed by 2 radiologists with more than 5 years of MRI diagnostic experience. Analyses were done independently and blindly. If there were inconsistencies at the final review of all of the analysis, a third highly qualified radiologist with more than 10 years of MRI diagnostic experience reviewed the imaging studies and made the final determination.</Para>
                    <Para ID="Par17">Signal intensity of the ablation zone on T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images were observed carefully, and changing characteristics and time-signal intensity changes were recorded. There are no standard criteria or quantitative parameters of T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI sequences for evaluating lung nodule post-cryoablation. However, a 5-point grading scale method has been proven to be effective and reliable for subjectively evaluating image quality, and to compare different technologies in tumor diagnosis [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">20</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">21</CitationRef>]. Thus, we applied a 5-point grading scale ranging from 1 (low) to 5 (high) on both T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images for scoring signal intensity of the ablation zone. The scoring criteria were: On T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI images, lung parenchyma background was scored as 1 point, muscle signals as 3 points, fat tissue signal intensity as 5 points, signal intensity between lung parenchyma and muscle as 2 points, between muscle and fat tissues as 4 points (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1a</InternalRef>). On T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images, lung parenchyma background was scored as 1 point, muscle signals as 3 points, water-like high signal intensity as 5 points, signals between parenchyma and muscles as 2 points, and between muscle and water as 4 points (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1b</InternalRef>). The ablation zone on T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images at 1-day post-cryotherapy often showed heterogeneous signal intensity. When this occurred, the scores were determined by the dominant signals at the largest part of the ablation zone. Accompanying signs were also observed, including inflammation, atelectasis, and pleural effusion. Inflammation was identified as a large flake appearance with blurred margins, slightly high T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI signals with bronchial low signal intensity inside, and marked enhancement and blood vessels penetrating signs. Atelectasis was identified as a reduced wedge shape of a segment or lobe, slightly high signal intensity on T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images without a bronchial low signal intensity inside, and significantly enhanced with a clear and straight border. Pleural effusion was identified by a crescent or ribbon-like intra-thoracic water-like signal intensity.
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Changes in volume (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis>) and T
                              <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis>) and T
                              <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI score (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis>) during the study period (
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 26 nodules). Nodule volume data are presented as a box plot: 1st quartile (top of the box), median (line shown in box), 3rd quartile (bottom of the box), and examined Friedman’s test. T
                              <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                              <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI data are presented as mean ± standard deviation, and tested by linear mixed model. Letters denote significant difference between the given time and baseline
                              <Superscript>a</Superscript>, day 1
                              <Superscript>b</Superscript>, week 1
                              <Superscript>c</Superscript>, or 1 month 
                              <Superscript>d</Superscript> (
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.002). Volume (cm
                              <Superscript>3</Superscript>)
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO1">
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/40644_2017_131_Fig1_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par18">Dynamic enhanced sequences, including mask phase, were transmitted to a Work Station 4.5, and processed by the SER software package. A region of interest (ROI) was placed in the aorta, and in the largest cross-section of the ablation zone on the same slice. Time-signal intensity curves were automatically generated.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec7">
                  <Heading>Statistical analysis</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par19">Mean and standard deviation were computed for age, nodule volume, T
                    <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI, and T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI, and age range was reported as well. Categorical variables were summarized as frequency and percentage. Inter-rater reliability for T
                    <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI analysis was examined by weighted Kappa. Five levels of agreement were defined according to the Kappa statistic: poor (κ &lt; 0.2), fair (0.2 ≤ κ &lt; 0.4), moderate (0.4 ≤ κ &lt;0.6), good (0.6 ≤ κ &lt; 0.8), and very good (0.8 ≤ κ ≤ 1.00). Nodule volume at various time points were presented as a box plot: 1st quartile (top of the box), median (line shown in box), 3rd quartile (bottom of the box). Data on nodule volume were examined by Friedman’s test, while the time trends of T
                    <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI signal intensity were presented as line charts and examined using a linear mixed model. If the time effect was significant, post-hoc tests were implemented using Bonferroni’s correction method. To compare differences in T
                    <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI signal intensity between patients with and without local tumor progression, the Mann-Whitney U test was also performed. A value of 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.05 was considered statistical significant; the significance level was adjusted to 0.002 (0.05/21) if post-hoc tests were required. All statistical analyses were performed with PASW statistical software (version 21.0, IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA).
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec8">
                  <Heading>Results</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec9">
                    <Heading>Patients</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par20">Data of 26 nodules from 23 patients were used for the analysis (Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>). The mean patient age was 53.7 ± 13.6 (range: 25–78) years, and 57.7% were males. Of the 23 patients, 12 were lost to follow-up at 18 months, and another 5 were lost at 24 months.
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Table 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Characteristics of 26 nodules in 23 patients</SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>

                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>

                              </entry>
                            </row>

                              </entry>

                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>20 (76.9)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>Yes</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>6 (23.1)</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                          </tbody>
                        </tgroup>
                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>Age reported as mean ± standard deviation with (range); other data reported as number (percentage)</SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec10">
                    <Heading>Volume change characteristics</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par21">Changes in nodule volume through the study period are illustrated in Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1a</InternalRef>. The volume was increased at post-procedure day 1, then became smaller gradually at 1 week and 1 month, and then reduced in size to the baseline value at 3 months and remained at that size until the 12th month examination.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec11">
                    <Heading>Cavity formation</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par22">Other MRI findings such as cavitation and complications are summarized in Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef>. Cavitation post-cryoablation was found in 34.6% (9/26) of the nodules 1 month after treatment, but no further cavitation was noted as time progressed. Six of the 9 cases of cavitation were resolved at 3 months, and the others were resolved by 6 months. Interestingly, none of the patients with cavitation post-cryoablation developed local tumor progression.
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab2">

                          <CaptionNumber>Table 2</CaptionNumber>

                        </Caption>

                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>
                            <Superscript>a</Superscript>Two classifications of time-intensity curve: 1, no definite enhancement as a straight line; 2, mild delayed enhancement as an inflow curve
                          </SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par23">Consolidation, atelectasis, and pneumothorax were found in 42.3%, 30.8%, and 26.9% of nodules 1 day after the treatment, respectively. No consolidation or atelectasis was observed after 3 months, and pneumothoraces were resolved by 1 month.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec12">
                    <Heading>Changes of signal intensity</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par24">The inter-rater reliability with regard to observation of T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI signal intensity are reported in Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab3">3</InternalRef>. Regardless of time, the inter-rater reliability of T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI were good or very good, except that T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI measured at month 6 only achieved moderate reliability. Changes in T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI are illustrated in Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1b and c</InternalRef>. The T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI score increased from 2.87 at baseline to the peak of 4.58 at week 1, then declined to around 3 after 3 months (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1b</InternalRef>). A similar trend was found for T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI, except the T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI score significantly decreased to 3.2 at 1 month, and then leveled off to around 2.9 at 6 months (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1c</InternalRef>).
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab3">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Table 3</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Inter-rater reliability for T
                              <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                              <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>

                        </tgroup>
                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">CI</Emphasis> confidence interval
                          </SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec13">
                    <Heading>Enhancement characteristics</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par25">Lung nodules exhibited different enhancement characteristics pre-cryoablation. The majority (73.1%, 19/26) exhibited moderate persistent enhancement, and the time-intensity curve was plateau (type II). However, there were 2 types of time-signal intensity curves post-cryoablation: a straight line representing no definite enhancement from 1-day to 1-month, and an inflow curve representing mild delayed enhancement from month 3 to month 12 (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>). Images of a progressive lesion are shown in Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3</InternalRef>.
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig2">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 2</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Post-contrast images of venous phase (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis>), T
                              <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis>), and T
                              <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis>) of a non-progressive lesion. At the early stage (1 day, 1-month and 3-month), there was no definite enhancement in the ablation zone; later, mild enhancement was noted. Similarly, at the early stage the time-signal curve was a straight line type, and later became an inflow type
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO2">
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/40644_2017_131_Fig2_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig3">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 3</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Post-contrast images of venous phase (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis>), T
                              <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis>), and T
                              <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis>) of a progressive lesion. Progression was noted at 3 months postoperatively. Images obtained at 1 week and 1 month postoperatively showed an unclear and incomplete hypointense rim, especially the T
                              <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO3">
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/40644_2017_131_Fig3_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec14">
                    <Heading>Local tumor progression</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par26">At 12 months after treatment, 4 nodules showed local tumor progression. At 18 months after treatment, and additional 2 nodules developed local progression. A difference in T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI signal intensity between patients with and without local tumor progression was found; however, the difference was no longer statistically significant after 1 week. A difference in T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI signal intensity was also noted after treatment, but the difference became none significant at 6 months. At 3 months after treatment the ablation zone in 22.7% (5/22) of nodules remain round or nodule-like in the non-progression group, and at 12 months 77.3% (17/22) of ablation zones had streaks and or a patch shape.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par27">Of 6 patients that developed local tumor progression, 4 were male and adenocarcinoma was the histological type in 4 cases. Complications like consolidation, atelectasis, and pneumothorax occurred within 1 week to 3 months after treatment (Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab4">4</InternalRef>). Two patients received treatment with embedded 
                      <Superscript>125</Superscript>I particles, 2 a second cyroablation, and 2 local radiotherapy. The ablation zone in the 6 patients with progression showed an incomplete ring at 1 week and 3 months on T
                      <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                      <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images, suggesting that this finding early post-cryoablation may be an indicator for progression.
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab4">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Table 4</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Characteristics of 6 patients with local tumor progression</SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>

                              </entry>

                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry nameend="c7" namest="c1">
                                <SimplePara>Volume, cm
                                  <Superscript>3</Superscript>
                                </SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                            </row>
                            <row>
                              <entry colname="c1">
                                <SimplePara> Baseline</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c2">
                                <SimplePara>1.46</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>14.91</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>5.66</SimplePara>

                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c3">
                                <SimplePara>N</SimplePara>
                              </entry>
                              <entry colname="c4">
                                <SimplePara>Y</SimplePara>
                              </entry>

                        </tgroup>
                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">AD</Emphasis> adenocarcinoma, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">N</Emphasis> no, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">N/A</Emphasis> not available, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">SC</Emphasis> squamous cell carcinoma, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">Y</Emphasis> yes
                          </SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec15">
                  <Heading>Discussion</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par28">A number of studies have shown that cryoablation is an effective treatment for primary lung tumors and pulmonary metastasis [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">3</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR4">4</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR22">22</CitationRef>]. However, familiarity with the post-procedural findings, and the ability to discriminate them from local progression, is critically important.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par29">Our study showed there are characteristic changes of lung nodules after cryotherapy. There is an early increase in volume of the ablated zone that peaks at 1 day after the procedure, remains consistent to 1 week, and then gradually declines to the baseline size at 3 months. The volume increase at 1 day is secondary to ice ball formation and acute lung changes in the target region. However, the reason why the signal is heterogeneous at 1 day post-cryoablation is not clear. Heterogeneous signals can reflect post-cryoablation complications; a high signal on T
                    <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images can be due to alveolar hemorrhage, which is suggestive of small vessel rupture, whereas a low signal in the outer periphery may be the result of alveolar wall collapse and small bronchi rupture. In an animal study, Romaneehsen et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">23</CitationRef>] showed that a volume decrease at 1 week after cryoablation was associated with a reduction or disappearance of a low signal region in the outer periphery, which is suggestive that tissue repair begins in the outer region. A signal increase in the core of the ablated zone has been shown by animal experiments to be secondary to coagulation necrosis [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">23</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR24">24</CitationRef>]. This findings has also been found in radiofrequency ablation in the liver [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par30">The persistent initial volume increase is secondary to the mobilization of macrophages and neutrophils into the cryoablation zone as part of the post-cryoablation immunologic cascade, which leads to tumor lysis and ensuing tissue repair [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR24">24</CitationRef>]. Subsequently, as the concentration of cellular debris, macrophages, and neutrophils decreases, there is steady reduction in the volume of the cryoablation zone [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR24">24</CitationRef>], as noted in our study. It is unclear why there is an increase of T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI signal intensity in the ablated zone at 1-month post-cryoablation, as there is no relevant literature on the topic. It may secondary to stromal hyperplasia, which is abundant in newly developing small vessels and new fibrous tissue, thus reflecting tissue repair [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">6</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR24">24</CitationRef>]. The continuous decrease of signal intensity on T
                    <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images in the ablated zone from 3 months onward may represent repair and fibrosis.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par31">In our study, at 1 day, 1- week, and 1 month post-cryoablation, the ablated zone showed no enhancement, which may be due to complex changes related to cell necrosis [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">23</CitationRef>]. From 3 months onward mild enhancement was note in nodules that did not develop local progression. This is consistent with CT findings of lung nodules post-ablation [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">6</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par32">The local progression rate in our study during a 12-month follow-up period was lower than that reported by Liu et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>] and Inoue et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR10">10</CitationRef>] Most nodules (73.7%) in our study had a diameter &lt; 30 mm, and approximately 30% had a diameter of 30–40 mm; thus, they were relatively small. The low progression rate in this study may due to the limited sample size, size of the nodules, or the histological cancer types.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par33">The presence of hypointense rim as a “ring” appears to be critically important, as suggested from study of radiofrequency ablation [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR25">25</CitationRef>]. In this study, the hypointense rim was present at 1-week and 1-month post-cryoablation, and was a complete rim in 84.6% of nodules and incomplete in 15.4%. Although statistical comparative analysis in the progression group could not be performed due to the small sample size, all cases with local progression exhibited an incomplete ring at the ablation zone at 1 week and 3 months on T
                    <Subscript>1</Subscript>WI and T
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>WI images, suggesting that this finding early post-cryoablation may be an indicator for progression.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par34">Studies of radiofrequency ablation indicate the presence of cavitation is a very important predictor of prognosis [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">6</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>]. We found cavitation in approximately 30% of nodules after treatment, which is similar to the 35% reported by Ito et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR26">26</CitationRef>], but lower than the 53% reported by Chaudhry et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>]. The spectrum of pulmonary nodules in our study was similar to that of the study by Ito et al., but different from that of Chaudhry et al. who only included patients with stage I non-small cell lung cancer. None of the patients who developed tumor progression had evidence of cavitation, suggesting that cavitation may predict a good clinical outcome. In our study, the ablated zone in approximately 77% of patients without local progression eventually developed streaks and a patch shape, and the other cases remained round or nodule shaped. Chaudhry et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>] found that shape change in the ablated occurred up to 6 months after treatment, and then remains stable to 12 months after cryoablation.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par35">While the current study focused on MRI changes, other studies examined CT and PET/CT for the evaluation of nodules post ablation. Abtin et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">6</CitationRef>] examined CT, PET, and dual-modality imaging with combined PET and CT (PET/CT) for their value in identifying partial ablation, tumor recurrence, and progression in lung nodules treated with RFA. The authors divided post ablation into 3 periods: early (up to 1 week), intermediate (&gt; 1 week to 2 months), and late (&gt; 2 months). Imaging features that were suggestive of residual or recurrent disease included 1) increasing contrast agent uptake in the ablation zone (&gt;180 s on dynamic images), nodular enhancement &gt;10 mm, central enhancement &gt;15 HU, and enhancement greater than baseline any time after ablation; 2) growth of the ablation zone after 3 months as compared with baseline, peripheral nodular growth, and change from ground-glass opacity to solid opacity; 3) increased metabolic activity beyond 2 months, residual activity centrally or at the ablated tumor, and development of nodular activity.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par36">There are limitations to what we consider a preliminary study. The sample size was small, the nodules were extremely heterogeneous, i.e., they were both primary and metastatic cancer and the histological type varied, and because of patients lost to follow-up only data up to 12 months could be analyzed. We could not correlate MRI findings with histopathological changes as performing repeat biopsies solely for the purposes of research is not ethical. We did not examine DWI sequence data and ADC values, which have been proven a reliable for the diagnosis of pulmonary nodules [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR27">27</CitationRef>], and evaluation of therapeutic response [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">21</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR28">28</CitationRef>]. These examinations were not performed because there were artifacts on DWI images at 1 day and 1 week post-cryoablation, and putting the ROI in the correct place was difficult due to cavity formation. The method of evaluating the effect of cryoablation, tissue changes, and local residual tumor and local tumor progression was subjective, and was based on CT observations of lung tumors and MRI observations of liver tumors, changes to lung tumors that have been cryoablated identified by MRI may not correspond. Positron emission thermography (PET)-CT may have provided greater value and more objective data with respect to examining serial changes in the tumors. However, PET is not generally covered by insurance (only 7 patients in the current study received PET-CT as part of their initial work-up), and our budget did not allow for us to perform the procedure on all patients, and there is the concern of ionizing radiation with repeated CT scanning. We did not compare MRI and CT data, as study has evaluated the value of CT, MRI, and histological examination after cryoablation of renal tumors and concluded that MRI is superior to CT [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR29">29</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec16">
                  <Heading>Conclusions</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par37">The results of this study showed there are characteristic changes that can be identified on MRI after cryoablation of lung tumors. A complete hypointense rim at 1 week and 1 month post-cryoablation, and cavitation in the ablation zone at 1 month post-cryoablation may be signs of adequate treatment and that local tumor progression is less likely. Though we consider this a preliminary study, the results suggest that MRI may be a good method to follow the results of cryoablation of lung tumors.</Para>
                </Section1>
              </Body>
              <BodyRef FileRef="BodyRef/PDF/40644_2017_Article_131.pdf" PDFType="Typeset" TargetType="OnlinePDF"/>

                  <Citation ID="CR5">
                    <CitationNumber>5.</CitationNumber>
                    <BibArticle>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>M</Initials>

                      <BibAuthorName>

                    </OrgAddress>
                  </Affiliation>
                </AuthorGroup>
                <Abstract ID="Abs1" Language="En" OutputMedium="All">
                  <Heading>Abstract</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par1">The lung is an important open organ and the primary site of respiration. Many life-threatening diseases develop in the lung, e.g., pneumonia, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPDs), pulmonary fibrosis, and lung cancer. In the lung, innate immunity serves as the frontline in both anti-irritant response and anti-tumor defense and is also critical for mucosal homeostasis; thus, it plays an important role in containing these pulmonary diseases. Innate lymphoid cells (ILCs), characterized by their strict tissue residence and distinct function in the mucosa, are attracting increased attention in innate immunity. Upon sensing the danger signals from damaged epithelium, ILCs activate, proliferate, and release numerous cytokines with specific local functions; they also participate in mucosal immune-surveillance, immune-regulation, and homeostasis. However, when their functions become uncontrolled, ILCs can enhance pathological states and induce diseases. In this review, we discuss the physiological and pathological functions of ILC subsets 1 to 3 in the lung, and how the pathogenic environment affects the function and plasticity of ILCs.</Para>
                </Abstract>
                <KeywordGroup Language="En" OutputMedium="All" Source="Author">
                  <Heading>Keywords</Heading>
                  <Keyword>lung</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>innate lymphoid cells</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>pulmonary diseases</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>regional immunity</Keyword>
                </KeywordGroup>
                <ArticleNote Type="Misc">
                  <SimplePara>An erratum to this article is available at 
                    <ExternalRef>
                      <RefSource>https://doi.org/10.1007/s13238-017-0399-1</RefSource>
                      <RefTarget Address="https://doi.org/10.1007/s13238-017-0399-1" TargetType="URL"/>
                    </ExternalRef>.
                  </SimplePara>
                </ArticleNote>
              </ArticleHeader>
              <Body>
                <Section1 ID="Sec1">
                  <Heading>Introduction</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par2">Regional immunity greatly differs from the conventional immune organ or system. Because human diseases are tightly connected with regional immunity, researchers have recently begun to focus on the regional immunity of organs such as the lung, intestine, liver, and skin. The lung is an open organ that is involved in gas conduction and exchange. Approximately 8,000 to 9,000 liters of air are breathed into the lung every day. Compared with the gut and the skin, the lung has a wider surface area, up to 90 m
                    <Superscript>2</Superscript>. A single layer of pulmonary epithelial cells covers the alveoli (Kopf et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR76">2015</CitationRef>). Because of these characteristics, the lung is constantly exposed to environmental stressors, such as pathogens, allergens, and airborne toxins, e.g., cigarette smoke. In the battle between the mucosal immune cells and the invaders, the innate immune cells are the first line of defense, fortifying the trenches. The innate immune cells in the lung mainly comprise lung-resident macrophages, lung-resident dendritic cells (DCs) (Holt et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR53">2008</CitationRef>; Kopf et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR76">2015</CitationRef>), and emerging sets of innate lymphoid cells (ILCs) (Spits and Di Santo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR123">2011</CitationRef>; Spits and Cupedo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR122">2012</CitationRef>; Eberl et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR31">2015</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par3">ILCs are important tissue-resident innate immune cells. They are promptly activated by danger signals from injured mucosa and produce an array of effective cytokines to repel pathogens and tumor cells, thereby maintaining mucosal integrity. However, if they are excessively activated, they may cause pathologic tissue damage, e.g., asthma, Crohn’s disease, or psoriasis (Buonocore et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">2010</CitationRef>; Spits and Cupedo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR122">2012</CitationRef>; Spits et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR124">2013</CitationRef>; Karta et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR62">2016</CitationRef>). Research into ILCs in the lung is only now in its infancy but it is known that there are three groups of ILCs in the lung, namely ILC1s, ILC2s, and ILC3s. Recently Lai et al. reviewed the origin, development, heterogeneity, and interaction of ILCs with other cells in the lung (Lai et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR78">2016</CitationRef>), however the roles of ILCs in lung pathologies have not been extensively reviewed, especially with respect to ILC1s and ILC3s. With this in mind, here we describe the general characteristics, functions, and phenotypic plasticity of ILCs, focusing especially on the roles of all three groups of ILCs in diseases of the lung.
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec2">
                  <Heading>CLASSIFICATION AND GENERAL CHARACTERISTICS OF ILCs</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par4">Lymphoid tissue inducer (LTi) cells and NK cells are prototypic ILCs, which require the common γ chain of the interleukin-2 receptor (IL-2Rγ) and transcriptional repressor inhibitor of DNA binding 2 (Id2) for their development (Kelly and Scollay, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR64">1992</CitationRef>; Held et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR51">2011</CitationRef>; Hesslein and Lanier, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR52">2011</CitationRef>). Over the last ten years, numerous cells have been identified whose development is also IL-2Rγ and Id2-dependent; these cells are referred to as “innate lymphoid cells” (ILCs). ILCs have three main characteristics: a lymphoid morphology, the absence of rearranged antigen-specific receptors, and a lack of myeloid dendritic cell phenotypical markers; ILCs also do not express antigen receptors or undergo clonal selection (Spits and Cupedo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR122">2012</CitationRef>; Spits et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR124">2013</CitationRef>). In 2013, Spits et al. classified the ILCs into three groups according to their cytokine secretion ability, mirroring CD4
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> T helper (Th) cells: group 1 ILCs (ILC1s), comprising conventional NK cells and ILCs that produce interferon-γ (IFN-γ); group 2 ILCs (ILC2s), which are ILCs that secrete type 2 cytokines, such as IL-5 and IL-13; and group 3 ILCs (ILC3s), that produce IL-17 and/or IL-22 (Spits and Cupedo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR122">2012</CitationRef>; Spits et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR124">2013</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par5">ILCs mirror Th cells but also differ from them. Although ILCs and Th cells both arise from a common lymphoid progenitor (CLP), the development of ILCs is unique. It is generally believed that ILCs initially develop in fetal liver, whereas after birth they develop in the bone marrow (Vosshenrich et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR138">2005</CitationRef>; Sawa et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR115">2010</CitationRef>; Klose et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR74">2014</CitationRef>), and are then subsequently recruited into other tissues (Eberl et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR31">2015</CitationRef>; Gasteiger et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR39">2015</CitationRef>). Migration into tissues is likely mediated by the co-ordinated action of adhesion molecules and chemokines (Eberl et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR31">2015</CitationRef>). Interestingly, some researchers found that ILC progenitors seed themselves in tissues in the embryonic and adult phases, and in these tissue micro-environments they undergo development and differentiation (Montaldo et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR99">2014</CitationRef>; Bando et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">2015</CitationRef>). It should be noted that, in contrast to Th cells, ILCs remain tissue-resident; they are maintained locally in one organ and do not re-enter the circulation or migrate to other organs (Gasteiger et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR39">2015</CitationRef>; Fan and Rudensky, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR34">2016</CitationRef>). Following acute environmental challenges tissue-resident ILCs expand locally and in this way the pool of cells is renewed, although phenotypic transformation can also occur. Hematogenously derived ILC precursors or mature ILCs can also partially supply the local tissue ILC pool (Gasteiger et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR39">2015</CitationRef>). In addition, ILCs lack recombination-activating gene (RAG), meaning that unlike B and T cells, ILCs can be activated directly (Spits and Cupedo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR122">2012</CitationRef>; Spits et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR124">2013</CitationRef>). When the mucosa is invaded by pathogens, allergens, or tumor cells, damaged epithelial cells secrete cytokines to directly stimulate ILCs. ILCs then become promptly activated, proliferate, and produce copious amounts of cytokines to repel the invaders and maintain mucosal homeostasis; this response, however, may also lead to pathological damage (Spits and Di Santo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR123">2011</CitationRef>; Scanlon and McKenzie, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR116">2012</CitationRef>; Philip and Artis, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR108">2013</CitationRef>; Salimi and Ogg, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR113">2014</CitationRef>). Thus, ILCs become activated by sensing danger signals from the tissue milieu rather than by antigen presentation with antigen-presenting cells (APCs) (Drake and Kita, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR26">2014</CitationRef>; Eberl et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR31">2015</CitationRef>). Compared with the few days or weeks required by Th cells (Hansen et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR50">1999</CitationRef>), ILCs can therefore be activated more quickly (Spits and Cupedo, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR122">2012</CitationRef>; Fan and Rudensky, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR34">2016</CitationRef>) (Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>).
                    <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab1">
                      <Caption Language="En">
                        <CaptionNumber>Table 1</CaptionNumber>
                        <CaptionContent>
                          <SimplePara>Comparison of ILC and Th cell characteristics</SimplePara>
                        </CaptionContent>
                      </Caption>

                      </tgroup>
                      <tfooter>
                        <SimplePara>APC, antigen-presenting cell; CLP, common lymphoid progenitor; ILCs, innate lymphoid cells; SLO, secondary lymph organ; TF, transcription factor</SimplePara>
                      </tfooter>
                    </Table>
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec3">
                  <Heading>ILC plasticity</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par6">The phenotype of ILCs is not stable; these cells are highly plastic and can change phenotypes under the influence of the environment. IL-2 and IL-12 drive human natural cytotoxicity receptor (NCR)-positive ILC3s (NCR
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s) to transform into ILC1s (Cella et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">2010</CitationRef>; Bernink et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">2013</CitationRef>; Bernink et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR10">2015</CitationRef>). In response to the tissue environment 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vivo</Emphasis>, ILC3s down-regulate the expression of RORγt (retinoic acid receptor-related orphan receptor γt) and produce IFN-γ (Vonarbourg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR136">2010a</CitationRef>). IL-1β and IL-12 induce ILC2s to express T-bet and to produce IFN-γ while down-regulating ST2 and GATA3, and losing the ability to produce IL-5 and IL-13 (Bal et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>; Kim et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR69">2016</CitationRef>; Lim et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR82">2016</CitationRef>). IL-23 and IL-1β cause CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC1s to differentiate into IL-22-producing ILC3s (Bernink et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR10">2015</CitationRef>). Enhanced GATA3 expression by ILC1s results in their conversion to ILC2s with the capacity to produce greater amounts of type 2 cytokines (Mjosberg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR97">2012</CitationRef>; KleinJan et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR72">2014</CitationRef>). Such plasticity occurs not only between ILC groups, but also between ILC subgroups. For example, mouse NKp46
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>RORγt
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> LTi-like cells may transform into NKp46
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>RORγt
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> cells either 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vivo</Emphasis> or 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vitro</Emphasis> (Vonarbourg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR136">2010a</CitationRef>; Klose et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR73">2013</CitationRef>; Rankin et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR110">2013</CitationRef>; Rankin et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR111">2016</CitationRef>). Human NKp44
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3s undergo a profound shift toward NKp44
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC3s upon culture in the presence of IL-2, IL-1β, and IL-23, and they display pro-inflammatory properties (Bernink et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">2013</CitationRef>; Glatzer et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR42">2013</CitationRef>). Plasticity is one of the important characteristics of ILCs, and this property is especially important in the lung; the shift of ILC2s to ILC3s and the plasticity within ILC2 subgroups will be discussed below in detail (Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef>) (Fig. 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1</InternalRef>).
                    <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab2">
                      <Caption Language="En">
                        <CaptionNumber>Table 2</CaptionNumber>
                        <CaptionContent>
                          <SimplePara>Characteristics of lung ILCs</SimplePara>
                        </CaptionContent>
                      </Caption>

                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>CD44
                                <Superscript>+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>IL-9R
                                <Superscript>+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>Lin
                                <Superscript>−</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>CD90
                                <Superscript>+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>CD127
                                <Superscript>+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>NKp46
                                <Superscript>−/+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>NKp30
                                <Superscript>−/+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>CD56
                                <Superscript>−/+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>CCR6
                                <Superscript>−/+</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>Active factors</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>IL-12, IL-18</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>IL-25, IL-33, TSLP, PGD
                                <Subscript>2</Subscript>, TGF-β, Spred1, Arginase 1,
                              </SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>TL1A, RAGE, SP-D, IRF4</SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>CysLT1, IL-1β</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>IL-1β, IL-23</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>Inhibitory factors</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>-</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>IFN-γ, IL-27, Lipoxin4</SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>Corticosteroid, TSA, PGI
                                <Subscript>2</Subscript>, HES
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>-</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>Effective cytokines</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>IFN-γ</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-13, IL-9</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>IL-17, IL-22, TNF-α, IL-8, IL-2,</SimplePara>
                              <SimplePara>GM-CSF, lymphotoxin</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                        </tbody>
                      </tgroup>
                      <tfooter>
                        <SimplePara>NCR, natural cytotoxicity receptor; TF, transcription factor; Bcl11b, B cell leukemia/lymphoma 11b; Gfi1, growth factor independence-1; Lin, lineage; G9a, lysine methyltransferase G9a; HES, 
                          <Emphasis Type="Italic">Heligmosomoides polygyrus</Emphasis> excretory/secretory products; TSLP, thymic stromal lymphopoietin; PGD
                          <Subscript>2</Subscript>, prostaglandin D
                          <Subscript>2</Subscript>; TL1A, tumor necrosis factor like cytokine 1A; RAGE, receptor for advanced glycation end-products; SP-D, surfactant protein D; IRF4, interferon regulatory factor 4; TSA, trichostatin A; PGI
                          <Subscript>2</Subscript>, prostaglandin I
                          <Subscript>2</Subscript>; CysLT1, cysteinyl leukotriene receptor 1
                        </SimplePara>
                      </tfooter>
                    </Table>
                    <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig1">
                      <Caption Language="En">
                        <CaptionNumber>Figure 1</CaptionNumber>
                        <CaptionContent>
                          <SimplePara>
                            <Emphasis Type="Bold">ILC plasticity</Emphasis>. ILCs recruit into the lung and become resident in the mucous epithelium. When the tissue is exposed to danger signals elicited by pathogens, allergens or tumor cells, the epithelium or other innate immune cells produce many cytokines. In response to these cytokines, ILCs may alter their phenotype to respond to the environment. IL-2 and IL-12 drive the transformation of ILC3s to ILC1s. ILC1s convert to ILC3s under the influence of IL-1β and IL-23; ILC2s also transform to ILC1s when cultured with IL-12 and IL-1β. Upon increased GATA3 expression, ILC1s gain ILC2s characteristics; when cultured with TGF-β and IL-6, ILC2s become ILC3-like. Whether ILC3s convert into ILC2s is still unclear. In the ILC2 and ILC3 sub-groups, iILC2 cells give rise to cells with nILC2 phenotype when cultured in the presence of IL-2, IL-7, IL-25, and IL-33 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vitro</Emphasis> or 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vivo</Emphasis>. Under the influence of IL-2, IL-1β, and IL-23, NCR
                            <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3s express NCR
                            <Superscript>+</Superscript>. The hypothesis that nILC2s convert to iILC2s and NCR
                            <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s convert to NCR
                            <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3s should be confirmed in the future. See text for details
                          </SimplePara>
                        </CaptionContent>
                      </Caption>
                      <MediaObject ID="MO1">
                        <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/13238_2017_379_Fig1_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                      </MediaObject>
                    </Figure>
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec4">
                  <Heading>Identification and characterization of ILC1s</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par7">Compared with the other ILC groups, ILC1s are the least studied. Their characteristics are not yet well defined, and indeed there is even still debate concerning their classification. As of now, the ILCs nomenclature introduced by Spits et al. (
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR124">2013</CitationRef>) is widely accepted, with NK cells and ILC1s belonging to group 1 ILCs. Group 1 ILCs are defined by their ability to produce IFN-γ and inability to produce IL-4, IL-13, IL-22, and IL-17. They require transcription factor T-bet for their development (Spits et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR124">2013</CitationRef>). NK cells have been reviewed elsewhere, and therefore we will only focus on ILC1s in this review.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par8">The original report concerning mouse ILC1s described them as RORγt
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>NKR
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>LTi, capable of releasing IFN-γ, and as being potent inducers of experimental colitis (Vonarbourg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR137">2010b</CitationRef>). Another group of mouse ILC1s was then described as NKp46
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>NKp1.1
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>Eomes
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>T-bet
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>, with the ability to produce IFN-γ (Klose et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR74">2014</CitationRef>). In humans, ILC1s can be divided into CD127
                    <Superscript>low</Superscript> ILC1s and CD127
                    <Superscript>high</Superscript> ILC1s, based on the expression of CD127. CD127
                    <Superscript>low</Superscript> ILC1s are defined as CD3
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD56
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>NKp44
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD103
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> and CD3
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD56
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>NKp44
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD103
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>; the former have an intraepithelial localization (Fuchs et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR37">2013</CitationRef>). CD127
                    <Superscript>high</Superscript> ILC1s were first identified in human tonsil and intestine, and they are defined as Lineage (Lin)
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CRTH2
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD117
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>NKp44
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript> (Bernink et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">2013</CitationRef>). Although the markers that define ILC1s in mouse and human are somewhat different, the two are generally defined as lineage negative, T-bet positive, and both are capable of producing IFN-γ.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par9">CD127
                    <Superscript>high</Superscript> and CD127
                    <Superscript>low</Superscript> ILC1s have also been identified in the human lung. CD127
                    <Superscript>high</Superscript> ILC1s are identified as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD117
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>NKp44
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>; they express T-bet but do not express C-C motif chemokine receptor 6 (CCR6), CD103, or CD25. CD127
                    <Superscript>low</Superscript> ILC1s are defined as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>NKp46
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>, and express T-bet. Similar to CD127
                    <Superscript>high</Superscript> ILC1s in the tonsil and the intestine, most Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>NKp46
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>NKp44
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>cells express CD103 (Carrega et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">2015</CitationRef>). Another group identified non-toxic ILC1s in the human lung was Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD56
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>IL12Rβ2
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> (De Grove et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">2016</CitationRef>). In mouse lung, ILC1s are defined by the Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD90
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>T-bet
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> phenotype, and they express IL-12Rβ2 and IL-18Rα; furthermore, IL-12 and IL-18 enhance ILC1 expansion 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vivo</Emphasis>, and they produce copious amounts of IFN-γ (Silver et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR118">2016a</CitationRef>) (Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef>).
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec5">
                  <Heading>ILC1s in the lung</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec6">
                    <Heading>ILC1s and infection</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par10">ILC1s produce large amounts of IFN-γ and protect the organism against pathogens as first reported in mouse models of intracellular infection, e.g., infections caused by the parasite 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Toxoplasma gondii</Emphasis> and by 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Clostridium difficile</Emphasis> in the intestine (Klose et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR74">2014</CitationRef>; Abt et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">2015</CitationRef>). Silver et al. (
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR118">2016a</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR119">b</CitationRef>) found that during lung infection in mice caused by either influenza A, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Haemophilus influenzae</Emphasis>, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), or 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Staphylococcus aureus</Emphasis>, GATA3 expression in the resident ILC2s was rapidly down-regulated (within two days after infection), and this was accompanied by decreased expression of ST2, CD25 (IL-2Rα), IL-7Rα, inducible costimulator (ICOS), and the stem cell factor receptor c-kit (CD117). Meanwhile, the T-bet
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC1 number in the lung increased and the expression of IL-12 and IL-18 receptors (IL-12Rβ2 and IL-18Rα) in ILC1s was up-regulated. The down-regulation of GATA3 expression was negatively correlated with IL-18Rα up-regulation. These results indicate that during infection of the lung, ILC2s may lose their properties and phenotypically convert into ILC1s. To confirm these findings, Silver et al. used a reporter mouse that expressed ST2 labeled with green fluorescent protein (GFP), they found that upon stimulation with IL-12, IL-18, and IL-33, the number of IL-18Rα
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC1 cells increased, and 50% of these cells expressed ST2-GFP. Collectively, these data suggest that lung ILC1s are derived from ILC2s that are resident in the lung rather than from ILC1 proliferation.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par11">In the same study, GFP
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC2s (GFP-labeled ILC2s) were transferred to 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Rag2</Emphasis>
                      <Superscript>−/−</Superscript>/
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Il2rg</Emphasis>
                      <Superscript>−/−</Superscript> mice with mature lymphocyte deficiency, and then the mice were infected with influenza A virus. GFP
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC2s infiltrated into the lungs of host mice 7 d after infection. GATA3 expression in these cells was significantly down-regulated and accompanied by a striking up-regulation of both IL-18Rα and IL-12Rβ2 expression. Double IHC (immunohistochemistry) revealed that ILCs were localized to the influenza virus-infected airways. IHC combined with hybridization
