                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">in situ</Emphasis> revealed that 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Il-12</Emphasis> and 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Il-18</Emphasis> mRNAs produced by myeloid-derived cells were present near GFP
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC2s in the inflamed region. GATA3
                      <Superscript>high</Superscript>ILCs were predominantly localized in uninfected tissue regions, whereas GATA3
                      <Superscript>low</Superscript> ILCs were enriched in virus-associated areas (Silver et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR118">2016a</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par12">In summary, these data demonstrate that during infection, ILC2s migrate to the inflamed regions, where the myeloid-derived pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-12 and IL-18 drive ILC2 conversion into ILC1s, enabling their participation in the anti-pathogen response (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>).
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig2">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Figure 2</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">ILC1 functions in the lung</Emphasis>. When pathogens, such as viruses or bacteria, or tumor cells invade the airway epithelium, the myeloid cells receive danger signals from the epithelium and produce IL-12 and IL-18. These pro-inflammatory cytokines down-regulate GATA3 expression of ILC2s and then drive the conversion of ILC2s into ILC1s. IL-12 and IL-18 also enhance the activation and expansion of ILC1s. After activation, ILC1s produce copious amounts of IFN-γ. IFN-γ plays potentially important roles in clearing both pathogens and tumors, and also in the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). See text for details
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO2">
                          <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/13238_2017_379_Fig2_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec7">
                    <Heading>ILC1s and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par13">COPD is widely regarded as a heterogeneous disease associated with increased numbers of alveolar macrophages, T lymphocytes (predominantly Tc1, Th1, and Th17 cells), B lymphocytes, and neutrophils (Barnes, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">2009</CitationRef>; Kearley et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR63">2015</CitationRef>). Recently, two groups almost simultaneously reported a relationship between ILC1s and COPD (Bal et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>; Silver et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR118">2016a</CitationRef>). The percentage of ILC1s is much higher in patients with COPD than in healthy controls, and is accompanied by a lower occurrence of ILC2s, either in the lung or in the circulation (Bal et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>; Silver et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR118">2016a</CitationRef>). According to the classification of the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD), ILC1s occur more frequently in severe COPD (GOLD III–IV) than in milder COPD (GOLD I–II). A strong negative correlation exists between the occurrence of ILC1s in the blood and lung function, with a higher proportion of ILC1s associated with worse lung function. The numbers of circulating ILC1s are higher in patients with two or more exacerbations of COPD per year than in patients with one exacerbation per year (Bal et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>; Silver et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR118">2016a</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par14">The development and exacerbation of COPD are associated with cigarette smoke and viral and bacterial infection. Silver et al. (
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR118">2016a</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR119">b</CitationRef>) reported that the occurrence of GATA3
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC2s declines promptly and that the fraction of T-bet
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>IL-18Rα
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC1s is increased in response to cigarette smoke or viral and bacterial infections in mouse models (Silver et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR119">2016b</CitationRef>). When ILC2s from human fetal lung are cultured with IL-2, IL-1β, and IL-12, CRTH2 and c-kit in ILC2s are down-regulated, and the cells produce IFN-γ but not IL-5. These results indicate that ILC2s have the potential to transform into ILC1s when exposed to a type 1 inflammatory environment, such as cigarette smoke or infection, and participate in the development of COPD (Bal et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>) (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec8">
                    <Heading>ILC1s and tumors</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par15">Recently, Dadi et al. (
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">2016</CitationRef>) discovered that unconventional type 1-like innate lymphoid cells and type 1 innate-like T cells play a role in tumor-elicited immune surveillance in murine cancer models (Dadi et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">2016</CitationRef>). This suggests that ILC1s may possess an anti-tumor function; however, no data on the function of ILC1s in lung tumors are available, and future studies should thus be performed to further elucidate this issue.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec9">
                  <Heading>Identification and characterization of ILC2s</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par16">In 2001, Fort et al. were the first to report that non-T/non-B T 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">cells in Rag2</Emphasis>
                    <Superscript>−/−</Superscript>mice could produce IL-5 and IL-13, leading to a type 2 response (Fort et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR36">2001</CitationRef>). Ten years later, these cells were observed by different researchers and were differently named as nuocytes, natural helper cells, or innate helper type 2 cells (Moro et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR103">2010</CitationRef>; Neill et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR106">2010</CitationRef>; Price et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR109">2010</CitationRef>). These three groups of cells share similar molecular surface markers and function, and finally they were collectively named as group 2 innate lymphoid cells. In addition to Id2 and IL-2Rγ, the development and function of ILC2s depend on GATA3, Notch, and RORα (Halim et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR46">2012b</CitationRef>; Mjosberg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR97">2012</CitationRef>; Gentek et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR40">2013</CitationRef>). Growth factor independence-1 (Gfi1), B cell leukemia/lymphoma 11b (Bcl11b), lysine methyltransferase G9a, and ETS1 are also essential for the development of ILC2s (Spooner et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR125">2013</CitationRef>; Walker et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR139">2015</CitationRef>; Yu et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR150">2015</CitationRef>; Zook et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR152">2016</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par17">ILC2s can be activated by IL-25, IL-33, and thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP), which are produced by epithelial cells and certain immune cells. Other ILC2 activators were later identified, namely, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-family cytokine TL1A, prostaglandin D
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>, cysteinyl leukotriene receptor 1 (CysLT1), arginase 1, receptor for advanced glycation end-products, and surfactant protein D (Barnig et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">2013</CitationRef>; Doherty et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">2013</CitationRef>; Meylan et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR95">2014</CitationRef>; Yu et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR149">2014</CitationRef>; Tait Wojno et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR128">2015</CitationRef>; Taniguchi et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR130">2015</CitationRef>; Monticelli et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR101">2016</CitationRef>; Thawer et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR132">2016</CitationRef>). IL-1β has been considered to be an activator of ILC3s, but a recent study demonstrated that IL-1β may also activate ILC2s (Bal et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>). These cells can also produce amphiregulin to enhance the recovery of the mucosa during viral infection (Monticelli et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>). ILC2 inhibitors were recently identified and include prostaglandin I
                    <Subscript>2</Subscript>, IFN-γ, IL-27, and lipoxin A4. Because these molecules inhibit ILC2 proliferation and cytokine production (McHedlidze et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR90">2016</CitationRef>; Moro et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR104">2016</CitationRef>; Zhou et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR151">2016</CitationRef>), they may be used to control ILC2-related diseases (See below). Activated ILC2s predominantly produce type 2 cytokines such as IL-5, IL-13, and IL-4, and also IL-9 (Moro, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR102">2010</CitationRef>; Mjosberg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR96">2011</CitationRef>; Wilhelm et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR141">2011</CitationRef>; Kim et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR67">2013</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par18">In the mouse lung, ILC2s are defined as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD90
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>ICOS
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD25
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>ST2
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>. They also express CD44 and IL-17BR, and 20% of nuocytes (ILC2s) express c-kit (CD117) (Monticelli et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>; Barlow et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR4">2012</CitationRef>; Bartemes et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR7">2012</CitationRef>). Based on their killer cell lectin-like receptor G1 (KLRG1) expression, mouse lung ILC2s can be divided into two groups: nILC2s, designated as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>ST2
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>KLRG1
                    <Superscript>int</Superscript> cells, and iILC2s, designated as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>ST2
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>KLRG1
                    <Superscript>hi</Superscript> (Huang et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR56">2015</CitationRef>). ILC2s are also found in the fetal and adult lung, and in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BLF) in human. They are defined as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD161
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CRTH2
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> and also express ICOS, CD25 and ST2; they also partially express CD117 (Mjosberg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR96">2011</CitationRef>; Monticelli et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>). ILC2s in mouse and human have similar markers and function, although CRHT2 is specific for human since mouse ILC2s do not express this marker (Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef>).
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec10">
                  <Heading>ILC2s in the lung</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par19">ILC2s were the first ILC group identified in lung (Monticelli et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>). ILC2-related diseases in the lung involve pathogen infections (virus and helminth parasites), asthma, pulmonary fibrosis, and eosinophilic pleural effusion in primary spontaneous pneumothorax.
                  </Para>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec11">
                    <Heading>ILC2s and viral infection</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par20">During viral infection, ILC2s may exert a dual effect in the lung: on the one hand, ILC2s play a protective role in repelling the virus; on the other hand, if ILC2 function is not tightly controlled, these cells may induce airway hyperactivity (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3</InternalRef>).
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig3">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Figure 3</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">ILC2 functions in the lung</Emphasis>. Following interaction with pathogens or allergens, the airway epithelium secretes IL-25, IL-33, TSLP, and TGF-β. Upon a molecular cue from the damaged epithelium, activated macrophages and DCs also release IL-33. All of these cytokines activate ILC2s. After activation, ILC2s proliferate and produce copious amounts of IL-4, IL-5, IL-9, IL-13, and amphiregulin. IL-4 stimulates B cells and also activates DCs and enhances Th2 cell maturation and activation. IL-5 and IL-13 stimulate the proliferation and recruitment of eosinophils, which are involved in parasite clearance and airway hyper-responsiveness (AHR). IL-5 also enhances B1 cell self-renewal and antibody production by B cells. ILC2s produce IL-9, and the autocrine effect of IL-9 stimulates secretion of effector cytokines by ILC2s. IL-13 induces smooth muscle contractility and airway remodeling that leads to AHR. Additionally, IL-9 plays an essential role in mast cell differentiation and also can induce mast cells to secrete IL-6; IL-9 can also promote both the proliferation of eosinophils and induce their migration into the lung. IL-13 can also induce collagen deposition and the development of pulmonary fibrosis. Furthermore, IL-13 enhances eosinophil recruitment and alternative macrophage activation. Finally, ILC2s also play an important role in airway remodeling by secreting amphiregulin. See text for details
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO3">
                          <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/13238_2017_379_Fig3_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec12">
                      <Heading>Maintenance of epithelial integrity</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par21">During the early phase of respiratory infection caused by influenza A virus subtype H
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1,</Subscript> no significant differences were observed between wild-type mice and 
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">Rag</Emphasis>
                        <Superscript>−/−</Superscript> mice that lack adaptive immunity with respect to the decline in lung function and pathology of the lung. Because ILC2s accumulated in the lung, it was inferred that lung ILC2s play a key role in the regulation of lung innate immunity and tissue homeostasis (Monticelli et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>). Depletion of ILCs led to substantial lung epithelial degeneration and necrosis, as a result of significantly impaired epithelial integrity. Adoptive transfer of ILCs to ILC-depleted mice effectively restored epithelial integrity (Monticelli et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>). In the same study it was found that IL-33/IL-33R signaling was essential for the accumulation of ILC2s in H
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript> virus infected lungs whereas IL-13 and IL-22 appeared to be dispensable for tissue homeostasis (Monticelli et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>). Data from genome-wide transcriptional profiling has suggested that ILC2s in the lung express wound healing-associated genes at higher levels. 
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">In vivo</Emphasis>, lung ILC2s have the ability to produce high levels of amphiregulin, a molecule that regulates tissue remodeling and repair during acute epithelial injury and asthma (Dolinay et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR24">2006</CitationRef>; Enomoto et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR32">2009</CitationRef>; Fukumoto et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR38">2010</CitationRef>; Monticelli et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR100">2011</CitationRef>). In summary, lung ILC2s play an important role in maintaining the integrity of the respiratory epithelium and restoring lung function by producing amphiregulin during H
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript> infection.
                      </Para>
                    </Section3>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec13">
                      <Heading>Induction of lung inflammation and airway hyper-reactivity</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par22">Chang et al. (
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">2011</CitationRef>) observed that BALB/c mice infected with H
                        <Subscript>3</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript> virus rapidly develop AHR (airway hyper-responsiveness) that peaked on day 5 of infection. Because the sensitization of Th2 cells and enrollment of adaptive immunity during allergen-induced AHR required 7~14 d to develop (Hansen et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR50">1999</CitationRef>), based on the speed with which H
                        <Subscript>3</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript> induced AHR, it was hypothesized that this response was mediated by innate immune mechanisms. The authors provided evidence that indeed H
                        <Subscript>3</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript>-induced AHR development did involve the innate immune pathway and did not require T, B, or NKT cells (Chang et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">2011</CitationRef>). Depletion of natural helper cells suppressed the AHR response, and furthermore only the transfer of IL-13-producing ILC2s, but no other IL-13-producing cells (such as mast cells or basophils), was sufficient for the development of H
                        <Subscript>3</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript>-induced AHR. Furthermore, H
                        <Subscript>3</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript>-induced AHR was tightly correlated with the presence of ILC2s, IL-33, and IL-13. IL-33 derived from alveolar macrophages likely plays an essential role in the activation of ILC2s (Chang et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">2011</CitationRef>). These data confirm that ILC2s are essential for the development of AHR during H
                        <Subscript>3</Subscript>N
                        <Subscript>1</Subscript> infection.
                      </Para>
                      <Para ID="Par23">During RSV infection, the number of IL-13-producing ILC2s triples compared with basal levels, and the IL-13 levels increase simultaneously. This increase contributes to airway hyper-reactivity and airway mucus accumulation in a TSLP-dependent manner (Stier et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR126">2016</CitationRef>). ILC2s have also been shown to produce IL-13 in order to recruit eosinophils and induce AHR through the IL-33/ST2 pathway during RSV infection (Liu et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR84">2015b</CitationRef>). Similarly, neonatal rhinovirus induces AHR and mucus metaplasia through IL-25 and ILC2s (Hong et al., 
                        <CitationRef CitationID="CR54">2014</CitationRef>).
                      </Para>
                    </Section3>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec14">
                    <Heading>ILC2s and helminth parasites</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par24">Upon infection with helminthic parasites, the host undergoes a strong type 2 response to clear the pathogens (Paul and Zhu, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR107">2010</CitationRef>; Maizels et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR86">2012</CitationRef>). During 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Strongyloides venezuelensis</Emphasis> infection of the lung, IL-33 levels increase, activating ILC2s to release the effector cytokines IL-5 and IL-13 that, in turn, can recruit eosinophils to fight the infection. IL-33
                      <Superscript>−/−</Superscript> mice are unable to recruit eosinophils to the lungs or expel 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">S. venezuelensis</Emphasis> (Yasuda et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR146">2012</CitationRef>). During lung inflammation induced by 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Nippostrongylus brasiliensis</Emphasis>, epithelial cells produce TSLP and IL-33, synergistically stimulating ILC2s to produce IL-5 and IL-13. Furthermore, IL-9, which is produced by ILC2s in an autocrine manner, stimulates IL-5 and IL-13 production by ILC2s. In IL-9 receptor-deficient mice infected with 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">N. brasiliensis</Emphasis>, ILC2s numbers are reduced and IL-5, IL-13, and amphiregulin levels are decreased, whereas the numbers of Th2 cells remain unchanged. As a result, helminth clearance is strongly impaired (Turner et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR133">2013</CitationRef>). The IL-9 signal plays an important role in the activation of ILC2s, especially in the early phase of helminth infection. This process also requires interferon regulatory factor 4 (IRF4) (Turner et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR133">2013</CitationRef>; Mohapatra et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR98">2016</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par25">During 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">N. brasiliensis</Emphasis> infection, the ILC2 subgroup iILC2 can convert into nILC2. 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">N. brasiliensis</Emphasis>-infected 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Il17rb</Emphasis>
                      <Superscript>−/−</Superscript> mice lack iILC2 cells and, interestingly, nILC2 cell numbers are significantly decreased in these mouse models. This suggests that iILC2s contribute to the nILC2 population during 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">N. brasiliensis</Emphasis> infection. Researchers simultaneously transferred CD45.1
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> nILC2s and CD45.2
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> iILC2s into 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Rag2</Emphasis>
                      <Superscript>−/−</Superscript>
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Il2rg</Emphasis>
                      <Superscript>−/−</Superscript> mice infected with 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">N. brasiliensis</Emphasis>, and 14 d later found that all iILC2 cells had developed into nILC2-like cells. iILC2s may thus comprise a transient progenitor population of cells that can transform into nILC2-like cells and be involved in the clearance of 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">N. brasiliensis</Emphasis> (Huang et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR56">2015</CitationRef>) (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par26">Interestingly, another natural mouse parasite, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Heligmosomoides polygyrus</Emphasis>, that causes parasitic infections suppresses inflammatory responses in models of asthma, food allergy, diabetes, and colitis (McSorley and Maizels, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR91">2012</CitationRef>). 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">H. polygyrus</Emphasis> excretory/secretory (HES) products can suppress both Treg (Grainger et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR44">2010</CitationRef>) and dendritic cells (Massacand et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR88">2009</CitationRef>). McSorley et al. found that HES products inhibit the allergic reaction in the ovalbumin (OVA)-induced mouse asthma model by suppressing the release of IL-33 and inhibiting the activation of ILC2s (McSorley et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR92">2014</CitationRef>; McSorley et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR93">2015</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec15">
                    <Heading>ILC2s and asthma</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par27">Asthma is a heterogeneous disease that occurs worldwide and whose pathology involves chronic airway inflammation. The type 2 response is regarded as a central mechanism for allergic asthma (Deckers et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">2013</CitationRef>; Licona-Limon et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR81">2013</CitationRef>). Conventionally, Th2 cells have been regarded as the main source of type 2 cytokines, but this notion has now been challenged by the emergence of ILC2 cells.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par28">In mouse asthma models that use ovalbumin (Kim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR66">2012</CitationRef>), house dust mite (HDM) (Wilhelm et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR141">2011</CitationRef>; Halim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR45">2012a</CitationRef>; Klein Wolterink et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR71">2012</CitationRef>), papain (Halim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR45">2012a</CitationRef>), and fungal allergens, ILC2s uniformly increase in number and are the major source of IL-5 or/and IL-13, especially in the early phases of the disease. In mouse models that lack adaptive immune cells, i.e., T and B cells, allergens can also induce significant AHR, a high level of type 2 cytokines, and increased numbers of ILC2s in the lung (Bartemes et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR7">2012</CitationRef>; Halim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR45">2012a</CitationRef>). In these allergen-induced asthma models, the pulmonary epithelium, macrophages, and DCs release IL-33; in addition, the pulmonary epithelium also produces IL-25, TSLP, and transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β). All of these cytokines can activate ILC2s (Halim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR45">2012a</CitationRef>; Kim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR66">2012</CitationRef>; Iijima et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR59">2014</CitationRef>; Denney et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR22">2015</CitationRef>). 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">In vitro</Emphasis>, IL-25 and IL-33 enhance the proliferation of ILC2s and stimulate them to produce IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, and/or IL-9 (Wilhelm et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR141">2011</CitationRef>; Barlow et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR4">2012</CitationRef>; Bartemes et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR7">2012</CitationRef>; Halim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR45">2012a</CitationRef>; Kim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR66">2012</CitationRef>; Klein Wolterink et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR71">2012</CitationRef>). This is important because, IL-4 stimulates B cells to produce IgE, IL-5 recruits and activates eosinophils and also enhances B cell antibody production and B1 cell self-renewal, and IL-13 enhances smooth muscle contraction, epithelial mucous production, airway remodeling, and eosinophil recruitment. IL-9 plays an essential role in mast cell differentiation and can also induce mast cells to secrete IL-6; IL-9 promotes both the proliferation of eosinophils and their migration into the lung (Renauld, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR112">2001</CitationRef>). Otherwise, the IL-9 production of ILC2s depends on IL-2 secreted by adaptive immune cells. IL-9 also stimulates ILC2s to produce IL-13 and IL-5 (Wilhelm et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR141">2011</CitationRef>). All of these cytokines play an important role in the development of AHR (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par29">During AHR development, ILC2s crosstalk with DCs, CD4
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> Th2 cells, B cells, and Th9 cells, thereby potentiating the pathology. ILC2s produce IL-13, which directly activates DCs to express CCL17, enhancing CD4
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> Th2 cell activation; ILC2s also activate Th2 cells directly by producing IL-4 and OX40L. ILC2s and CD4
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> Th2 cells thereby exert a synergistic effect on the development of AHR (Drake et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR27">2014</CitationRef>; Gold et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR43">2014</CitationRef>; Halim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR47">2014</CitationRef>; Halim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR48">2015</CitationRef>; Liu et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR83">2015a</CitationRef>). Mouse lung ILC2s enhance the proliferation of B1- and B2-type B cells and stimulate their production of IgM, IgG1, IgA, and IgE 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vitro</Emphasis>. Specifically, ILC2-derived IL-5 is critically involved in increased IgM production (Drake et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR28">2016</CitationRef>). Polarized ILC2s and Th9 cells also stimulate each other in mouse models of asthma in the lung (Ying et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR147">2016</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par30">Researchers have recently observed that similar to Th2 cells, ILC2s gain memory-like properties upon allergen challenge. ILC2s stimulated by inhalation of either IL-33 or papain persist for a long time; even after resolution of the inflammatory response; in fact, some ILC2s persist for more than 4 weeks. Furthermore, ‘allergen-experienced’ ILC2s responded better to unrelated allergen than naïve ILC2s, mediating a more severe allergic inflammation (Martinez-Gonzalez et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR87">2016</CitationRef>). Allergen-experienced ILC2s are also more responsive and produce higher amounts of the same cytokines than unexperienced ILC2s. Compared with memory lymphocytes, ILC2s are activated by cytokines, while memory lymphocytes are activated by specific antigens, thus the memory-like ILC2s are antigen non-specific. This means that memory-like ILC2s can be activated by unrelated allergens but produce a stronger response than naïve ILC2s. Memory-like ILC2s can also enhance Th2 cell-mediated adaptive type 2 lung inflammation. These two important characteristics may explain the phenomena that some asthma patients react against multiple allergens, while some do not (Martinez-Gonzalez et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR87">2016</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par31">In comparison with mouse, far fewer studies describing the role of ILC2s in human asthma have been published. The occurrence of ILC2s is more frequent in the blood of subjects with allergic asthma than in healthy individuals and allergic donors. When stimulated with IL-25 or IL-33, peripheral blood mononuclear cells from patients with allergic asthma produced significantly greater amounts of IL-5 and IL-13 than those from patients with allergic rhinitis and those from healthy donors (Bartemes et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">2014</CitationRef>; Jia et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR60">2016</CitationRef>). Recently, ILC2s were found in the bronchoalvoelar lavage (BAL) and sputum of patients with asthma, and the proportion of IL-5
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>IL-13
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC2s in the sputum of patients with severe asthma was higher than that in corresponding samples from patients with mild asthma (Smith et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR120">2016</CitationRef>). ILC2 levels are also increased in the sputum from severe asthmatic children (Nagakumar et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR105">2016</CitationRef>). Other researchers have also compared the relationship between ILC2s and asthma control status, and the results indicate a positive correlation between IL-13-producing ILC2s and asthma control status (Jia et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR60">2016</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par32">Based on the above studies of examining ILC2s in human asthma, the number of ILC2s is increased in asthmatic patients’ blood, these ILC2s are activated, and the number of IL-13-producing ILC2s negatively correlates with asthma control status. These results might suggest that level of ILC2s in the blood maybe partially indicate asthma status. However, ILCs are generally tissue-resident cells and the characteristics of ILCs in tissue are very different from ILCs in the circulation since tissue-resident ILCs are affected by the tissue microenvironment, which can cause changes of biomarker profile as well as function. Therefore, the blood ILC profile and function does not absolutely represent ILC2s resident in the lungs of asthmatics; blood ILC2s therefore only partially indicates the status of the disease. In the future, it will be important to study the function of human tissue-resident ILC2s, for example ILC2s from BAL and sputum, and even from lung tissue itself.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec16">
                    <Heading>ILC2s and pulmonary fibrosis</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par33">Pulmonary fibrosis is a heterogeneous disease that is prevalent worldwide, and that is typically regarded as a chronic progressive disease, with high morbidity and mortality (Hutchinson et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR58">2015</CitationRef>). The key pathogenic mechanism involves extracellular matrix deposition in the lung. The pro-inflammatory cytokines TGF-β, IL-13, IL-1β, and IL-17A all play an important role in the fibrotic process (Kolb et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR75">2001</CitationRef>; Wynn, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR143">2011</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par34">In the mouse model of pulmonary fibrosis that uses injection of 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">S. mansoni</Emphasis> eggs, IL-25 has been shown to be the key cytokine in the development of fibrosis. IL-25 induces a dramatic increase in both IL-13 and TGF-β in the lungs. In humans, increased levels of IL-25 and ILC2s are found in the BAL and lung tissue of patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (Hams et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR49">2014</CitationRef>). Compared with wild-type mice, pulmonary collagen deposition is impaired in ILC2-deficient mice after 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">S. mansoni</Emphasis> egg injection (Hams et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR49">2014</CitationRef>). Furthermore, ILC2s induce pulmonary collagen deposition in an IL-13-dependent manner (Hams et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR49">2014</CitationRef>). Li et al. (
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR79">2014</CitationRef>) have suggested that the IL-33-ST2 axis is essential for the initiation and progression of pulmonary fibrosis. In this model IL-33 activates M2 macrophages to produce IL-13 and TGF-β1, and then further induces the expansion of ILC2s to produce IL-13, ultimately resulting in the development of pulmonary fibrosis (Li et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR79">2014</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par35">Dermal and circulating ILC2 counts correlate closely with the occurrence of pulmonary fibrosis in systemic sclerosis patients. This implies that ILC2s may aggravate the pulmonary fibrosis in these patients (Wohlfahrt et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR142">2016</CitationRef>) (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec17">
                    <Heading>ILC2s and eosinophilic pleural effusion (EPE) in primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP)</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par36">EPE is defined as &gt; 10% eosinophilia in the pleural fluid and is frequently associated with the presence of blood and/or air in the pleural space (Kalomenidis and Light, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR61">2003</CitationRef>). PSP is a common complication, with a high rate of recurrence in EPE (Kalomenidis and Light, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR61">2003</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par37">The levels of IL-4, IL-5, IL-13, and Eotaxin-3, as well as TSLP and IL-33, have been shown to be increased in the pleural fluid of PSP patients. These cytokines are type 2 immune response-related, and it therefore appears that Th2 cells and ILC2s might play an essential role in this pathology; however, CD4
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> and CD8
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> T cells are known not to be involved in the pathogenesis of PSP (Kwon et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR77">2013</CitationRef>). IL-33 directly stimulates ILC2s to produce increased amounts of IL-5, which then recruits eosinophils into the pleural space, resulting in EPE; Th2 cells are not involved in this process. This indicates that the type 2 immune response is associated with the development of EPE in PSP through an ILC2-dependent but Th2-independent manner (Kwon et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR77">2013</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec18">
                  <Heading>Identification and characterization of ILC3s</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par38">ILC3s can be classified into two main groups according to the host developmental stage when they mature: fetal LTi cells and post-natal (adult) ILC3s. Fetal LTi cells, the prototypical ILC3s, were originally reported two decades ago. In mice, LTi cells are identified as CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD3
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD4
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>. Their development is RORγt-dependent, they originate in the fetal liver, and they are found in fetal lymphoid nodes and the intestine (Kelly and Scollay, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR64">1992</CitationRef>; Mebius et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR94">1997</CitationRef>; Yoshida et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR148">1999</CitationRef>; Eberl et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR30">2004</CitationRef>; Finke, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR35">2005</CitationRef>). In humans, fetal LTi cells were first found in 2009 and recognized as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>RORγt
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD4
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>; they play a role similar to that of mouse LTi cells (Cupedo et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">2009</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par39">In mice, adult ILC3s are defined as CD45
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>Thy1
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>RORγt
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>, and they partially express CCR6 and NKp46 (Sanos et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR114">2009</CitationRef>; Takatori et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR129">2009</CitationRef>; Vonarbourg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR137">2010b</CitationRef>; Song et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR121">2015</CitationRef>). RORγt, AHR, GATA3, and T-bet are required for their development (Luci et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR85">2009</CitationRef>; Klose et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR73">2013</CitationRef>; Hughes et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR57">2014</CitationRef>; Serafini et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR117">2014</CitationRef>). In humans, adult ILC3s are defined as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CRTH2
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD117
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>; they also heterogeneously express NKp44, NKp46, CD56, and NKp30 (Crellin et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">2010</CitationRef>; Hoorweg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR55">2012</CitationRef>; Glatzer et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR42">2013</CitationRef>). Upon stimulation with IL-1β and IL-23, ILC3s express IL-17, IL-22, and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) (Takatori et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR129">2009</CitationRef>; Crellin et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">2010</CitationRef>; Hoorweg et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR55">2012</CitationRef>; Song et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR121">2015</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par40">Adult ILC3s are the most heterogeneous ILCs. Depending on the level of the expressed NK receptor, e.g., NKp44, NKp46, or NKp30, ILC3s can be divided into NCR
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3s and NCR
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s. ILC3s can also be divided according to the level of expression of CCR6 into CCR6
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript> ILC3s and CCR6
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC3s. Recently, it was shown that NCR engagement enables ILC3s to play a pro-inflammatory role (Glatzer et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR42">2013</CitationRef>); based on this an increasing numbers of researchers use the NCR status to classify the function of adult ILC3s. Similar markers and functions are found in both mouse and human ILC3s with the exception that mice do not express NKp44 (Killig et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR65">2014</CitationRef>).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par41">In the mouse lung, ILC3s were initially reported by Centre et al. (2015), who found that 30% of ILCs were ILC3s, defined as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD90
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>RORγt
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>; almost 70% of ILC3s also co-express CCR6. IL-1β and IL-23 have been shown to activate these cells. ILC3s were also identified as a major source of IL-22 produced in response to IL-23 stimulation (Van Maele et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR135">2014</CitationRef>). In the human lung, ILC3s are identified as Lin
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>CRTH2
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD117
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>, and are NCR
                    <Superscript>−</Superscript> or NCR
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>. NCR
                    <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s produce IL-22, TNF-α, IL-8, IL-2, and GM-CSF upon stimulation (Carrega et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">2015</CitationRef>; De Grove et al., 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">2016</CitationRef>) (Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef>).
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec19">
                  <Heading>ILC3s in the lung</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec20">
                    <Heading>ILC3s and infection</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par42">ILC3s play an essential role in the maintenance of mucosal barrier function because they produce effector cytokines, especially IL-22 and IL-17. IL-22 and IL-17 activate epidermal cells to produce antimicrobial molecules and protect the host from extracellular bacteria and fungi (Liang et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR80">2006</CitationRef>). IL-22 can also enhance the epithelial production of mucus-associated molecules (McAleer and Kolls, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR89">2014</CitationRef>). A protective role of ILC3s against infections in the digestive system has also been reported. During an intestinal infection with 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Citrobacter rodentium</Emphasis>, the number of IL-22-producing ILC3s increased in the intestinal lamina propria (Cella et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR14">2009</CitationRef>; Sanos et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR114">2009</CitationRef>). Gladiator et al. found that ILC3s can also produce IL-17 that helps eliminate pathogens during fungal infection in mice, especially in the early phase of infection. (Gladiator et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR41">2013</CitationRef>). In 2014, Van Maele et al. reported the function of ILC3s in the lung. During 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Streptococcus pneumoniae</Emphasis> infection, ILC3s rapidly accumulate in the lung tissue to produce IL-22 in a DC- and MyD88-dependent manner (Van Maele et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR135">2014</CitationRef>). Boosting lung ILC3 numbers might therefore represent an interesting strategy for fighting respiratory bacterial infections.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par43">One study suggested that Toll-like receptor 5 (TLR5) signaling could activate ILCs (CD3
                      <Superscript>−</Superscript>CD127
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>) and enhance the production of IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucial for anti-pathogen defenses in the mucous membrane of the intestine and the lung (Van Maele et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR134">2010</CitationRef>). This raises the interesting notion that TLR5 may activate ILC3s to reject the pathogen in the lung. Later, Van Maele et al. found that during 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">S. pneumoniae</Emphasis> infection, the TLR5 agonist flagellin accelerates and over-stimulates lung ILC3s to produce more IL-22 (Van Maele et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR135">2014</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par44">
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Klebsiella pneumoniae</Emphasis> is a gram-negative bacterium that is highly resistant to antibiotics and is a common pathogen in pneumonia (Doorduijn et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR25">2016</CitationRef>). In 2014, Xu et al. found that IL-22-producing NK cells are required for optimal host defense in mouse models of 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">K.</Emphasis>
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">pneumoniae</Emphasis> infection (Xu et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR145">2014</CitationRef>). Recently, another group reported that following infection with 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">K.</Emphasis>
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">pneumoniae</Emphasis> in mice, inflammatory monocytes are immediately recruited to the lungs, where they produce TNF, which then increases the number of IL-17-producing ILC3s. IL-17A-dependent clearance of 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">K.</Emphasis>
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">pneumoniae</Emphasis> is impaired in monocyte- or TNF-depleted mouse models, whereas IL-17-producing ILC3s enhance monocyte-mediated bacterial clearance. These results indicate that ILC3s and monocytes participate in a positive feedback cycle that promotes the clearance of highly antibiotic-resistant bacterial pathogens from the lung (Xiong et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR144">2016</CitationRef>) (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig4">4</InternalRef>).
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig4">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Figure 4</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">ILC3 functions in the lung</Emphasis>. After receiving the danger signals from the airway epithelium upon pathogen and tumor cell invasion, DCs and macrophages release IL-1β and IL-23, which activate ILC3s. Activated ILC3s release IL-17, IL-22, IL-8, IL-2, TNF, and LTα1β2. IL-17 and IL-22 play a dual role: on the one hand, they stimulate the epithelium to produce antimicrobial peptides and proteins, and mucus-associated molecules to clear the pathogen and tumor cells to maintain homeostasis of the mucosa; on the other hand, they may aggravate the development of obesity-related asthma and COPD. IL-22-producing-ILC3s may have anti-asthma effects, whereas IL-17-producing ILC3s may participate in the pathology of asthma, especially in obesity-related asthma. IL-2 and IL-8 recruit neutrophils to the lung. LTα1β2 stimulates mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) to express ICAM-1 and VCAM-1. These molecules participate in the formation of a tertiary lymphoid organ in the tumor. See text for details
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO4">
                          <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/13238_2017_379_Fig4_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par45">iILC2-derived ILC3-like cells also play a role in 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Candida albicans</Emphasis> infections. iILC2s express an intermediate amount of RORγt, i.e., one that is significantly different from nILC2s but lower than that in ILC3 cells. A small proportion of freshly isolated iILC2s produces IL-17 upon stimulation with PMA and ionomycin (Huang et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR56">2015</CitationRef>). When cultured with TGF-β and IL-6, iILC2s become ILC3-like, produce IL-17, and lose the ability to produce IL-13. During 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">C. albicans</Emphasis> infection, iILC2 cells aid in the clearance of this pathogen. In the lungs of mice infected with 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">C. albicans</Emphasis>, transferred iILC2 cells become ILC3-like cells after 5 d; these ILC3-like cells produce IL-17 but not IL-13 (Huang et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR56">2015</CitationRef>). Thus, iILC2 cells can transform into ILC3-like cells 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vitro</Emphasis> and 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">in vivo</Emphasis>, and gain the ability to protect the host against 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">C. albicans</Emphasis> (Huang et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR56">2015</CitationRef>) (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec21">
                    <Heading>ILC3s and asthma</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par46">In addition to ILC2s, ILC3s are also involved in asthma. In an OVA-induced asthma murine model, Taube et al. found that IL-22 expression increased, and the IL-22 was mainly produced by innate lymphoid cells in the lungs, rather than by TH cells. OVA challenged IL-22-deficient mice suffered from much higher AHR. In contrast mice treated with IL-22 before OVA challenge displayed significantly reduced allergic airway inflammation. Based on these data, IL-22-producing ILC3s may participate in reducing allergic asthma pathology (Taube et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR131">2011</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par47">Obesity is a risk factor associated with asthma, and obese asthma patients respond poorly to typical anti-asthma medications, including corticosteroids (Sutherland et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR127">2009</CitationRef>); therefore, a distinct immune mechanism must be at play in obese asthmatics. Mice fed a high-fat diet become obese and exhibit AHR through an IL-17A and NKRP3-dependent pathway, and this AHR also occurs in obese 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Rag1</Emphasis>
                      <Superscript>−/−</Superscript> mice (Kim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR68">2014</CitationRef>). In this model, the number of CCR6
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> IL-17A-producing ILC3s is elevated in the lung and macrophage-derived IL-1 directly causes AHR by stimulating this IL-17-producing ILC3 population (Kim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR68">2014</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par48">Everaere et al. found a similar result where, compared with lean mice, the number of ILCs was increased in the lung of obese mice, and this effect was accompanied by eosinophil infiltration. Following an HDM challenge, the counts of ILC2s and ILC3s in the lung further increased, as did IL-33 and IL-1β levels, whereas ILC markers in visceral adipose tissue decreased. In an obese mouse model with ILC depletion, the HDM-induced inflammatory profile of the airway was profoundly decreased, including reduced Th2 and Th17 infiltration (Everaere et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR33">2016</CitationRef>) (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig4">4</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par49">In humans, IL-17-producing ILCs are found in BAL fluid samples from asthma patients; their levels are increased in severe asthma patients compared with those in patients with mild asthma or control donors (Kim et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR68">2014</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par50">These results indicate that IL-22-producing-ILC3s may have an anti-asthma effect, whereas IL-17-producing ILC3s participate in the pathology of asthma, possibly providing a link between obesity and asthma. Further studies should be performed to help illuminate these potential connections.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec22">
                    <Heading>ILC3s and COPD</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par51">IL-17A plays an essential role in the development of COPD. Since ILC3s have the ability to produce IL-17A it is therefore possible that ILC3s are linked with COPD. De Grove et al. (
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">2016</CitationRef>) found that in patients with COPD, the population of NCR
                      <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3s comprises the largest subset of ILCs (De Grove et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">2016</CitationRef>). Bal et al. (
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>) also found that NKp44
                      <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3 levels were increased, whereas the numbers of ILC2s and NKp44
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript> ILC3s were significantly diminished in lung tissue from patients with severe COPD (Bal et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2016</CitationRef>). This supports our hypothesis that IL-17-producing ILC3s may play a role in COPD; however, the authors suggested that the accumulation of NCR
                      <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3s in COPD could be associated with the protective immunity of the host in response to bacterial respiratory tract infections that occur frequently in patients with COPD. The involvement of ILC3s in COPD therefore requires further study (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig4">4</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec23">
                    <Heading>ILC3s and tumors</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par52">A dual effect of ILC3s on tumor immunity was suggested for intestinal tumors. On the one hand, IL-22 produced by ILC3s maintains mucosal integrity and clearance of pathogens and transformed cells. On the other hand, IL-22 activates the STAT3 cascade to enhance tumor generation (Kirchberger et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR70">2013</CitationRef>). Carrega et al. (
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">2015</CitationRef>) observed that NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s were enriched in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and that the proportion of NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s was positively associated with tumor stage. NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s were present in significantly higher amounts in stage I/II NSCLC tumors than in more tumors from more advanced stages. When stimulated, NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s, which had been freshly isolated from NSCLC tissues, produced IL-22, TNF-α, IL-8, and IL-2, but did not secrete IL-17. IL-22 maintains the integrity of epithelial cells (Dudakov et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR29">2015</CitationRef>); TNF-α is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that exerts anti-tumor and anti-pathogen effects, and IL-8 and IL-2 enhance leukocyte recruitment and proliferation (Waugh and Wilson, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR140">2008</CitationRef>; Boyman and Sprent, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">2012</CitationRef>). Based on the characteristics of the cytokines produced by NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s, it was concluded that these cells might play a role in anti-tumor defenses (Carrega et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">2015</CitationRef>).
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par53">As stated above, LTi is the prototype for ILC3s. LTi cells produce lymphotoxin α, lymphotoxin β, and TNF-α. They also stimulate stromal cells to produce vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 (VCAM-1) and intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1), which recruit the immune cells and form the fetal lymphoid node and Peyer’s patches (Kelly and Scollay, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR64">1992</CitationRef>; Mebius et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR94">1997</CitationRef>; Yoshida et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR148">1999</CitationRef>; Eberl et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR30">2004</CitationRef>; Finke, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR35">2005</CitationRef>; Cupedo et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">2009</CitationRef>). Lung cancer-derived NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s express more lymphotoxin mRNA than their tonsil counterparts. Furthermore, lung cancer-derived NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s elicit significant up-regulation of ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 in mesenchymal stem cells in a lymphotoxin α, lymphotoxin β, and TNF-α dependent manner. Additionally, NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s preferentially reside at the edge of lymphoid structures associated with NSCLC, and the percentage of NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s is correlated with the density of tertiary lymphoid structures in the tumor region. These observations suggest that NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s might play a role in the formation and maintenance of these structures as well as lymphoid aggregates in tumor tissue (Carrega et al., 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">2015</CitationRef>). Otherwise, NCR
                      <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3s can gain pro-inflammatory properties by engaging NKp44, as the number of NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3s is increased in the lung tumor region (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig4">4</InternalRef>). Whether the conversion of NCR
                      <Superscript>−</Superscript>ILC3 to NCR
                      <Superscript>+</Superscript>ILC3 cells contributes to this increased number and how the tumor microenvironment influences this conversion are questions that should be answered in future studies. Additionally, the question of whether IL-22-producing ILC3s enhance or inhibit tumors in the lung remains unresolved and should be studied further.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec24">
                  <Heading>Conclusions</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par54">ILCs are attracting increasing attention on account of their distinct tissue-resident properties. Although it is known that ILCs are involved in pulmonary infection, asthma, COPD, fibrosis, and tumors in the lung, in-depth studies are still only in their infancy. The mechanisms of ILC activation, proliferation, and regulation in the lung are not clear; how exactly the pathological environment affects ILC function and how ILCs respond to the environment also remain unknown. Elucidation of these mechanisms is therefore an urgent matter, especially in pulmonary diseases. Answers to these questions will hopefully provide new clues for the treatment of these serious human diseases.
</Para>
                </Section1>
              </Body>
              <BodyRef FileRef="BodyRef/PDF/13238_2017_Article_379.pdf" TargetType="OnlinePDF"/>
              <ArticleBackmatter>
                <Acknowledgments>
                  <Heading>ACKNOWLEDGMENTS</Heading>

We are grateful to Ying Sun for critical reading of this manuscript. We sincerely apologize to the authors whose work was not cited in this review due to the space limitations.</SimplePara>
                  <FormalPara ID="FPar1" RenderingStyle="Style1">
                    <Heading>ABBREVIATIONS</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par55">AHR, airway hyper-responsiveness; APC, antigen-presenting cell; Bcl11b, B cell leukemia/lymphoma 11b; BLF, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid; CCR6, C-C motif chemokine receptor 6; COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; CysLT1, cysteinyl leukotriene receptor 1; DC, dendritic cell; EPE, eosinophilic pleural effusion; G9a, lysine methyltransferase G9a; GATA3, GATA binding protein 3; GFP, green fluorescent protein; GM-CSF, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor; HDM, house dust mite; HES, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Heligmosomoides polygyrus</Emphasis> excretory/secretory products; ICAM-1, intercellular adhesion molecule 1; IFN-γ, interferon-γ; ILCs, innate lymphoid cells; IL-2Rγ, common γ chain of the interleukin-2 receptor; IRF4, interferon regulatory factor 4; Lin, lineage; LTi, lymphoid tissue inducer; NCR, natural cytotoxicity triggering receptor; NK cell, nature killer cell; NSCLC, non-small cell lung cancer; OVA, ovalbumin; PSP, primary spontaneous pneumothorax; RAG, recombination-activating gene; ROR, retinoic acid receptor-related orphan receptor; TGF-β, transforming growth factor-β; Th cells, T helper cells; TLR5, Toll-like receptor 5; TNF, tumor necrosis factor; TSLP, thymic stromal lymphopoietin; VCAM-1, vascular cell adhesion molecule-1
                    </Para>
                  </FormalPara>

                  <Citation ID="CR6">
                    <BibArticle>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>C</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Barnig</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>M</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Cernadas</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>S</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Dutile</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>X</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Liu</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>MA</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Perrella</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>S</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Kazani</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>ME</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Wechsler</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>E</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Israel</FamilyName>

                    <OrgAddress>
