                    </OrgAddress>
                  </Affiliation>
                  <Affiliation ID="Aff7">
                    <OrgID Level="Institution" Type="ISNI">0000 0001 2336 6580</OrgID>
                    <OrgID Level="Institution" Type="GRID">grid.7605.4</OrgID>
                    <OrgDivision>Department of Oncology</OrgDivision>
                    <OrgName>University of Turin</OrgName>
                    <OrgAddress>
                      <Street>Via Giuseppe Verdi, 8</Street>
                      <Postcode>10124</Postcode>
                      <City>Turin</City>
                      <Country Code="IT">Italy</Country>
                    </OrgAddress>
                  </Affiliation>
                </AuthorGroup>
                <Abstract ID="Abs1" Language="En" OutputMedium="All">
                  <Heading>Abstract</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par1">Typical (TCs) and atypical carcinoids (ACs) are defined based on morphological criteria, and no grading system is currently accepted to further stratify these entities. The 2015 WHO classification restricts the Ki-67 role to biopsy or cytology samples, rather than for prognostic prediction. We aimed to investigate whether values and patterns of Ki-67 alone would allow for a clinically meaningful stratification of lung carcinoids, regardless of histological typing. Ki-67 proliferation index and pattern (homogeneous versus heterogeneous expression) were assessed in a cohort of 171 TCs and 68 ACs. Cases were subdivided into three Ki-67 ranges (&lt;4/4–9/≥10%). Correlations with clinicopathological data, univariate and multivariate survival analyses were performed. The majority of cases (61.5%) belonged to the &lt;4% Ki-67 range; 25.1 and 13.4% had a proliferation index of 4–9% and ≥10%, respectively. The &lt;4% Ki-67 subgroup was significantly enriched for TCs (83%, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.0001); ACs were more frequent in the subgroup showing Ki-67 ≥ 10% (75%, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.0001). A heterogeneous Ki-67 pattern was preferentially seen in carcinoids with a Ki-67 ≥10% (38%, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.02). Mean Ki-67 values ≥4 and ≥10% identified categories of poor prognosis both in terms of disease-free and overall survival (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.003 and &lt;0.0001). At multivariate analysis, the two thresholds did not retain statistical significance; however, a Ki-67 ≥ 10% identified a subgroup of dismal prognosis even within ACs (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.03) at univariate analysis. Here, we describe a subgroup of lung carcinoids showing brisk proliferation activity within the necrosis and/or mitotic count-based categories. These patients were associated with specific clinicopathological characteristics, to some extent regardless of histological subtyping.
                  </Para>
                </Abstract>
                <KeywordGroup Language="En" OutputMedium="All" Source="Author">
                  <Heading>Keywords</Heading>
                  <Keyword>Carcinoid</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Lung</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>WHO classification</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Ki-67</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Heterogeneity</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Prognosis</Keyword>
                </KeywordGroup>
              </ArticleHeader>
              <Body>
                <Section1 ID="Sec1">
                  <Heading>Introduction</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par2">Carcinoid tumours of the lung are rare primary lesions accounting for 0.2% (atypical carcinoids, AC) to 2% (typical carcinoids, TC) of resected lung cancers. According to the 2015 WHO classification [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>], they make up the morphologically defined group of neuroendocrine tumour (NETs) based upon cytological traits, mitotic count and necrosis. Lung NETs comprise low- to intermediate-grade forms (TCs and ACs, respectively), clearly segregated from high-grade malignancies, namely large cell NE carcinomas and small cell carcinomas. Carcinoid tumours, however, translate into a broad clinicopathologic spectrum characterized by highly variable outcomes, which are currently best stratified according to the 2015 WHO classification and 8th edition TNM staging [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. Surgery is the best treatment modality choice for both TCs and ACs [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>], with TCs usually exhibiting long life expectancy with 5- and 10-year survival rate by far over 90% [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">3</CitationRef>]. Conversely, ACs exhibit a more aggressive clinical course and a 5-year survival rate ranging from 56 to 87%, which is lower in node positive patients, suggesting that this subgroup could benefit from some adjuvant treatment [
                    <CitationRef AdditionalCitationIDS="CR5 CR6 CR7" CitationID="CR4">4</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">8</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par3">In pulmonary NETs, whether biopsy samples or surgical specimens, no grading system is currently accepted for further stratifying single tumour entities beyond the pure tumour histological typing. Indeed, the grading system proposed for gastroenteropancreatic (GEP) NETs does not apply to thoracic NETs, nor Ki-67 plays a role in tumour classification. In the 2015 WHO classification, the Ki-67 prognostic role is not established and is considered valuable in biopsy or cytology samples only [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. As a matter of fact, several groups have confirmed the significant prognostic value of Ki-67 in lung NETs [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">9</CitationRef>], with a 4–5% cut-off being the most widely employed for the sake of reproducibility and reliability [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR10">10</CitationRef>] compared to mitotic count and necrosis, especially when dealing with biopsy specimens [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">11</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par4">However, in multivariate survival analysis, Ki-67 seems to add little value to histological typing [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">13</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR14">14</CitationRef>] when a 4–5% cut-off is adopted, but results from several studies are still inconclusive. In order to integrate rather than to replace the histological classification with the information stemming from Ki-67 index determination, Rindi and co-workers have proposed an accurate and innovative grading system for pulmonary NETs (G1 to G3) where mitotic count, necrosis and Ki-67 index were jointly combined on the basis of lung-specific cut-off values [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>]. At the histological level, only TCs by morphology turned out G1, while ACs and the LCNEC/SCLC group crossed G1 to G3 and G2 to G3 categories, respectively, confirming the inherent heterogeneity in behaviour of intermediate- to high-grade lung NETs [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par5">In the GEP area, NET-G3 retaining a well-differentiated morphology but showing proliferation rates consistent with NE carcinomas, either in the whole tumour or in focal areas only, have recently been recognized [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">17</CitationRef>]. These tumours are associated to genetic alterations of well-differentiated tumours, but with a clinical behaviour intermediate between G2 NETs and more conventional NE carcinomas [
                    <CitationRef AdditionalCitationIDS="CR19" CitationID="CR18">18</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">20</CitationRef>]. This phenomenon would identify secondary high-grade NE tumours evolving from pre-existing lower grade carcinoids, as recently demonstrated in the thymus [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">21</CitationRef>]. In the lung, LCNECs with carcinoid-like appearance have been identified [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR22">22</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">23</CitationRef>], but little is known about the clinical impact of carcinoid tumours, as defined by current diagnostic guidelines, showing high Ki-67 indices.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par6">Based on these premises, in this study, we sought to investigate the prevalence of carcinoid tumours showing brisk proliferation activity and to define whether values and patterns of Ki-67 labelling alone would allow for a clinically meaningful stratification of a large cohort of lung carcinoids, regardless of the histological type. This could be propaedeutic to the identification of low- to intermediate-grade NETs in the lung that may have the potential to evolve to a higher grade disease, thus sustaining the paradigm shift to secondary high-grade NETs even in the lung.</Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec2">
                  <Heading>Materials and methods</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec3">
                    <Heading>Cohort and Ki-67 scoring</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par7">The pathology files of the AOU Città della Salute e della Scienza di Torino and San Luigi Hospital were interrogated for a diagnosis of carcinoid tumour on surgical specimen, and a total of 239 consecutive specimens were retrieved. All original H&amp;E slides were reviewed by four of the authors (CM, GG, MV, MP) to confirm the diagnostic categorization, including re-evaluation of the mitotic count and Ki-67 index, the latter on newly stained slides (if unavailable or suboptimal). The cohort comprised 171 TCs and 68 ACs, defined according to the WHO 2015 criteria [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. The study has been approved by the local ethical committee (Department of Oncology at San Luigi Hospital, number 17975, October 14th 2015). Discordant cases were discussed at a multi-headed microscope to reach agreement. We manually scored Ki-67 labelling index by counting at least 1000 cells. We also recorded whether the pattern of Ki-67 labelling was homogeneous throughout tumour samples or whether hotspot areas could be clearly identified (heterogeneous Ki-67 pattern). Whenever hotspot areas were detected, the highest recorded value was taken into account to perform statistical correlative analyses. Hotspot areas were defined as 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">foci</Emphasis> of tumour cells selected at low magnification (40×) based on an overcrowding of positive nuclei that led to a much higher count than the mean Ki-67 index evaluated on the overall tumour cell population. No specific cut-offs were adopted to identify hotspots. This definition allowed to identify areas of heterogeneous proliferation even within the context of TCs, where a proliferation count as low as 1 to 4% is usually encountered.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par8">A dedicated database was constructed where clinicopathological features were annotated, including follow-up data.</Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec4">
                    <Heading>Statistical analysis</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par9">Cases were subdivided according to three different Ki-67 ranges (&lt;4, 4–9, ≥10%) and correlation with histopathological features; pattern of Ki-67 and follow-up data were performed by Chi square test. The 4% threshold for Ki-67 is one of the most frequently adopted in literature [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR14">14</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef AdditionalCitationIDS="CR25" CitationID="CR24">24</CitationRef>–
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR26">26</CitationRef>], while the ≥10% cut-off was chosen based on the mean Ki-67 value of 9% observed in this series of AC (otherwise belonging to the 10–20% range mentioned for carcinoids in the current WHO classification [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]). A 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.05 value was considered statistically significant. Univariate time to progression and overall survival analyses were performed with the Kaplan-Meier method, and the log-rank test was employed to compare survival curves. Cox proportional hazards regression model was also used in multivariate survival analysis.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec5">
                  <Heading>Results</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec6">
                    <Heading>Clinicopathological features</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par10">TCs and ACs showed a mean Ki-67 value of 2.8 and 9%, respectively, ranging from 1 to 18% for TCs and 1 to 43% for ACs (Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1</InternalRef>). Of note, four cases of ACs (1.7% of the total, 5.9% of the ACs) displayed a mean proliferation index of ≥25%.
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Atypical carcinoids showing different Ki-67 patterns (homogenous versus heterogeneous). ACs with organoid and trabecular growth patterns (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis> and 
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis>: H&amp;E 40×, inset 100×) showing a homogenously (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis>: 40×) and heterogeneously (
                              <Emphasis Type="Bold">d</Emphasis>: 40×) increased Ki-67 index, in both cases up to 12%
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO1">
                          <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/428_2017_2177_Fig1_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par11">Stratification of the tumour cohort according to 4 and 10% Ki-67 cut-off thresholds is shown in Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>. The large majority of cases (147/239, 61.5%) pertained to the lowest Ki-67 range (&lt;4%), 60 cases (25.1%) had a proliferation index between 4 and 9%, and a minor subgroup (32/239, 13.4%) displayed a Ki-67 labelling index of ≥10%.
                      <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Table 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Clinicopathological features stratified according to different classes of proliferation, as defined by Ki-67 cut-offs of 4 and 10%</SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>

                        </tgroup>
                        <tfooter>
                          <SimplePara>
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">M</Emphasis> male, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">F</Emphasis> female, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">TC</Emphasis> typical carcinoid, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">AC</Emphasis> atypical carcinoid, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">NED</Emphasis> no evidence of disease, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">DOC</Emphasis> died of other unrelated causes, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">AWD</Emphasis> alive with disease, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">DOD</Emphasis> died of disease, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">OS</Emphasis> overall survival, 
                            <Emphasis Type="Italic">TTP</Emphasis> time to progression
                          </SimplePara>
                        </tfooter>
                      </Table>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par12">The low Ki-67 subgroup (&lt;4%) was significantly enriched for TCs (122/147, 83%, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.0001, Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>), whereas ACs were more frequently found in the subgroup showing a mean Ki-67 of ≥10% (24/32, 75%, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.0001, Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>). Nevertheless, eight cases with a Ki-67 higher than 10% were classified as TC, according to the morphological criteria. A homogeneous Ki-67 labelling pattern was a significant feature of the low (&lt;4%) Ki-67 subgroup (80/93, 86%, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.02, Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>, Fig. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>) as well as of the intermediate (4–9%) Ki-67 subgroup (32/40, 80%, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.02, Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>), whereas a heterogeneous Ki-67 pattern was preferentially seen in the subgroup of carcinoids with a proliferation index of ≥10% (11/29 assessable cases, 38%, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.02, Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>, Figs. 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1</InternalRef> and 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>).
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig2">
                        <!--SingleCol-->
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 2</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Relative prevalence of Ki-67 pattern (homogeneous versus heterogeneous distribution) in lung carcinoids. A homogeneous Ki-67 labelling pattern was significantly more represented in the low (&lt;4%) Ki-67 subgroup (86%, 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.02, Chi square test) and in the intermediate (4–9%) Ki-67 subgroup (80%, 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.02, Chi square test), whereas a heterogeneous Ki-67 pattern was preferentially seen in the subgroup of carcinoids with a proliferation index of ≥10% (38%, 
                              <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.02, Chi square test)
                            </SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO2">
                          <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/428_2017_2177_Fig2_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par13">Vascular invasion and pleural involvement were relatively more represented in the carcinoid subgroup with Ki-67 ≥ 10%, and the differences among subgroups were statistically significant (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.001, Table 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef>).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec7">
                    <Heading>Patient outcome</Heading>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec8">
                      <Heading>Univariate analyses</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par14">Patients with a TC diagnosis had an excellent disease-free and overall survival, which was significantly better compared to patients affected by ACs (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.0001, Tables 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef> and 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab3">3</InternalRef>, Fig. 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3</InternalRef>).
                        <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab2">
                          <Caption Language="En">
                            <CaptionNumber>Table 2</CaptionNumber>
                            <CaptionContent>
                              <SimplePara>Univariate and multivariate time to progression survival analysis</SimplePara>
                            </CaptionContent>
                          </Caption>

                            <colspec align="left" colname="c5" colnum="5"/>
                            <colspec align="left" colname="c6" colnum="6"/>
                            <colspec align="left" colname="c7" colnum="7"/>

                              <row>

                                <entry colname="c7">

                                </entry>
                              </row>

                        </Table>
                        <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig3">
                          <!--SingleCol-->
                          <Caption Language="En">
                            <CaptionNumber>Fig. 3</CaptionNumber>
                            <CaptionContent>
                              <SimplePara>Kaplan-Meier survival curves in lung carcinoids segregated according to histological type (
                                <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis>) and Ki-67 &gt; 4% (
                                <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis>). 
                                <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis> Patients with a TC diagnosis had an excellent overall survival, which was significantly better compared to patients affected by ACs (
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.0001). 
                                <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis> The 4% cut-off on the whole tumour cohort effectively split patients into worse categories for tumours displaying Ki-67 higher than 4% (
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.003)
                              </SimplePara>
                            </CaptionContent>
                          </Caption>
                          <MediaObject ID="MO3">
                            <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/428_2017_2177_Fig3_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                          </MediaObject>
                        </Figure>
                      </Para>
                      <Para ID="Par15">When investigating Ki-67, we first dichotomized cases according to a 4% cut-off on the whole tumour cohort finding that it effectively split patients into worse categories in terms of both disease-free and overall survival for tumours displaying Ki-67 higher than 4% (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.003, Tables 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef> and 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab3">3</InternalRef>; Fig. 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Fig3">3</InternalRef>). The same held true when stratifying cases by using the 10% cut-off threshold, with two different prognostic populations for both time to progression and overall survival (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> &lt; 0.0001, Tables 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef> and 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab3">3</InternalRef>). In addition, when the whole tumour cohort was stratified into three groups according to the 4 and 10% cut-off thresholds, we observed that outcome of patients with tumours pertaining to the three relevant Ki-67 categories (&lt;4, 4–9, ≥10%) was different in terms of both overall survival and time to progression (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.0052 and &lt;0.0001, respectively; Table 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef> and Fig. 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Fig4">4</InternalRef>), with cases displaying a Ki-67 ≥ 10% running a poorer survival. Of note, the difference in terms of outcome between the categories of &lt;4% and 4–9% was not significantly different for either overall survival or time to progression (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.40 and 
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.32, respectively). Importantly, the ≥10% cut-off was capable of significantly predicting patients’ outcome in terms of overall survival (
                        <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.03, Fig. 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Fig4">4</InternalRef>) even in the sole AC subgroup (accounting for the largest number of tumours with a relatively higher Ki-67).
                        <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig4">
                          <!--SingleCol-->
                          <Caption Language="En">
                            <CaptionNumber>Fig. 4</CaptionNumber>
                            <CaptionContent>
                              <SimplePara>Kaplan-Meier survival curves in lung carcinoids segregated according to distinct Ki-67 thresholds (4 and 10%). Analysis of patients’ outcome in terms of overall survival (
                                <Emphasis Type="Bold">a</Emphasis>) and time to progression (
                                <Emphasis Type="Bold">b</Emphasis>) in the whole cohort of lung carcinoids stratified according to 4 and 10% cut-offs. Of note, the difference in terms of outcome between the categories of &lt;4 and 4–9% was not statistically significant for either overall survival or time to progression (
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.40 and 
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.32, respectively). 
                                <Emphasis Type="Bold">c</Emphasis> Subgroup analysis restricted to atypical carcinoids segregated according to the 10% cut-off, which significantly predicted the ultimate outcome of patients (
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> = 0.03) even in the sole AC histological type
                              </SimplePara>
                            </CaptionContent>
                          </Caption>
                          <MediaObject ID="MO4">
                            <ImageObject Color="Color" FileRef="MediaObjects/428_2017_2177_Fig4_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="LinedrawHalftone"/>
                          </MediaObject>
                        </Figure>
                      </Para>
                      <Para ID="Par16">Finally, male sex, G2 Rindi’s grade, presence of vascular invasion or necrosis, and positive nodal status were significantly associated with adverse prognosis at both time to progression and overall survival.</Para>
                    </Section3>
                    <Section3 ID="Sec9">
                      <Heading>Multivariate analysis</Heading>
                      <Para ID="Par17">Male sex, nodal status and histological typing were independent prognostic factors at multivariate analysis, whereas the two Ki-67 cut-off thresholds of ≥4 and ≥10% did not retain statistical significance upon multivariate analysis (Tables 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef> and 
                        <InternalRef RefID="Tab3">3</InternalRef>). The subgroup of ACs was not powered enough to perform a multivariate analysis.
                      </Para>
                    </Section3>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec10">
                  <Heading>Discussion</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par18">In this study, we showed that up to 13% of lung carcinoids display a Ki-67 proliferation index of ≥10% and that 6% of ACs may show Ki-67 values around 25%. Most importantly, a 10% cut-off for Ki-67 labelling index provided a clinically meaningful stratification of carcinoid tumours of the lung even within the subgroup of ACs, thereby providing evidence that proliferation index assessed by Ki-67 would add useful prognostic information to histological subtyping.</Para>
                  <Para ID="Par19">It is currently a matter of debate whether the 2015 WHO classification [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>] is adequate enough to encompass the spectrum of lung NETs. This classification has substantially confirmed the four categories already crystallized in the two previous editions: it is solely based on histological parameters [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR27">27</CitationRef>], and the threshold of 10 mitoses/2 mm
                    <Superscript>2</Superscript> is the criterion used to take pulmonary carcinoids apart from NE carcinomas [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. Here, we show that the rare group of carcinoid tumours is biologically heterogeneous, including a subgroup of lesions with a relatively high proliferative potential as highlighted by the Ki-67 index. From a classification standpoint, the even rarer AC category is monolithic (necrosis and/or 2 to 10 mitoses/2mm
                    <Superscript>2</Superscript>), even if a cut-off of six mitoses has been proposed, but not envisaged, to separate tumours with different life expectation [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR28">28</CitationRef>]. The only diagnostic alternative is the category of high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas, either LCNECs or SCLCs, which is however ruled out upon mitotic count. Interestingly, even LCNECs may show morphologic [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR22">22</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">23</CitationRef>] and molecular [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR23">23</CitationRef>] features rather akin to ACs, supporting the view of a grey-zone in lung NETs where a biological continuum could probably be more effective than categorical criteria for classification purposes. Most importantly, the optimal treatment options for ACs after surgery, particularly in the metastatic setting, are highly debated and variably including close follow-up, systemic therapies different from or comprising platinum or even biological drugs (somatostatin analogues or m-TOR inhibitors).
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par20">Based on this evidence, we reasoned that rather than forcing the four-tier histological classification, an approach based on proliferation activity could be beneficial to best depict the clinical variety within carcinoid tumours, thereby integrating a purely histological classification. At present, over 2000 lung NET cases have been published having Ki-67 investigated as part of the morphological and phenotypical description [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">9</CitationRef>], and most of these studies recognize the usefulness of Ki-67 index reporting. A multicentre study on almost 400 cases proposed a grading system for lung NETs incorporating the Ki-67 index alongside mitotic count and necrosis evaluation [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par21">In our study, we wanted to ascertain whether Ki-67 alone, not engaged in a grading system, would allow a prognostic classification within the category of carcinoid tumours with the specific aim of identifying a niche of carcinoid tumours (defined according to the official parameters) having a proliferation index above the expected values. Our results clearly show a prognostic separation in terms of both overall survival and time to progression when cut-offs of 4 and 10% are adopted. Our analysis also revealed that the tumours with either &lt;4 or 4–9% proliferation indices showed comparable survival rates, thus suggesting the 10% as a more suitable cut-off to identify lung carcinoids with a clinically meaningful brisk proliferation activity.</Para>
                  <Para ID="Par22">The adoption of Rindi’s grade (grade 2 versus 1) showed a significant correlation with outcome in univariate but not in multivariate analysis. Although also the Ki-67 thresholds here analysed did not reach statistical significance in multivariate analysis, it is interesting to note that the 10% cut-off was able to tease out a category of tumours harbouring dismal prognosis even within the restricted category of ACs, whereas Rindi’s grade did not hold significant prognostic information in this subset of patients.</Para>
                  <Para ID="Par23">Importantly, a heterogeneous Ki-67 proliferation pattern was significantly more common in the category of cases displaying a Ki-67 labelling index ≥10%. This is in line with recent reports suggesting that intra-tumour heterogeneity holds per se a negative prognostic impact, as shown across several distinct diseases [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR29">29</CitationRef>].
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par24">We documented in our study that a non-negligible number of life-threatening ACs showed quite unexpected high Ki-67 indices, which overlapped with those reported for LCNECs [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR9">9</CitationRef>], even if not fulfilling the relevant mitotic count for this tumour category. Although Ki-67 levels and mitoses do not entirely reflect the same cell cycle-associated event, it is known that pancreatic NETs with discrepant Ki-67 and mitotic indices bear different impacts on tumour grading [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR30">30</CitationRef>]. Moreover, we speculate that these ACs with high Ki-67 index could harbour a potential of transition towards LCNECs with similar molecular profiles, either synchronously or metachronously, as recently demonstrated in thymus ACs [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">21</CitationRef>]. Furthermore, a recent study by Simbolo et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR31">31</CitationRef>] has also shown that rare lung LCNECs resembling carcinoids harbour 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">MEN1</Emphasis> mutations—the most frequent alteration in ACs—along with 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">TERT</Emphasis>, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">SDHA</Emphasis>, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">RICTOR</Emphasis>, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">PIK3CA</Emphasis>, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">MYCL</Emphasis> and 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">SRC</Emphasis> gains are shared with high-grade carcinomas. This is in line with a paradigm shift, even in the lung, that envisages the development of secondary high-grade NETs from pre-existing lower grade NETs, as demonstrated in the thymus [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR21">21</CitationRef>]. Regrettably, the numerosity of outlier tumour carcinoids, i.e. either highly proliferating or harbouring genetic features of aggressive disease (
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">TP53</Emphasis> mutations, hypermutated profile), was too limited in the recent study reported by Simbolo et al. [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR31">31</CitationRef>] to draw any informative conclusions. In this scenario, it becomes clear that a thorough genomic characterization focused on a large cohort of highly proliferating carcinoid tumours in strict comparison with LCNECs and SCLCs is eagerly awaited.
                  </Para>
                  <Para ID="Par25">In conclusion, although the histological subtyping still represents the cornerstone in lung carcinoid classification, the inter- and intra-tumour heterogeneity of proliferation indices together with different clinical behaviour within the same histological subgroups suggest that the current morphology-based system could be suboptimal for an effective prognostic stratification and therapy planning. Herein, we indicate that a subgroup of ACs showed brisk Ki-67 indices within the spectrum of allowed mitotic count. These patients were associated with specific clinical and pathological characteristics, to some extent regardless of histological subtyping. Preliminary data obtained by our group in thymus ACs on synchronous and metachronous lesions suggest that a progression capability of these lesions may stem form a markedly heterogeneous intra-tumour distribution of Ki-67 labelling indices. The correct identification of these tumours is clinically warranted. A thorough molecular characterization of this specific high proliferative index carcinoid subgroup may uncover the determinants of their biology and/or progression capacity, as well as identify biomarkers of potential therapeutic usefulness.</Para>
                </Section1>
              </Body>
              <BodyRef FileRef="BodyRef/PDF/428_2017_Article_2177.pdf" TargetType="OnlinePDF"/>
              <ArticleBackmatter>

                  <Citation ID="CR11">
                    <CitationNumber>11.</CitationNumber>
                    <BibArticle>
                      <BibAuthorName>
                        <Initials>A</Initials>
                        <FamilyName>Fabbri</FamilyName>
                      </BibAuthorName>

                      </Occurrence>
                    </BibArticle>
                    <BibUnstructured>Simbolo M, Mafficini A, Sikora KO, Fassan M, Barbi S, Corbo V, Mastracci L, Rusev B, Grillo F, Vicentini C, Ferrara R, Pilotto S, Davini F, Pelosi G, Lawlor RT, Chilosi M, Tortora G, Bria E, Fontanini G, Volante M, Scarpa A (2017) Lung neuroendocrine tumours: deep sequencing of the four WHO histotypes reveals chromatin remodelling genes as major players and a prognostic role for TERT, RB1, MEN1 and KMT2D. J Pathol 241(4):488–500. doi:
                      <ExternalRef>
                        <RefSource>10.1002/path.4853</RefSource>
                        <RefTarget Address="10.1002/path.4853" TargetType="DOI"/>
                      </ExternalRef>
                    </BibUnstructured>
                  </Citation>
                </Bibliography>
              </ArticleBackmatter>
            </Article>
          </Issue>
        </Volume>

                <ArticleTitle Language="En" OutputMedium="All">Diagnosing filamentous fungal infections in immunocompromised patients applying computed tomography-guided percutaneous lung biopsies: a 12-year experience</ArticleTitle>

                      <Country Code="AT">Austria</Country>
                    </OrgAddress>
                  </Affiliation>
                  <Affiliation ID="Aff7">
                    <OrgID Level="Institution" Type="ISNI">0000 0000 8853 2677</OrgID>
                    <OrgID Level="Institution" Type="GRID">grid.5361.1</OrgID>
                    <OrgDivision>Department of Internal Medicine II</OrgDivision>
                    <OrgName>Medical University of Innsbruck</OrgName>

                      <Country Code="AT">Austria</Country>
                    </OrgAddress>
                  </Affiliation>
                </AuthorGroup>
                <Abstract ID="Abs1" Language="En" OutputMedium="All">
                  <Heading>Abstract</Heading>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec1">
                    <Heading>Background</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par1">Invasive fungal diseases (IFD) are an important cause of morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients, and early diagnosis and management are a challenge. We evaluated the clinical utility of computed tomography (CT)-guided percutaneous lung biopsies in diagnosing IFD.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec2">
                    <Heading>Methods</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par2">Between 2003 and 2014, we analyzed 2671 CT-guided lung biopsies, from which 157 were IFD associated; we aimed to determine microbiological-based diagnostic accuracy of calcofluor white staining (CFWS), culture, 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> antigen detection (GM), broad-range fungal PCR, and 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR per sample.
                    </Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec3">
                    <Heading>Results</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par3">127 (81%) specimens were microscopically positive for any fungal elements, 30 (19%) negative. 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> and non-
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> like hyphae were obtained in 85 (67%) and 42 (33%) specimens, respectively. CFWS positivity was defined as proof of infection. Sensitivity, specificity, and positive (PPV) and negative predictive (NPV) values for CT scan were 100, 44, 80, and 100%, for 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR 89, 58, 88, and 58%, for broad-range fungal PCR 90, 83, 95, and 90%, and for GM 94, 83, 95, and 90%. The most common CT features were patchy opacifications with central necrosis (78%) or cavern defects (50%), less common were air bronchograms (39%) or ground glass halos (39%), and all other features were rare. The overall pneumothorax rate subsequent to biopsy was 19%, but in only 2% of all cases the placement of a chest tube was indicated. One case of fatal air embolism occurred.
                    </Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                  <AbstractSection ID="ASec4">
                    <Heading>Conclusions</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par4">CT-guided lung biopsies have high diagnostic accuracy in terms of microscopic examination, and complication rates are low. Molecular-based and antigen tests applied on fungal hyphae-positive specimens showed comparable results.</Para>
                  </AbstractSection>
                </Abstract>
                <KeywordGroup Language="En" OutputMedium="All" Source="Author">
                  <Heading>Keywords</Heading>
                  <Keyword>
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis>
                  </Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Mucormycoses</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Fungal infection</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Invasive fungal disease</Keyword>
                  <Keyword>Computed tomography-guided lung biopsy</Keyword>
                </KeywordGroup>
              </ArticleHeader>
              <Body>
                <Section1 ID="Sec1">
                  <Heading>Introduction</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par5">Invasive fungal diseases (IFD) are a major cause of morbidity and mortality in immunocompromised patients [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR1">1</CitationRef>]. Case fatality rates range from 30 to 80% in neutropenic patients and result at least partly from difficulties in obtaining a reliable diagnosis at an early stage of disease. The diagnostic workup may consist of imaging techniques, culture, serology, and molecular-based methods. Culture-based methods are often delayed and may have low sensitivity [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>], because the materials used are not picked up from the proper site of ongoing, progressive infection yielding necrotic tissue. In most instances, an antimycotic treatment had already been started, so that the viability of the pathogens is hampered. Galactomannan detection in body fluids is more sensitive than culture for diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis (IA), but sensitivity is variable (17–100%) [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>]. Only moderate data are available for 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR3">3</CitationRef>] and β-
                    <Emphasis Type="SmallCaps">d</Emphasis>-glucan (Fungitell, Associates of Cape Cod) [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR4">4</CitationRef>] in diagnosing IFD, from blood and broncho-alveolar lavages (BAL). Imaging has a crucial role in the diagnosis and management of patients with suspected IFD who are immunocompromised [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR2">2</CitationRef>]. The preferred method of choice is a computed tomography (CT) scan, as chest radiography might show normal or non-specific findings in neutropenic patients with IFD [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR5">5</CitationRef>]. Although the halo sign and air crescent sign are characteristic, they are not diagnostic of IA. Infections due to other angioinvasive fungi, such as Mucorales, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Fusarium</Emphasis> spp. as well as 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Nocardia</Emphasis> spp. may cause radiological features described for IA [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR6">6</CitationRef>, 
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR7">7</CitationRef>]. However, the identification of the causative organism is highly warranted for a targeted treatment, especially if patients fail to respond to standard anti-mold therapy. Mucorales are resistant to the newer antifungal drugs such as voriconazole and echinocandins [
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR8">8</CitationRef>] and therefore the choice of first-line treatment is (liposomal) amphotericin B; 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">A. terreus</Emphasis>, by contrast, is amphotericin B resistant; both fungal pathogens are frequently involved in pulmonary infections in our patient cohort [
                    <CitationRef AdditionalCitationIDS="CR10" CitationID="CR9">9</CitationRef>–
                    <CitationRef CitationID="CR11">11</CitationRef>]. Hence, our center needs a powerful diagnostic strategy with the performance of CT-guided lung biopsies displaying a standard of care. Here, we aimed to investigate the value of CT-guided lung biopsies in diagnosing IFDs in immunocompromised patients and best practice specimen handling, applying Calcofluor White staining (CFWS), culture, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> antigen detection (GM), broad-range fungal PCR, and 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR in lung specimens obtained during 2003–2014.
                  </Para>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec2">
                  <Heading>Materials and methods</Heading>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec3">
                    <Heading>Patients</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par6">We attended to 2671 patients undergoing lung biopsy for any diagnostic reason, including cancer, infectious diseases, and others between 2003 and 2014. Of them, 179 patients were evaluated with fever and a CT scan compatible with filamentous fungal lung infections according to EORTC/MSG criteria [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR12">12</CitationRef>]. Of these patients, 168 eligible patients underwent CT-guided lung biopsies because they either did not improve during standard antifungal therapy or the proof of diagnosis was important for further medical procedures. From this cohort, 11 samples were excluded for various reasons such as lack of triple diagnostic tests performed (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 6), PCR inhibition (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 2), or lack of detailed clinical data (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 3). Thus, data were evaluated of 157 patients, with the majority having underlying hematological malignancies (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 85), solid organ transplantations (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 40), solid cancer (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 19) or otherwise severe immunocompromised conditions (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 13). Lung biopsy specimens were investigated for the presence of fungal pathogens.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par7">Patients received standard of care treatment, including antibiotics and antifungals, and those with hematological malignancies and or allogeneic/autologous stem cell transplantations and or lung transplantation received standard prophylaxis with fluconazole, and/or posaconazole, and/or micafungin if indicated [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR13">13</CitationRef>]. CT scans were performed as part of the diagnostic workup and were reviewed by a senior radiologist for evidence of fungal infection, which included the presence and distribution of nodule(s) and/or consolidations with or without ground-glass opacities, a halo sign, and an air crescent sign and cavitation. Various CT scanners of different vendors and protocols with various slice thickness with or without intravenous contrast enhancement were used over the time. In all patients, the whole chest was scanned continuously utilizing a multidetector spiral CT technique, including a high-resolution mode with at least 1.0 mm or even sub-millimeter slice thickness.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par8">Patients who were hemodynamically unstable or in whom platelet counts could not be maintained over 60 × 10
                      <Superscript>9</Superscript>/l were excluded. Thrombocytopenic patients received platelet transfusions before the procedure, at the discretion of the clinical team, and a prothrombin time of at least 50% (normal range 70–130%) was requested. Patients suspected to suffer from IFDs were on empirical antifungal therapy at the time of taking lung biopsies.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec4">
                    <Heading>CT-guided percutaneous lung biopsies</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par9">Lung biopsies were performed by different radiologists, exclusively using CT. Two CT devices, equipped with the Smart-Step technique, were deployed for this purpose (Lightspeed 16 or VCT 64, GE Healthcare) [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR14">14</CitationRef>]. Decisions for patient management were made on a case-by-case basis by the radiologists, based on size and location of the pulmonary lesion. After the intervention, patients were routinely monitored and initially chest radiographs and after 2007 low-dose CTs of the entire chest thorax [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR15">15</CitationRef>] were obtained during follow-up to exclude complications, particularly pneumothorax.
                    </Para>
                    <Para ID="Par10">CT-guided percutaneous biopsies were performed with an automated biopsy gun with a detachable coaxial cutting needle system (Bard
                      <Superscript>®</Superscript>) as described by Lucidarme et al. [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR16">16</CitationRef>]. In our study, an outer coaxial needle with 18-gauge diameter and an inner biopsy needle with 17-gauge diameter were chosen with a local anesthesia with 1% lidocaine, either without or, in most cases, with general anesthesia. On average, 8.5 ± 3.3 samples were taken, with a length of either 1.5 or 2.2 cm. Clinical specimens were collected at the Division of Hygiene and Medical Microbiology, Medical University of Innsbruck, and samples were aseptically divided into three fractions for microscopy, culture, PCR, and GM testing.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec5">
                    <Heading>Fungal microbiology</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par11">Biopsy specimens, transferred to 2 ml normal saline were minced and homogenized aseptically. Afterward, samples were vortexed, kept at room temperature for 30 min, and centrifuged. All specimens, consisting of supernatants and homogenized tissues, were investigated for fungi by application of the Fungi-Fluor™ (Calcofluor White staining solution, Polysciences, USA; CFWS staining). Samples which showed 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis>-like hyphae were tested for GM and 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR17">17</CitationRef>, 
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR18">18</CitationRef>] positivity. GM (BioRad, Austria) was performed according to the instructions of the company and a 0.5 cutoff was used to define the positivity for GM. Samples which showed non-
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis>-like hyphae by CFWS and which remained negative in GM and 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR were evaluated by a broad-range PCR using internally transcribed spacer region (ITS) [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR19">19</CitationRef>]. In parallel, all samples were cultured in Sabouraud Dextrose Broth at 37 °C for 14 days. For controls, 24 CT-guided lung biopsies not associated with any IFD were evaluated applying all microbiological assays. Figure 
                      <InternalRef RefID="Fig1">1</InternalRef> shows a flow diagram of the sequence of diagnostic tests applied.
                      <Figure Category="Standard" Float="Yes" ID="Fig1">
                        <Caption Language="En">
                          <CaptionNumber>Fig. 1</CaptionNumber>
                          <CaptionContent>
                            <SimplePara>Flow diagram of the sequence of diagnostic test applied</SimplePara>
                          </CaptionContent>
                        </Caption>
                        <MediaObject ID="MO1">
                          <ImageObject Color="BlackWhite" FileRef="MediaObjects/15010_2017_1072_Fig1_HTML.gif" Format="GIF" Rendition="HTML" Type="Linedraw"/>
                        </MediaObject>
                      </Figure>
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec6">
                    <Heading>Criteria for fungal diagnosis</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par12">Proven pulmonary IA was defined as positive tissue biopsy showing typical septate, acute branching hyphae (CFWS) with positive GM and 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR tests and with or without positive cultures for 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis>. Proven pulmonary IFD (non-
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> fungal infection) was defined as positive tissue biopsy showing unseptate or sparsely septate, broad, and irregular hyphae with positive panfungal PCR tests and with or without positive culture for any suitable fungus. Samples with negative results were reported as sterile; samples showing technical difficulties were excluded from the analysis (
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">n</Emphasis> = 11).
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                  <Section2 ID="Sec7">
                    <Heading>Statistical analysis</Heading>
                    <Para ID="Par13">The primary purpose of the study was to evaluate the feasibility of lung biopsies in diagnosing fungal infections in immunocompromised patients. The secondary purposes were to determine the outcome in terms of diagnostic yield and to determine the complications related to the procedure. The Society of Interventional Radiology clinical practice guidelines of 2003 were used to classify minor and major complications [
                      <CitationRef CitationID="CR20">20</CitationRef>]. Statistical analysis included a 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">t</Emphasis> test for assessing the difference in continuous values between the two groups (i.e. patients with 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> infections and patients with non-
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> filamentous fungal infections); a Chi square test was used to assess the difference in categorical values between the two groups. A 
                      <Emphasis Type="Italic">p</Emphasis> value &lt; 0.05 was considered to be statistically significant.
                    </Para>
                  </Section2>
                </Section1>
                <Section1 ID="Sec8">
                  <Heading>Results</Heading>
                  <Para ID="Par14">Using CFWS, 127 (81%) samples were positive for any fungal elements, 30 (19%) remained negative. 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus-</Emphasis> and non-
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis>-like hyphae were obtained in 85 (67%) and 42 (33%) specimens, respectively (Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab1">1</InternalRef> and Fig. 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Fig2">2</InternalRef>). Fungal species identification done by micromorphology or molecular-based methods yielded 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> spp., Mucoraceae and others (Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab2">2</InternalRef>); cultures were positive in only 62 samples investigated. Control specimens remained culture, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR, broad-range PCR, and GM antigen test negative in all cases. CFWS positivity, which reflects proof of an infection according to EORTC criteria (golden standard), was defined as the standard of comparison; sensitivity, specificity, and positive (PPV) and negative predictive (NPV) values for CT scan, 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> PCR, broad-range PCR, and GM from lung biopsy specimens are outlined in Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab3">3</InternalRef>. Antifungal therapy at time of biopsy consisted of voriconazole and/or echinocandins in 55% of patients suffering from non-
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> infections, hence displaying lack of activity against fungal pathogens identified. Over the years, a shift from 
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> to non-
                    <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> infections took place and, based on antifungal treatment strategies applied, it is obvious that anti-mold prophylaxis successfully prevents IA, as only five cases were detected during 2011 and 2014. In comparison, 80 IA cases were detected between 2003 and 2010, respectively, see Table 
                    <InternalRef RefID="Tab4">4</InternalRef>.
                    <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab1">
                      <Caption Language="En">
                        <CaptionNumber>Table 1</CaptionNumber>

                        </CaptionContent>
                      </Caption>

                      <tfooter>
                        <SimplePara>
                          <Emphasis Type="Italic">PPV</Emphasis> positive predictive value, 
                          <Emphasis Type="Italic">NPV</Emphasis> negative predictive value
                        </SimplePara>
                        <SimplePara>CT-guided lung samples resulted from 127 patients and 24 control (negative) patients</SimplePara>
                        <SimplePara>
                          <Superscript>a</Superscript> Over the last 12 years, we used various 
                          <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus-</Emphasis>specific PCR assays targeting the 18S ribosomal RNA
                        </SimplePara>
                        <SimplePara>
                          <Superscript>b</Superscript> We applied a broad-range PCR using the internal transcribed spacer region
                        </SimplePara>
                        <SimplePara>
                          <Superscript>c</Superscript> GM testing defined a cutoff value of 0.5
                        </SimplePara>
                      </tfooter>
                    </Table>
                    <Table Float="Yes" ID="Tab4">
                      <Caption Language="En">
                        <CaptionNumber>Table 4</CaptionNumber>
                        <CaptionContent>
                          <SimplePara>Fungal pathogens identified, treatment modalities, and diagnostic tests applied over the last 12 years in immunosuppressed patients</SimplePara>
                        </CaptionContent>
                      </Caption>
                      <tgroup cols="4">
                        <colspec align="left" colname="c1" colnum="1"/>
                        <colspec align="left" colname="c2" colnum="2"/>
                        <colspec align="left" colname="c3" colnum="3"/>
                        <colspec align="left" colname="c4" colnum="4"/>
                        <thead>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>Time period</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>2003–2006</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>2007–2010</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>2011–2014</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>Number of patients with proven lung infections</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>55
                                <Superscript>a</Superscript>
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>43</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>29</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" nameend="c4" namest="c1">
                              <SimplePara>Fungal pathogens identified</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">Aspergillus</Emphasis> species
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>42</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>38</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>5</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">A. terreus</Emphasis> complex
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>24</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>19</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>1</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">A. fumigatus</Emphasis> complex
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>18</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>16</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>1</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>
                                <Emphasis Type="Italic">A. flavus</Emphasis> complex
                              </SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>0</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>1</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>1</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">
                              <SimplePara>  Other species</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>0</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c3">
                              <SimplePara>2</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c4">
                              <SimplePara>2</SimplePara>
                            </entry>
                          </row>
                          <row>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c1">

                            </entry>
                            <entry align="left" colname="c2">
                              <SimplePara>5</SimplePara>
